time-\nbased vesting) covering a number of shares of Rockwell Collins common stock (rounded down to the nearest whole share)\ndetermined by multiplying the number of shares of B/E Aerospace that were subject to the B/E Aerospace award by a ratio of the\nvalue of the merger consideration divided by the Rockwell Collins stock price (with the value of the stock consideration portion of\nthe merger consideration determined by multiplying the number of such shares of Rockwell Collins common stock by the Rockwell\nCollins stock price).\n\nTreatment of B/E Aerospace Stock Units\n\n        Each stock unit credited to the account of any current or former director under the B/E Aerospace Amended and Restated Non-\nEmployee Directors Stock and Deferred Compensation Plan that is outstanding immediately prior to the effective time of the\nmerger, which is referred to as the effective time, will be converted into the right to receive the merger consideration.\n\n        For a more complete description of the treatment of outstanding restricted stock unit awards granted to the executive officers of\nB/E Aerospace in November 2016, see "The Merger\xe2\x80\x94Interests of Directors and Executive Officers in the Merger" beginning on\npage 102.\n\nRockwell Collins\n\n        The merger will not affect Rockwell Collins\' stock-based awards. All such awards will remain outstanding subject to the same\nterms and conditions that are applicable to such stock-based awards prior to the merger.\n\nRockwell Collins Board of Directors Following Completion of the Merger \n\n        The merger agreement provides that Rockwell Collins will take all necessary corporate action so that, upon and after the\neffective time, the size of the Rockwell Collins Board will be increased by two members to a total of eleven, and two individuals\nselected by B/E Aerospace who meet Rockwell Collins\' independence criteria and are otherwise reasonably acceptable to Rockwell\nCollins will be appointed to the Rockwell Collins Board. One such individual will serve as a member of the class of directors of the\nRockwell Collins Board with terms expiring in 2018, and the other will serve as a member of the class of directors of the Rockwell\nCollins Board with terms expiring in 2020. Pursuant to this provision of the merger agreement, John T. Whates and Richard G.\nHamermesh, both members of the B/E Aerospace Board, were selected by B/E Aerospace to be appointed to the Rockwell Collins\nBoard and are expected to serve as members of the class of directors of the Rockwell Collins Board with terms expiring in 2018 and\n2020, respectively. Other than such additional directors, no changes to the Rockwell Collins Board are expected in connection with\nthe consummation of the merger.\n\n        For a more complete description of the directors and executive officers of the surviving corporation, see "The Merger\xe2\x80\x94\nGovernance of Rockwell Collins Following Completion of the Merger" beginning on page 101.\n\nHeadquarters \n\n        Upon completion of the transaction, Rockwell Collins\' headquarters will remain in Cedar Rapids, Iowa.\n\n20\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n28/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nRecommendations of the Rockwell Collins Board of Directors \n\n        After careful consideration, the Rockwell Collins Board unanimously recommends that holders of Rockwell Collins common\nstock vote:\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n"FOR" the Share Issuance proposal; and \n\n"FOR" the Rockwell Collins Adjournment proposal.\n\n        For further discussion of the Rockwell Collins Board\'s reasons for the transaction and the recommendations of the Rockwell\nCollins Board, see "The Merger\xe2\x80\x94Rockwell Collins Board of Directors\' Recommendations and Its Reasons for the Transaction"\nbeginning on page 66.\n\nRecommendations of the B/E Aerospace Board of Directors \n\n        After careful consideration, the B/E Aerospace Board unanimously recommends that holders of B/E Aerospace common stock\nvote:\n\n"FOR" the Merger proposal; \n\n"FOR" the Merger-Related Compensation proposal to approve, on an advisory (non-binding) basis, any\n"golden parachute" compensation arrangement that may be paid or become payable to B/E Aerospace\'s\nnamed executive officers that is based on or otherwise relates to the merger or contemplated by the merger\nagreement; and \n\n"FOR" the B/E Aerospace Adjournment proposal.\n\n        For a more complete description of the B/E Aerospace Board\'s reasons for the transaction and the recommendation of the B/E\nAerospace Board, see "The Merger\xe2\x80\x94B/E Aerospace Board of Directors\' Recommendations and Its Reasons for the Transaction"\nbeginning on page 70.\n\nOpinions of Financial Advisors \n\nRockwell Collins\' Financial Advisor\n\nOpinion of J.P. Morgan Securities LLC\n\n        Rockwell Collins retained J.P. Morgan Securities LLC, which is referred to as J.P. Morgan, to act as its financial advisor in\nconnection with the proposed merger. At the meeting of the Rockwell Collins Board on October 21, 2016, J.P. Morgan rendered its\noral opinion to the Rockwell Collins Board that, as of such date and based upon and subject to the factors and assumptions set forth\nin its opinion, the merger consideration to be paid by Rockwell Collins was fair, from a financial point of view, to Rockwell Collins.\nThe oral opinion was subsequently confirmed in writing by delivery of J.P. Morgan\'s written opinion dated October 23, 2016.\n\n        The full text of the written opinion of J.P. Morgan, which sets forth the assumptions made, matters considered and\nlimits on the review undertaken, is attached as Annex B to this joint proxy statement/prospectus and is incorporated herein\nby reference. The summary of the opinion of J.P. Morgan set forth in this joint proxy statement/prospectus is qualified in its\nentirety by reference to the full text of such opinion. Rockwell Collins stockholders are urged to read the opinion in its\nentirety. J.P. Morgan\'s opinion was addressed to the Rockwell Collins Board (in its capacity as such) in connection with and\nfor the purposes of its evaluation of the merger, was directed only to the fairness, from a financial point of view, to Rockwell\nCollins of the merger consideration to be paid by Rockwell Collins and did not address any other aspect of the merger. J.P.\nMorgan expressed no opinion as to the fairness of the merger consideration to the holders of any class of securities, creditors\nor other constituencies of Rockwell Collins or as to the underlying decision by Rockwell Collins to engage in the merger. The\nissuance of J.P. Morgan\'s opinion was approved by a fairness committee of J.P. Morgan.\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n29/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n21\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n30/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nThe opinion does not constitute a recommendation to any stockholder of Rockwell Collins as to how such stockholder should\nvote with respect to the merger or any other matter.\n\nB/E Aerospace\'s Financial Advisors\n\nOpinion of Citigroup Global Markets Inc.\n\n        On October 23, 2016, Citigroup Global Markets Inc., which is referred to as Citigroup, delivered to the B/E Aerospace Board a\nwritten opinion dated October 23, 2016, to the effect that, as of such date and based on and subject to the assumptions made,\nprocedures followed, matters considered and limitations and qualifications set forth in the written opinion, each as described in\ngreater detail in the section entitled "The Merger\xe2\x80\x94Opinions of B/E Aerospace\'s Financial Advisors" beginning on page 82, the\nmerger consideration to be received by the holders of outstanding shares of common stock of B/E Aerospace, other than shares of\nB/E Aerospace common stock held by holders who are entitled to, and properly demand, appraisal of their shares of B/E Aerospace\ncommon stock and shares of B/E Aerospace common stock that are owned, directly or indirectly, by Rockwell Collins, B/E\nAerospace (as treasury shares or otherwise) or Merger Sub (collectively, referred to as the excluded holders) in the merger was fair,\nfrom a financial point of view, to such holders. Citigroup\'s opinion, the issuance of which was authorized by Citigroup\'s fairness\nopinion committee, was provided to the B/E Aerospace Board in connection with its evaluation of the merger and was limited to the\nfairness, from a financial point of view, as of the date of Citigroup\'s opinion, to the holders of outstanding shares of common stock\nof B/E Aerospace (other than excluded holders) of the merger consideration to be received by such holders in the merger.\n\n        Citigroup\'s opinion does not address any other aspects or implications of the merger and does not constitute a\nrecommendation to any stockholder as to how such stockholder should vote or act on any matters relating to the merger.\nThe summary of Citigroup\'s opinion contained in this joint proxy statement/prospectus is qualified in its entirety by\nreference to the full text of the opinion. We encourage you to read the full text of Citigroup\'s written opinion, which is\nattached to this joint proxy statement/prospectus as Annex C and sets forth, among other things, the assumptions made,\nprocedures followed, matters considered and limitations and qualifications on the scope of review undertaken.\n\nOpinion of Goldman, Sachs & Co.\n\n        On October 23, 2016, Goldman, Sachs & Co., which is referred to as Goldman Sachs, delivered to the B/E Aerospace Board a\nwritten opinion dated October 23, 2016, to the effect that, as of such date and based upon and subject to the factors and assumptions\nset forth therein, the merger consideration to be paid to the holders (other than Rockwell Collins and its affiliates) of outstanding\nshares of common stock of B/E Aerospace pursuant to the merger agreement was fair from a financial point of view to such holders.\n\n        The full text of the written opinion of Goldman Sachs, dated October 23, 2016, which sets forth assumptions made,\nprocedures followed, matters considered and limitations on the review undertaken in connection with the opinion, is\nattached as Annex D. Goldman Sachs provided its opinion for the information and assistance of the B/E Aerospace Board in\nconnection with its consideration of the merger. The Goldman Sachs opinion is not a recommendation as to how any holder\nof B/E Aerospace common stock should vote with respect to the merger or any other matter.\n\nInterests of Directors and Executive Officers in the Merger \n\n        The directors and executive officers of B/E Aerospace have interests in the merger that are in addition to their interests as\nstockholders of B/E Aerospace generally. These interests include, but are not limited to, continued employment of certain executive\nofficers with the surviving company,\n\n22\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n31/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nindemnification and insurance for current and former directors and executive officers, transaction bonuses for certain executive\nofficers and the treatment in the merger of B/E Aerospace restricted stock units, restricted stock awards and other equity-based\nawards held by these directors and executive officers (including accelerated vesting of B/E Aerospace restricted stock units and\nrestricted stock awards immediately upon the effective time). Certain B/E Aerospace executive officers are, by reason of their\nrespective employment agreements with B/E Aerospace, entitled to severance payments and other benefits immediately upon the\nconsummation of the merger (certain other executive officers are entitled to severance payments and benefits upon a qualifying\ntermination of employment following the merger). In addition, Richard G. Hamermesh and John T. Whates, both members of the\nB/E Aerospace Board, will be appointed to the Rockwell Collins Board. The B/E Aerospace Board was aware of these interests and\nconsidered them, among other matters, in approving the merger agreement and in determining to recommend that B/E Aerospace\nstockholders adopt the merger agreement.\n\nU.S. Federal Income Tax Consequences of the Merger \n\n        The exchange of B/E Aerospace common stock pursuant to the merger will be a taxable transaction for U.S. federal income tax\npurposes. Accordingly, a U.S. holder (as defined in "The Merger\xe2\x80\x94U.S. Federal Income Tax Consequences" beginning on page 125)\nof B/E Aerospace common stock who receives the merger consideration in exchange for such U.S. holder\'s shares of B/E Aerospace\ncommon stock generally will recognize taxable gain or loss in an amount equal to the difference, if any, between (i) the sum of the\nfair market value of the Rockwell Collins common stock and the amount of cash, including cash in lieu of fractional shares,\nreceived in the merger and (ii) such U.S. holder\'s adjusted tax basis in the shares of B/E Aerospace common stock exchanged\ntherefor. If you are a non-U.S. holder, the merger generally will not result in tax to you under U.S. federal income tax laws unless\nyou have certain connections with the United States.\n\n        This joint proxy statement/prospectus contains a general discussion of United States federal income tax consequences of\nthe merger. This description does not address any non-U.S. tax consequences, nor does it pertain to state, local or other tax\nconsequences. Consequently, you are urged to contact your own tax advisor to determine the particular tax consequences to\nyou of the merger.\n\nAccounting Treatment of the Merger \n\nAppraisal Rights \n\n        The merger will be accounted for as an acquisition of B/E Aerospace by Rockwell Collins under the acquisition method of\naccounting in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the U.S., which is referred to as GAAP.\n\n        Under Delaware law, Rockwell Collins stockholders will not be entitled to any appraisal rights in connection with the merger\nor any other transactions described in this joint proxy statement/prospectus.\n\n        Under Delaware law, if the merger is completed, record holders of B/E Aerospace common stock who do not vote in favor of\nthe adoption of the merger agreement and who otherwise properly exercise their appraisal rights will be entitled to seek appraisal\nfor, and obtain payment in cash for the judicially determined fair value of, their shares of B/E Aerospace common stock, in lieu of\nreceiving the merger consideration. The "fair value" could be higher or lower than, or the same as, the merger consideration. The\nrelevant provisions of the DGCL are included as Annex E to this joint proxy statement/prospectus. B/E Aerospace stockholders are\nencouraged to read these provisions carefully and in their entirety. Moreover, due to the complexity of the procedures for exercising\nthe right to seek appraisal, B/E Aerospace stockholders who are considering exercising that right are encouraged to seek the advice\nof legal counsel. Failure to comply strictly with these provisions may result in loss of the right of appraisal. For a more complete\ndescription of B/E Aerospace stockholders\' appraisal rights, see "The Merger\xe2\x80\x94Appraisal Rights" beginning on page 119.\n\n23\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n32/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\n \n\nRegulatory Approvals \n\n        The merger is subject to the requirements of the Hart-Scott-Rodino Antitrust Improvements Act of 1976, as amended, which is\nreferred to as the HSR Act, which prevents Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace from completing the merger until required\ninformation and materials are furnished to the Antitrust Division of the Department of Justice, which is referred to as the DOJ, and\nthe Federal Trade Commission, which is referred to as the FTC, and the HSR Act waiting period is terminated or expires. On\nNovember 7, 2016, Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace filed the requisite notification and report forms under the HSR Act with\nthe DOJ and the FTC. The required 30-day waiting period under the HSR Act expired at 11:59 Eastern time on December 7, 2016.\n\n        The merger is also subject to antitrust review by governmental authorities in several foreign jurisdictions in which the\ncompanies have a sufficient market presence to require filings. The parties are making filings in Europe, China, the Philippines,\nSouth Korea and Turkey.\n\n        Although we expect that all regulatory clearances and approvals will be obtained, we cannot assure you that these clearances\nand approvals will be timely obtained or obtained under the terms of the merger agreement at all or that the granting of these\nclearances and approvals will not involve the imposition of additional conditions on the completion of the merger, including the\nrequirement to divest assets, or require changes to the terms of the merger agreement. These conditions or changes could result in\nthe conditions to the merger not being satisfied.\n\n        For a more complete description of regulatory approvals relating to the merger, see "The Merger\xe2\x80\x94Regulatory\nApprovals Required for the Merger" beginning on page 116.\n\nLitigation Relating to the Merger\n\n        In connection with the merger, three putative class action lawsuits were filed by three different purported B/E Aerospace\nstockholders. The lawsuits allege, among other things, that the Form S-4 filed by Rockwell Collins on November 23, 2016 misstates\nand/or omits material information. Two of the lawsuits assert claims against B/E Aerospace and the members of the B/E Aerospace\nBoard; the other lawsuit asserts claims against B/E Aerospace, the members of the B/E Aerospace Board, Rockwell Collins and\nMerger Sub. The lawsuits seek to enjoin the merger, to recover damages and other relief. For a more detailed description of\nlitigation in connection with the merger, see "The Merger\xe2\x80\x94Litigation Relating to the Merger" beginning on page 124.\n\nConditions to Completion of the Merger \n\n        The parties expect to complete the merger after all of the conditions to the merger in the merger agreement are satisfied or\nwaived, including after Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace receive stockholder approval of the Share Issuance proposal and the\nMerger proposal, respectively, at their respective special meetings and receive all required regulatory approvals. The parties\ncurrently expect to complete the transaction in the spring of 2017. However, it is possible that factors outside of each company\'s\ncontrol could require them to complete the transaction at a later time or not to complete it at all.\n\nConditions to the Obligations of the Parties to Complete the Merger\n\n        The obligations of each of Rockwell Collins, Merger Sub and B/E Aerospace to complete the merger are subject to the\nsatisfaction or (to the extent permitted by law) waiver of the following conditions:\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nRockwell Collins having obtained the Rockwell Collins Stockholder Approval, and B/E Aerospace having obtained\nthe B/E Aerospace Stockholder Approval;\n\n24\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n33/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nthe shares of Rockwell Collins common stock to be issued in connection with the merger having been approved for\nlisting on the NYSE, subject to official notice of issuance; \n\nthe registration statement on Form S-4 of which this joint proxy statement/prospectus forms a part having become\neffective under the Securities Act of 1933, as amended, which is referred to as the Securities Act, and not being the\nsubject of any stop order or any legal, administrative or other similar proceedings or actions by or before the SEC\nseeking a stop order; \n\nany applicable waiting period (and any extension thereof) under the HSR Act relating to the consummation of the\nmerger having expired or early termination thereof having been granted, and any authorization or consent from a\ngovernmental authority required to be obtained with respect to the merger under any antitrust laws in Europe, China,\nthe Philippines, South Korea or Turkey having been obtained and remaining in full force and effect (for a more\ncomplete description of the governmental filings and consents required for the merger, see "The Merger\xe2\x80\x94\nRegulatory Approvals Required for the Merger" beginning on page 116); and \n\nno governmental authority having issued or entered any order or enacted any law after the date of the merger\nagreement having the effect of enjoining or otherwise prohibiting the consummation of the merger or the other\ntransactions contemplated by the merger agreement.\n\nConditions to the Obligations of Each of Rockwell Collins and Merger Sub to Complete the Merger\n\n        In addition, the obligations of each of Rockwell Collins and Merger Sub to complete the merger are subject to the satisfaction\nor (to the extent permitted by law) waiver of the following conditions:\n\nthe representations and warranties of B/E Aerospace set forth in the merger agreement with respect to\n(i) capitalization being true and correct in all respects (other than de minimis inaccuracies) and (ii) outstanding\nequity awards, corporate authorization of the merger agreement, required stockholder approval of adoption of the\nmerger agreement and the transactions contemplated by the merger agreement, the inapplicability of anti-takeover\nlaws, brokers and transaction-related fees and expenses, opinions from financial advisors and the valid and binding\nnature of B/E Aerospace\'s amendment to the KLX tax sharing agreement being true and correct in all material\nrespects, without giving effect to qualifications in such representations and warranties with respect to materiality or\nmaterial adverse effects on B/E Aerospace, in the case of clauses (i) and (ii), as of the closing date of the merger,\nwhich is referred to as the closing date (or, in the case of representations and warranties made as of a specific date,\nas of such date), with the representations and warranties listed in clauses (i) and (ii) referred to as the B/E Aerospace\nfundamental representations and warranties; \n\nall other representations and warranties of B/E Aerospace set forth in the merger agreement (other than the\nB/E Aerospace fundamental representations and warranties), without giving effect to qualifications in such\nrepresentations and warranties with respect to materiality or material adverse effects on B/E Aerospace, being true\nand correct as of the closing date (or, in the case of representations and warranties made as of a specific date, as of\nsuch date), except where failure to be true and correct, individually or in the aggregate, has had or would reasonably\nbe expected to have a material adverse effect on B/E Aerospace; \n\nB/E Aerospace having performed or complied in all material respects with its obligations under the merger\nagreement required to be performed or complied with on or prior to the closing of the merger; \n\nsince the date of the merger agreement, no event, occurrence, development or change having occurred that had or\nwould reasonably be expected to have, individually or in the aggregate, a material adverse effect on B/E Aerospace;\n\n25\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n34/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nRockwell Collins having received a certificate from an executive officer of B/E Aerospace certifying that the above\nconditions have been satisfied; and \n\nRockwell Collins having received a written opinion from Rockwell Collins\' tax counsel, referred to as the Rockwell\nCollins Tax Advisor Opinion (or, if Rockwell Collins\' tax counsel advises that it will not deliver a written opinion,\nfrom both B/E Aerospace\'s tax counsel and another nationally recognized law firm reasonably acceptable to\nRockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace, referred to as the additional tax counsel), to the effect that the merger will not\ncause the KLX spin-off to fail to qualify for the KLX spin-off tax treatment.\n\nConditions to the Obligation of B/E Aerospace to Complete the Merger\n\n        In addition, the obligation of B/E Aerospace to complete the merger is subject to the satisfaction or (to the extent permitted by\nlaw) waiver of the following conditions:\n\nthe representations and warranties of Rockwell Collins and Merger Sub set forth in the merger agreement with\nrespect to (i) capitalization being true and correct in all respects (other than de minimis inaccuracies) and\n(ii) outstanding equity awards, capitalization of Merger Sub, corporate authorization of the merger agreement,\nrequired stockholder approval of the issuance of Rockwell Collins common stock in connection with the merger,\nbrokers and transaction-related fees and expenses and opinions from financial advisors being true and correct in all\nmaterial respects, without giving effect to qualifications in such representations and warranties with respect to\nmateriality or material adverse effects on Rockwell Collins, in the case of clauses (i) and (ii), as of the closing date\n(or, in the case of representations and warranties made as of a specific date, as of such date), with the representations\nand warranties listed in clauses (i) and (ii) referred to as the Rockwell Collins fundamental representations and\nwarranties; \n\nall other representations and warranties of Rockwell Collins and Merger Sub set forth in the merger agreement (other\nthan the Rockwell Collins fundamental representations and warranties), without giving effect to qualifications in\nsuch representations and warranties with respect to materiality or material adverse effects on Rockwell Collins,\nbeing true and correct as of the closing date (or, in the case of representations and warranties made as of a specific\ndate, as of such date), except where failure to be true and correct, individually or in the aggregate, has had or would\nreasonably be expected to have a material adverse effect on Rockwell Collins; \n\nRockwell Collins and Merger Sub having performed or complied in all material respects with each of their\nrespective obligations required under the merger agreement to be performed or complied with on or prior to the\nclosing of the merger; \n\nsince the date of the merger agreement, no event, occurrence, development or change having occurred that had or\nwould reasonably be expected to have, individually or in the aggregate, a material adverse effect on Rockwell\nCollins; \n\nB/E Aerospace having received a certificate from an executive officer of Rockwell Collins certifying that the above\nconditions have been satisfied; and \n\nB/E Aerospace having received a written opinion from B/E Aerospace\'s tax counsel, referred to as the\nB/E Aerospace Tax Advisor Opinion (or, if B/E Aerospace\'s tax counsel advises that it will not deliver a written\nopinion, the Rockwell Collins Tax Advisor Opinion and a similar opinion from the additional tax counsel), to the\neffect that the merger will not cause the KLX spin-off to fail to qualify for the KLX spin-off tax treatment.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n        To the extent permitted by law, the conditions set forth in the merger agreement may be waived by Rockwell Collins or\nB/E Aerospace subject to the agreement of the other party in certain\n\n26\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n35/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\ncircumstances. For a more complete description of the conditions to the merger, see "The Merger Agreement\xe2\x80\x94Conditions to the\nMerger" beginning on page 148.\n\nTreatment of B/E Aerospace\'s Existing Debt; Financing \n\n        In connection with the merger, the parties intend to terminate B/E Aerospace\'s existing revolving credit facility and term loan\nfacility.\n\n        Rockwell Collins\' obligation to complete the merger is not conditioned upon its obtaining financing. Rockwell Collins\nanticipates that approximately $3.6 billion will be required to pay the aggregate cash portion of the merger consideration to the\nB/E Aerospace stockholders and approximately $2.1 billion to refinance B/E Aerospace\'s existing debt. Rockwell Collins intends to\nfund the cash component of the merger consideration and refinance the acquired debt through new sources of debt financing. Upon\nthe closing of the acquisition, Rockwell Collins expects to have approximately $8 billion in total debt.\n\n        For a more complete description of sources of funding for the merger, see "The Merger\xe2\x80\x94Source of Funding for the Merger"\nbeginning on page 123.\n\nTiming of the Transaction \n\nNo Solicitation \n\n        The transaction is expected to be completed in the spring of 2017. However, it is possible that factors outside of each\ncompany\'s control could require them to complete the merger at a later time or not to complete the merger at all.\n\n        In the merger agreement, each of Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace has agreed:\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nto immediately cease and terminate, and to use reasonable best efforts to cause its officers, directors and other\nrepresentatives to cease and terminate all existing discussions, negotiations and communications with any person or\nentity with respect to acquisition proposals from any person or entity, including proposals to acquire 20% or more of\nsuch party\'s voting power, consolidated assets, revenues or net income, as further described under "The Merger\nAgreement\xe2\x80\x94Covenants and Agreements\xe2\x80\x94No Solicitation" beginning on page 141; \n\nnot to, and not to authorize any of its representatives to, directly or indirectly initiate, seek, solicit, knowingly\nencourage or knowingly induce or take any other action reasonably expected to lead to an acquisition proposal,\nengage in negotiations or discussions with or provide any non-public information to any person or entity relating to\nan acquisition proposal or grant any waiver or release under any standstill or other agreement (unless either party\'s\nboard of directors determines in good faith that refusing to grant such waiver or release would be inconsistent with\nits fiduciary duties under applicable law); \n\nnot to provide access (and within one business day of the date of the merger agreement, to terminate any such\naccess) to any third party to any data room containing any of such party\'s information; and \n\nwithin two business days of the date of the merger agreement, to demand the return or destruction of all confidential,\nnon-public information and materials and all other information and materials related to any acquisition proposal that\nhave been provided to third parties that have entered into confidentiality agreements relating to a possible acquisition\nproposal with the referenced party or any of its subsidiaries.\n\n27\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n36/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\n        The merger agreement includes certain exceptions to the non-solicitation covenant such that, prior to obtaining the\nB/E Aerospace Stockholder Approval or the Rockwell Collins Stockholder Approval, as applicable, the parties may take actions\nprohibited by the above limitations regarding an unsolicited acquisition proposal. Also, the applicable party\'s board of directors\nmay, subject to complying with certain specified procedures, including providing the other party with a chance to negotiate, and, in\ncertain circumstances, payment of a termination fee as described below, (i) change its recommendation in favor of the merger and\nthe transactions contemplated by the merger agreement, or terminate the merger agreement, in order to enter into a definitive\nagreement regarding an unsolicited acquisition proposal that is determined to be a "superior proposal," or (ii) change its\nrecommendation in favor of the merger and the transactions contemplated by the merger agreement in response to an "intervening\nevent" that becomes known after the date of the merger agreement but prior to receipt of the applicable stockholder approval, in\neach case, to the extent failure to do so would be inconsistent with its fiduciary duties under applicable law. For a more complete\ndescription of the limitations on solicitation of acquisition proposals from third parties and the ability of each company\'s board of\ndirectors to change its recommendation for the transaction, see "The Merger Agreement\xe2\x80\x94Covenants and Agreements\xe2\x80\x94No\nSolicitation" beginning on page 141.\n\nTermination of the Merger Agreement; Termination Fees \n\n        The merger agreement may be terminated at any time prior to the effective time, before or after approval is obtained from the\nstockholders of Rockwell Collins or B/E Aerospace, as follows:\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nby the mutual written consent of Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace; \n\nby either Rockwell Collins or B/E Aerospace if: party seeking to terminate the merger agreement for this reason has failed to perform or comply\nwith any of its obligations under the merger agreement and such failure has been the principal cause or\nresulted in the failure of the consummation of the merger by such date, this termination right being referred\nto as the End Date Termination Right; \n\nany governmental authority has issued or entered any final, non-appealable order or enacted any law after the\ndate of the merger agreement that has the effect of permanently restraining, enjoining or otherwise\nprohibiting the merger or the other transactions contemplated by the merger agreement, except where the\nissuance of such order was proximately caused by the failure of the party seeking to terminate the merger\nagreement for this reason to perform or comply with any of its obligations under the merger agreement; \n\nthe Rockwell Collins Stockholder Approval has not been obtained upon a vote taken at the duly convened\nRockwell Collins special meeting or at any adjournment or postponement of such meeting; or \n\nthe B/E Aerospace Stockholder Approval has not been obtained upon a vote taken at the duly convened\nB/E Aerospace resulting from any intentional breach of the merger\nagreement prior to such termination or fraud, in which case the aggrieved party will be entitled to all remedies\navailable at law or in equity, including liability for damages (taking into account all relevant factors, including the\nloss of the benefit of the merger, any lost stockholder premium, any lost synergies, the time value of money and any\nbenefit to the breaching party or its stockholders arising from such intentional breach or fraud); of Contents\n\n        In no event will Rockwell Collins or B/E Aerospace be required to pay a termination fee if such party has already paid a\ntermination fee, and no termination fee will be payable more than once.\n\n        In addition to the termination fees described above, the merger agreement provides for expense reimbursements in connection\nwith the termination of the merger agreement under the following circumstances:\n\nB/E Aerospace will reimburse Rockwell Collins for reasonable and documented out-of-pocket costs and expenses\nincurred by Rockwell Collins, including all fees and expenses incurred by Rockwell Collins in connection with the\nfinancing of the merger and the fees and expenses of advisors incurred by Rockwell Collins in connection with the\nmerger agreement and the transactions contemplated by the merger agreement, in an amount not to exceed\n$85 million: \n\nif the merger agreement is terminated (i) by either Rockwell Collins or B/E Aerospace due to failure of\nB/E Aerospace to obtain the B/E Aerospace Stockholder Approval, (ii) by B/E Aerospace pursuant to the\nB/E Aerospace Tax Opinion Termination Right, (iii) by Rockwell Collins pursuant to the Rockwell Collins\nBreach Termination Right or (iv) by Rockwell Collins pursuant to the Rockwell Collins Tax Opinion\nTermination Right and, in the case of this clause (iv), either (1) a breach or inaccuracy in the B/E Aerospace\nSigning Representation Letter causes the Rockwell Collins Tax Advisor Opinion not to be delivered (and\neither the B/E Aerospace Tax Advisor Opinion or the opinion of the additional tax counsel is not delivered\nfor any reason) or (2) B/E Aerospace fails to comply with its obligations under the covenant in the merger\nagreement related to certain tax matters. \n\nRockwell Collins will reimburse B/E Aerospace for reasonable and documented out-of-pocket costs and expenses\nincurred by B/E Aerospace, including all fees and expenses of advisors incurred by B/E Aerospace in connection\nwith the merger agreement and the transactions contemplated by the merger agreement, in an amount not to exceed\n$56 million: \n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nif the merger agreement is terminated by either Rockwell Collins or B/E Aerospace due to failure of\nRockwell Collins to obtain the Rockwell Collins Stockholder Approval.\n\n        Payment of the expense reimbursements by either party does not affect the other party\'s right to receive any applicable\ntermination fees, but does reduce on a dollar-for-dollar basis any termination fee that becomes due and payable to such other party\nunder the terms of the merger agreement.\n\n        The right of either party to receive the applicable termination fee and expense reimbursement, in circumstances in which the\napplicable termination fee or expense reimbursement is owed, is the sole and exclusive monetary remedy of the receiving party\nagainst the other party and its subsidiaries and representatives for all losses and damages suffered as a result of the failure of the\nconsummation of the transactions contemplated by the merger agreement to be consummated or failure to perform under the merger\nagreement or otherwise, except (i) in the event of (a) termination due to failure of a party to include its required recommendation\nunder the merger agreement in this joint proxy statement/prospectus or due to breach of such party\'s non-solicitation obligations,\n(b) intentional breach of the covenant in the merger agreement related to certain tax matters or fraudulent breach of either party\'s\nrepresentations and warranties under the merger agreement related to their respective tax representation letters or (c) the right of\neach party to receive the applicable termination fee less the applicable expense reimbursement under certain circumstances and\n(ii) that any party that fails to timely pay any termination fee or expense reimbursement due pursuant to the merger agreement will\nbe obligated to pay any costs and expenses in connection with any suit brought by the other party that results in a judgment against\nthe delinquent party for the payment of such termination fee and expense reimbursement.\n\n        For a more complete description of each party\'s termination rights and the related termination fee obligations, see "The Merger\nAgreement\xe2\x80\x94Termination" beginning on page 150 and "The Merger\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n41/330\n\n32\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n42/330\n\n\x0c\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nAgreement\xe2\x80\x94Effect of Termination\xe2\x80\x94Termination Fees and Expense Reimbursements" beginning on page 152.\n\n        At the Rockwell Collins special meeting, Rockwell Collins stockholders will be asked to consider and vote upon:\n\nMatters to be Considered at the Special Meetings \n\nRockwell Collins\n\nthe Share Issuance proposal; and \n\nthe Rockwell Collins Adjournment proposal.\n\n        Stockholder approval of the Share Issuance proposal is required to complete the merger.\n\n        The affirmative vote of holders of a majority of the votes cast by the shares of Rockwell Collins common stock represented (in\nperson or by proxy) at the Rockwell Collins special meeting is required to approve the Share Issuance proposal.\n\n        The affirmative vote of holders of a majority of the shares of Rockwell Collins common stock represented (in person or by\nproxy) at the Rockwell Collins special meeting and entitled to vote on the proposal, whether or not a quorum is present, is required\nto approve the Rockwell Collins Adjournment proposal.\n\n        The Rockwell Collins Board unanimously recommends that Rockwell Collins stockholders vote "FOR" both of the\nproposals set forth above, as more fully described under "Rockwell Collins Proposals" beginning on page 165.\n\nB/E Aerospace\n\n        At the B/E Aerospace special meeting, B/E Aerospace stockholders will be asked to consider and vote upon:\n\nthe Merger proposal; \n\nthe Merger-Related Compensation proposal; and \n\nthe B/E Aerospace Adjournment proposal.\n\n        Stockholder approval of the Merger proposal is required for completion of the merger.\n\n        The affirmative vote of holders of a majority of the shares of B/E Aerospace common stock issued and outstanding on the\nrecord date for the B/E Aerospace special meeting is required to approve the Merger proposal.\n\n        The affirmative vote of holders of a majority of the votes cast by shares of B/E Aerospace common stock represented (in\nperson or by proxy) at the B/E Aerospace special meeting and entitled to vote on such proposal is required to approve the Merger-\nRelated Compensation proposal.\n\n        The affirmative vote of holders of a majority of the votes cast by holders of shares of B/E Aerospace common stock\nrepresented (in person or by proxy) at the B/E Aerospace special meeting, whether or not there is a quorum, is required to approve\nthe B/E Aerospace Adjournment proposal.\n\n        The B/E Aerospace Board unanimously recommends that B/E Aerospace stockholders vote "FOR" all of the proposals\nset forth above, as more fully described under "B/E Aerospace Proposals" beginning on page 172.\n\n33\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n43/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nVoting by Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace Directors and Executive Officers \n\n        As of the record date, directors and executive officers of Rockwell Collins and their affiliates owned and were entitled to vote\n363,896 shares of Rockwell Collins common stock, representing approximately less than 1% of the total voting power of the shares\nof Rockwell Collins common stock outstanding on that date. It is currently expected that Rockwell Collins\' directors and executive\nofficers will vote their shares of Rockwell Collins common stock in favor of each of the proposals to be considered at the Rockwell\nCollins special meeting, although none of them have entered into any agreements obligating them to do so.\n\n        As of the record date, directors and executive officers of B/E Aerospace and their affiliates owned and were entitled to vote\n269,296 shares of B/E Aerospace common stock, representing less than 1% of the total voting power of the shares of B/E Aerospace\ncommon stock outstanding on that date. It is currently expected that B/E Aerospace\'s directors and executive officers will vote their\nshares of B/E Aerospace common stock in favor of each of the proposals to be considered at the B/E Aerospace special meeting,\nalthough none of them have entered into any agreements obligating them to do so. The number of shares reflected above does not\ninclude shares subject to outstanding unvested restricted stock awards or shares underlying unvested restricted stock units. For\ninformation with respect to restricted stock awards and restricted stock units, please see "\xe2\x80\x94Treatment of Restricted Stock Awards"\nand "\xe2\x80\x94Treatment of Restricted Stock Units" beginning on page 103 and page 104, respectively.\n\nRisk Factors \n\n        You should also carefully consider the risks that are described in the section entitled "Risk Factors" beginning on page 46.\n\n34\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n44/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nSELECTED HISTORICAL FINANCIAL DATA \n\nSELECTED HISTORICAL CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL DATA OF ROCKWELL COLLINS \n\n        The following table presents selected historical consolidated financial data for Rockwell Collins as of and for the fiscal years\nended on the Friday closest to September 30. This\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n45/330\n\n35\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nacquisition was funded through a combination of new long-term debt and short-term commercial paper\nborrowings.\n\n(d)\n\n(e)\n\n(f)\n\nNet income includes a $19 million income tax benefit related to the retroactive reinstatement of the previously\nexpired Federal Research and Development Tax Credit. Short-term debt includes commercial paper borrowings\nincurred to fund a portion of Rockwell Collins\' share repurchase program and also includes $200 million\nrelated to debt that matured in December 2013. \n\nNet income includes $38 million of net restructuring and asset impairment charges ($58 million before income\ntaxes), primarily related to employee severance costs and certain customer bankruptcy charges. Net income\nalso includes a $19 million income tax benefit related to the favorable resolution of certain tax matters in 2012.\n\nIn computing the ratio of earnings to fixed charges, earnings are defined as income from continuing operations\nbefore income taxes, adjusted for income or loss attributable to minority interests in subsidiaries, undistributed\nearnings of less than majority owned subsidiaries and fixed charges excluding capitalized interest. Fixed\ncharges are defined as interest on borrowings (whether expensed or capitalized) and that portion of rental\nexpense applicable to interest.\n\n36\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n46/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nSELECTED HISTORICAL CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL DATA OF B/E AEROSPACE \n\n        The following table presents selected historical consolidated financial data for B/E Aerospace as of and for the fiscal years\nending December 31, 2015, 2014, 2013, 2012 and 2011 and as of and for the nine months ended September 30, 2016 and 2015. The actual exchange ratio will be adjusted to reflect changes in the price of Rockwell Collins\ncommon stock prior to the closing of the merger as described in the section entitled "The Merger Agreement\xe2\x80\x94Merger\nConsideration to be Received by B/E Aerospace Stockholders" beginning on page 128 this joint proxy statement/prospectus. These\ncomputations exclude the $34.10 per share cash portion of the merger consideration.\n\n        The unaudited pro forma per share information reflects the merger and related transactions as if they had occurred on\nOctober 1, 2015 in the case of income from continuing operations per share, and as if they had occurred on September 30, 2016 in\nthe case of book value per share. The information in the table is based on, and should be read together with, the historical financial\ninformation of Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace which is incorporated by reference in this joint proxy statement/prospectus and\nthe financial information contained under "Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Combined Financial Statements," "Selected Historical\nFinancial Data\xe2\x80\x94Selected Historical Consolidated Financial Data of Rockwell Collins" and "Selected Historical Financial Data\xe2\x80\x94\nSelected Historical Consolidated Financial Data of B/E Aerospace" beginning on page 173, page 35, and page 37, respectively. See\nthe section entitled "Where You Can Find More Information" beginning on page 198 of this joint proxy statement/prospectus.\n\n        The unaudited pro forma combined per share data is presented for illustrative purposes only and is not necessarily indicative of\nactual or future financial position or results of operations that would have been realized if the proposed merger had been completed\nas of the dates indicated or will be realized upon the completion of the proposed merger. The summary pro forma information is\npreliminary, based on initial estimates of the fair value of assets acquired (including intangible assets) and liabilities assumed, and is\nsubject to change as more information regarding the fair values are obtained, which changes could be materially different than the\ninitial estimates.\n\n        Both Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace declared and paid dividends during the periods presented. The table also shows the estimated implied value of the per share consideration proposed for\neach share of B/E Aerospace common stock as of the same two days. This implied value was calculated by multiplying the closing\nprices of shares of Rockwell Collins common stock on those dates by the exchange ratio of 0.3101 (based on the closing price of\nRockwell Collins\' common stock as of the close of business on January 26, 2017, the most recent practicable date for which such\ninformation was available) and adding the cash portion of the merger consideration of $34.10 per share, without interest. The\nmarket prices of Rockwell Collins common stock and B/E Aerospace common stock will fluctuate before the special meetings and\nbefore the merger is completed. The exchange ratio may be adjusted to reflect changes in the Rockwell Collins stock price prior to\nthe closing of the merger, and the number of shares of Rockwell Collins common stock to be issued as part of the stock\nconsideration (and, in turn, the value of the merger consideration to be received in exchange for each share of B/E Aerospace\ncommon stock) may fluctuate with the market value of Rockwell Collins common stock until the last trading day before the merger\nis complete.\n\n \nOctober 21, 2016\nJanuary 26, 2017\n\nRockwell Collins\nCommon Stock\n\nB/E Aerospace\nCommon Stock\n\n \n\n \n\nImplied Per Share Value\nof Merger Consideration\n\n \n\n84.46  $\n91.26  $\n\n50.61  $\n61.72  $\n\n62.00 \n62.40 \n\n \n  $\n  $\n\n        The market prices of Rockwell Collins common stock and B/E Aerospace common stock have fluctuated since the date of the\nannouncement of the merger agreement and will continue to fluctuate from the date of this joint proxy statement/prospectus to the\ndate of the Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace special meetings and the date the merger is completed and thereafter. No assurance\ncan be given concerning the market prices of Rockwell Collins common stock or B/E Aerospace common stock before completion\nof the merger or Rockwell Collins common stock after completion of the merger. The exchange ratio may be adjusted to reflect\nchanges in the price of the Rockwell Collins common stock prior to the closing of the merger, and the number of shares of Rockwell\nCollins common stock to be issued as part of the stock consideration (and, in turn, the value of the merger consideration to be\nreceived in exchange for each share of B/E Aerospace common stock) when received by B/E Aerospace stockholders after the\nmerger is completed could be greater than, less than or the same as shown in the table above. Accordingly, stockholders are advised\nto obtain current market quotations for Rockwell Collins common stock and B/E Aerospace common stock in deciding whether to\nvote for adoption of the merger agreement or the issuance of shares of Rockwell Collins common stock, as applicable.\n\n43\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n53/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nCAUTIONARY NOTE REGARDING FORWARD-LOOKING STATEMENTS \n\n        This communication contains "forward-looking" statements as that term is defined in Section 27A of the Securities Act of 1933, as\namended, and Section 21E of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended by the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995,\nincluding statements regarding the proposed acquisition of B/E Aerospace by Rockwell Collins. All statements, other than historical facts,\nincluding statements regarding the expected timing of the closing of the proposed transaction; the ability of the parties to complete the\nproposed transaction considering the various closing conditions; the expected benefits of the proposed transaction such as improved\noperations, enhanced revenues and cash flow, growth potential, market profile and financial strength; the competitive ability and position\nof the combined company following completion of the proposed transaction; and any assumptions underlying any of the foregoing, are\nforward-looking statements. Forward-looking statements concern future circumstances and results and other statements that are not\nhistorical facts and are sometimes identified by the words "may," "will," "should," "potential," "intend," "expect," "endeavor," "seek,"\n"anticipate," "estimate," "overestimate," "underestimate," "believe," "could," "project," "predict," "continue," "target" or other similar\nwords or expressions. Forward-looking statements are based upon current plans, estimates and expectations that are subject to risks,\nuncertainties and assumptions. Should one or more of these risks or uncertainties materialize, or should underlying assumptions prove\nincorrect, actual results may vary materially from those indicated or anticipated by such forward-looking statements. The inclusion of such\nstatements should not be regarded as a representation that such plans, estimates or expectations will be achieved. Important factors that\ncould cause actual results to differ materially from such plans, estimates or expectations include, among other things:\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nthat one or more closing conditions to the transaction, including certain regulatory approvals, may not be satisfied or\nwaived, on a timely basis or otherwise, including that a governmental entity may prohibit, delay or refuse to grant approval\nfor the consummation of the proposed transaction, may require conditions, limitations or restrictions in connection with\nsuch approvals or that the required approval by the stockholders of each of Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace may not\nbe obtained; \n\nuncertainty of the expected financial performance of the combined company following completion of the proposed\ntransaction; \n\nfailure to realize the anticipated benefits of the proposed transaction, including as a result of delay in completing the\nproposed transaction or integrating the businesses of Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace; \n\nrisks associated with the financing of the proposed transaction; \n\nevolving legal, regulatory and tax regimes;\n\n44\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n54/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nchanges in general economic and/or industry specific conditions; In addition, you should read and\nconsider the risks associated with each of the businesses of B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins because these risks will relate to the\ncombined company following the completion of the merger. Descriptions of some of these risks can be found in the Rockwell Collins\nannual report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended September 30, 2016 and the B/E Aerospace annual report on Form 10-K for the\nfiscal year ended December 31, 2015, as such risks may be updated or supplemented in each company\'s subsequently filed Quarterly\nReports on Form 10-Q or Current Reports on Form 8-K, which are incorporated by reference into this joint proxy statement/prospectus.\nYou should also consider the other information in this document and the other documents incorporated by reference into this document.\nSee the section entitled "Where You Can Find More Information" beginning on page 198.\n\nRisks Related to the Merger \n\nThe merger is subject to conditions, some or all of which may not be satisfied, or completed on a timely basis, if at all. Failure to\ncomplete the merger could have material adverse effects on Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace.\n\n        The completion of the merger is subject to a number of conditions, including, among other things, receipt of the Rockwell Collins\nStockholder Approval, receipt of the B/E Aerospace Stockholder Approval and receipt of certain other regulatory approvals, which make\nthe completion and timing of the completion of the merger uncertain. See the section entitled "The Merger Agreement\xe2\x80\x94Conditions to the\nMerger," beginning on page 148, for a more detailed discussion. Also, either Rockwell Collins or B/E Aerospace may terminate the\nmerger agreement if the merger has not been consummated by 5:00 p.m. (New York time) on October 21, 2017, except that this right to\nterminate the merger agreement will not be available to any party whose failure to perform or comply with any of its obligations under the\nmerger agreement has been the principal cause of or resulted in the failure of the closing of the merger to have occurred on or before that\ndate.\n\n        If the merger is not completed, Rockwell Collins\' and B/E Aerospace\'s respective ongoing businesses may be materially adversely\naffected and, without realizing any of the benefits of having completed the merger, Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace will be subject to\na number of risks, including the following:\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nthe market price of Rockwell Collins common stock or B/E Aerospace common stock could decline; \n\nRockwell Collins or B/E Aerospace could owe substantial termination fees to the other party under certain circumstances; \n\nif the merger agreement is terminated and the Rockwell Collins Board or the B/E Aerospace Board seeks another business\ncombination, Rockwell Collins stockholders and B/E Aerospace stockholders cannot be certain that Rockwell Collins or\nB/E Aerospace will be able to find a party willing to enter into a transaction on terms equivalent to or more attractive than\nthe terms that the other party has agreed to in the merger agreement; \n\ntime and resources, financial and other, committed by Rockwell Collins\' and B/E Aerospace\'s respective management to\nmatters relating to the merger could otherwise have been devoted to pursuing other beneficial opportunities for their\nrespective companies;\n\n46\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n56/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nRockwell Collins or B/E Aerospace may experience negative reactions from the financial markets or from their respective\ncustomers or employees; and \n\nRockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace may be required to pay their respective costs relating to the merger, such as legal,\naccounting, financial advisory and printing fees, whether or not the merger is completed.\n\n        In addition, if the merger is not completed, Rockwell Collins or B/E Aerospace could be subject to litigation related to any failure to\ncomplete the merger or related to any enforcement proceeding commenced against Rockwell Collins or B/E Aerospace to perform their\nrespective obligations under the merger agreement. The materialization of any of these risks could materially and adversely impact\nRockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace\'s respective ongoing businesses.\n\n        Similarly, delays in the completion of the merger could, among other things, result in additional transaction costs, loss of revenue or\nother negative effects associated with uncertainty about completion of the merger.\n\nThe merger agreement contains provisions that limit each party\'s ability to pursue alternatives to the merger, could discourage a\npotential competing acquiror of either Rockwell Collins or B/E Aerospace from making a favorable alternative transaction proposal\nand, in specified circumstances, could require either party to pay substantial termination fees to the other party.\n\n        The merger agreement contains certain provisions that restrict each of Rockwell Collins\' and B/E Aerospace\'s ability to, among other\nthings, initiate, seek, solicit, knowingly encourage, knowingly induce or take any other action reasonably expected to lead to, or engage in\nnegotiations or discussions relating to, or approve or recommend, any third-party acquisition proposal. Further, even if the Rockwell\nCollins Board withdraws or qualifies its recommendation with respect to the issuance of Rockwell Collins common stock forming part of\nthe merger consideration or if the B/E Aerospace Board withdraws or qualifies its recommendation with respect to the adoption of the\nmerger agreement, in each case as permitted by the merger agreement, unless the merger agreement has also been terminated in\naccordance with its terms, Rockwell Collins or B/E Aerospace, as the case may be, will still be required to submit each of the Share\nIssuance proposal and the Merger proposal, as applicable, to a vote at their special meeting of stockholders. In addition, following receipt\nby Rockwell Collins or B/E Aerospace, as the case may be, of any third-party acquisition proposal that constitutes a "superior proposal,"\nthe other party will have an opportunity to offer to modify the terms of the transactions contemplated by the merger agreement before the\nboard of directors of the receiving party may withdraw or qualify its recommendation with respect to the Share Issuance proposal or the\nMerger proposal, as applicable, in favor of such superior proposal, as described further under "The Merger Agreement\xe2\x80\x94Covenants and\nAgreements\xe2\x80\x94No Solicitation" beginning on page 141.\n\n        In some circumstances, upon termination of the merger agreement, Rockwell Collins could be required to pay a termination fee of\n$300 million to B/E Aerospace and B/E Aerospace could be required to pay a termination fee of $200 million to Rockwell Collins. For\nfurther discussion, see the section entitled "The Merger Agreement\xe2\x80\x94Termination;\xe2\x80\x94Effect of Termination;\xe2\x80\x94Termination Fees and\nExpense Reimbursements" beginning on page 152.\n\n        These provisions could discourage a potential third-party acquiror or merger partner that might have an interest in acquiring all or a\nsignificant portion of Rockwell Collins or B/E Aerospace or pursuing an alternative transaction from considering or proposing such a\ntransaction, even if it were prepared to pay consideration with a higher per share cash or market value than the per share cash or market\nvalue proposed to be received or realized in the merger. In particular, a termination fee, if applicable, may be substantial, and could result\nin a potential third-party acquiror or merger partner proposing to pay a lower price to the Rockwell Collins stockholders or B/E Aerospace\nstockholders than it might otherwise have proposed to pay absent such a fee.\n\n47\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n57/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\n        If the merger agreement is terminated and either Rockwell Collins or B/E Aerospace determines to seek another business\ncombination, Rockwell Collins or B/E Aerospace, as applicable, may not be able to negotiate a transaction with another party on terms\ncomparable to, or better than, the terms of the merger.\n\nThe merger is subject to the expiration or termination of applicable waiting periods and the receipt of approvals, consents or\nclearances from regulatory authorities that may impose conditions that could have an adverse effect on B/E Aerospace, Rockwell\nCollins or the combined company or, if not obtained, could prevent completion of the merger.\n\n        Before the merger may be completed, any applicable waiting period (and any extension thereof) under the HSR Act relating to the\nconsummation of the merger must have expired or been terminated, and any authorization or consent from a governmental authority\nrequired to be obtained with respect to the merger in certain other applicable foreign antitrust laws must have been obtained. In deciding\nwhether to grant the required regulatory authorization or consent, the relevant governmental entities will consider the effect of the merger\non competition within their relevant jurisdiction. The terms and conditions of the authorizations and consents that are granted may impose\nrequirements, limitations or costs or place restrictions on the conduct of the combined company\'s business. Under the merger agreement,\nRockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace have agreed to use their reasonable best efforts to obtain such authorizations and consents and\ntherefore may be required to comply with conditions or limitations imposed by governmental authorities, except that Rockwell Collins will\nnot be required to agree to sell, divest, lease, license, transfer, dispose of or otherwise encumber or impair its ability to own or operate any\nof its or B/E Aerospace\'s assets or properties if such action would require the divestiture or holding separate of any assets of Rockwell\nCollins or B/E Aerospace or any of their subsidiaries representing more than $175 million of annual revenue generated in the 2015\ncalendar year.\n\n        In addition, regulators may impose conditions, terms, obligations or restrictions in connection with their authorization of or consent to\nthe merger, and such conditions, terms, obligations or restrictions may delay completion of the merger or impose additional material costs\non or materially limit the revenues of the combined company following the completion of the merger or may hinder the anticipated\nbenefits of the merger. There can be no assurance that regulators will choose not to impose such conditions, terms, obligations or\nrestrictions, and, if imposed, such conditions, terms, obligations or restrictions may delay or lead to the abandonment of the merger. For a\nmore detailed description of the regulatory review process, see the section entitled "The Merger\xe2\x80\x94Regulatory Approvals Required for the\nMerger" beginning on page 116.\n\nThe value of the stock portion of the merger consideration is subject to changes based on fluctuations in the value of Rockwell Collins\ncommon stock, and B/E Aerospace stockholders may receive stock consideration with a value that, at the time received, is less than\n$27.90 per share of B/E Aerospace common stock.\n\n        The market value of Rockwell Collins common stock will fluctuate during the period before the date of the Rockwell Collins and B/E\nAerospace special meetings, during the 20 trading day period that the exchange ratio will be based upon, and the time between the last day\nof the 20 trading day period and the time B/E Aerospace stockholders receive merger consideration in the form of Rockwell Collins\ncommon stock, as well as thereafter.\n\n        Upon completion of the merger, each issued and outstanding share of B/E Aerospace common stock will be converted into the right\nto receive the merger consideration, which is equal to $34.10 in cash, without interest, and a fraction of a share of Rockwell Collins\ncommon stock having a value equal to $27.90, subject to adjustment based upon a two-way collar mechanism as described below. If the\nRockwell Collins stock price is greater than or equal to $77.41 and less than or equal to $89.97, the exchange ratio will be equal to the\nquotient of (i) $27.90 divided by (ii) the Rockwell Collins stock\n\n48\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n58/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nprice, which, in each case, will result in the stock consideration having a value equal to $27.90. If Rockwell Collins stock price is greater\nthan $89.97, the exchange ratio will be fixed at 0.3101 and the value of the stock consideration will be more than $27.90, and if the\nRockwell Collins stock price is less than $77.41, the exchange ratio will be fixed at 0.3604 and the value of the stock consideration will be\nless than $27.90. Accordingly, the actual number of shares and the value of Rockwell Collins common stock delivered to B/E Aerospace\nstockholders will depend on the Rockwell Collins stock price, and the value of the shares of Rockwell Collins common stock delivered for\neach such share of B/E Aerospace common stock may be greater than, less than or equal to $27.90.\n\n        It is impossible to accurately predict the market price of Rockwell Collins common stock at the effective time or during the period\nover which the Rockwell Collins stock price is calculated and therefore impossible to accurately predict the number or value of the shares\nof Rockwell Collins common stock that B/E Aerospace stockholders will receive in the merger. You should obtain current market\nquotations for shares of Rockwell Collins common stock.\n\nEach party is subject to business uncertainties and contractual restrictions while the proposed merger is pending, which could\nadversely affect each party\'s business and operations.\n\n        In connection with the pendency of the merger, it is possible that some customers, suppliers and other persons with whom Rockwell\nCollins or B/E Aerospace has a business relationship may delay or defer certain business decisions or might decide to seek to terminate,\nchange or renegotiate their relationships with Rockwell Collins or B/E Aerospace, as the case may be, as a result of the merger, which\ncould negatively affect Rockwell Collins\' or B/E Aerospace\'s respective revenues, earnings and cash flows, as well as the market price of\nRockwell Collins common stock or B/E Aerospace common stock, regardless of whether the merger is completed.\n\n        Under the terms of the merger agreement, B/E Aerospace is subject to certain restrictions on the conduct of its business prior to\ncompleting the merger which may adversely affect its ability to execute certain of its business strategies, including the ability in certain\ncases to enter into or amend contracts, acquire or dispose of assets, incur indebtedness or incur capital expenditures. Such limitations could\nadversely affect B/E Aerospace\'s business and operations prior to the completion of the merger.\n\n        Under the terms of the merger agreement, Rockwell Collins is subject to a more limited set of restrictions on the conduct of its\nbusiness prior to completing the merger which may adversely affect its ability to execute certain of its business strategies, including the\nability in certain cases to amend its organizational documents, pay dividends and issue shares of Rockwell Collins common stock. Such\nlimitations could adversely affect Rockwell Collins\' business and operations prior to the completion of the merger.\n\n        Each of the risks described above may be exacerbated by delays or other adverse developments with respect to the completion of the\nmerger.\n\nUncertainties associated with the merger may cause a loss of management personnel and other key employees which could adversely\naffect the future business and operations of the combined company.\n\n        Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace are dependent on the experience and industry knowledge of their officers and other key\nemployees to execute their business plans. The combined company\'s success after the completion of the merger will depend in part upon\nthe ability of Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace to retain certain key management personnel and employees. Prior to completion of the\nmerger, current and prospective employees of Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace may experience uncertainty about their roles within\nthe combined company following the completion of the merger, which may have an adverse effect on the ability of each of Rockwell\nCollins and B/E Aerospace to attract or retain key management and other key personnel. In addition, no assurance can be given that the\ncombined company will be able to attract or retain key management personnel and other key\n\n49\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n59/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nemployees of Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace to the same extent that Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace have previously been able\nto attract or retain their own employees.\n\nLitigation filed against Rockwell Collins, B/E Aerospace, Merger Sub and the members of the B/E Aerospace Board could prevent or\ndelay the consummation of the merger or result in the payment of damages following completion of the merger.\n\n        In connection with the merger, three putative class action lawsuits were filed by three different purported B/E Aerospace\nstockholders. Two of the lawsuits assert claims against B/E Aerospace and the members of the B/E Aerospace Board; the other lawsuit\nasserts claims against B/E Aerospace, the members of the B/E Aerospace Board, Rockwell Collins and Merger Sub. The lawsuits seek to\nenjoin the merger, recover damages and other relief. For a more detailed description of litigation in connection with the merger, see "The\nMerger\xe2\x80\x94Litigation Relating to the Merger."\n\n        The outcome of these lawsuits is uncertain. One of the conditions to the closing of the merger is that no governmental authority has\nissued or entered any order after the date of the merger agreement having the effect of enjoining or otherwise prohibiting the\nconsummation of the merger or the other transactions contemplated by the merger agreement, and these lawsuits seek an order enjoining\nconsummation of the merger. If the cases are not resolved, these lawsuits could prevent or delay completion of the merger and result in\nsubstantial costs to Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace, including, but not limited to, costs associated with the indemnification of\ndirectors and officers. The defense or settlement of any lawsuit or claim that remains unresolved at the time the merger is completed may\nadversely affect Rockwell Collins\' and B/E Aerospace\'s business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.\n\nThe unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial information in this joint proxy statement/prospectus is presented for\nillustrative purposes only and may not be reflective of the operating results and financial condition of the combined company following\ncompletion of the merger.\n\n        The unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial information in this joint proxy statement/prospectus is presented for\nillustrative purposes only and is not necessarily indicative of what the combined company\'s actual financial position or results of\noperations would have been had the merger been completed on the dates indicated. The unaudited pro forma condensed combined\nfinancial information is subject to a number of assumptions, and does not take into account any synergies related to the proposed\ntransaction. Further, the combined company\'s actual results and financial position after the merger may differ materially and adversely\nfrom the unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial data that is included in this joint proxy statement/prospectus. The unaudited\npro forma condensed combined financial information has been prepared with the expectation, as of the date of this joint proxy\nstatement/prospectus, that Rockwell Collins will be identified as the acquirer under GAAP and reflects adjustments based upon\npreliminary estimates of the fair value of assets to be acquired and liabilities to be assumed. The final acquisition accounting will be based\nupon the actual purchase price and the fair value of the assets and liabilities of the party that is determined to be the acquiree under GAAP\nas of the date of the completion of the merger. In addition, subsequent to the closing date, there will be further refinements of the\nacquisition accounting as additional information becomes available. Accordingly, the final acquisition accounting may differ materially\nfrom the pro forma condensed combined financial information reflected in this document.
