For further discussion, see "Unaudited Pro\nForma Condensed Combined Financial Statements" beginning on page 173.\n\n50\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n60/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nCompletion of the merger will trigger change in control or other provisions in certain agreements to which B/E Aerospace is a party,\nwhich may have an adverse impact on the combined company\'s business and results of operations.\n\n        The completion of the merger will trigger change in control and other provisions in certain agreements to which B/E Aerospace is a\nparty. If Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace are unable to negotiate waivers of those provisions, the counterparties may exercise their\nrights and remedies under the agreements, potentially terminating the agreements or seeking monetary damages. Even if Rockwell Collins\nand B/E Aerospace are able to negotiate waivers, the counterparties may require a fee for such waivers or seek to renegotiate the\nagreements on terms less favorable to B/E Aerospace or the combined company. Any of the foregoing or similar developments may have\nan adverse impact on the combined company\'s business and results of operations.\n\nThe Rockwell Collins common stock to be received by B/E Aerospace stockholders upon completion of the merger will have different\nrights from shares of B/E Aerospace common stock.\n\n        Upon completion of the merger, B/E Aerospace stockholders will no longer be stockholders of B/E Aerospace but will instead\nbecome stockholders of Rockwell Collins and their rights as Rockwell Collins stockholders will be governed by the terms of Rockwell\nCollins\' certificate of incorporation and by-laws. The terms of Rockwell Collins\' certificate of incorporation and by-laws are in some\nrespects materially different than the terms of B/E Aerospace\'s certificate of incorporation and by-laws, which currently govern the rights\nof B/E Aerospace stockholders.\n\n        For a more complete description of the different rights associated with shares of B/E Aerospace common stock and shares of\nRockwell Collins common stock, see "Comparison of Rights of Stockholders of Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace" beginning on\npage 187.\n\nThe merger could result in significant liability to Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace if the merger causes the KLX spin-off to fail to\nqualify for the KLX spin-off tax treatment.\n\n        At the time of the KLX spin-off, B/E Aerospace received an opinion of Shearman & Sterling to the effect that, subject to the\nlimitations and assumptions set forth therein, the KLX spin-off that occurred in December 2014 will qualify for the KLX spin-off tax\ntreatment, which generally means a transaction tax-free to B/E Aerospace and its stockholders under the U.S. federal income tax rules for\nspin-offs in Section 355 of the Code and related provisions. If, however, the KLX spin-off were to fail to qualify for the KLX spin-off tax\ntreatment, B/E Aerospace would be subject to tax on substantial gain as if B/E Aerospace had sold the KLX common stock in a taxable\nsale for its fair market value at the time of the KLX spin-off. In addition, if the KLX spin-off failed to qualify for tax-free treatment, each\nB/E Aerospace stockholder at the time of the KLX spin-off would be treated as if it had received a distribution from B/E Aerospace in an\namount equal to the fair market value of the KLX common stock that they received; this distribution generally would be taxed as a\ndividend to the extent of the stockholder\'s pro rata share of B/E Aerospace\'s current and accumulated earnings and profits at the time of the\nKLX spin-off and then treated as a non-taxable return of capital to the extent of the stockholder\'s basis in the B/E Aerospace common\nstock and finally as capital gain from the sale or exchange of B/E Aerospace common stock.\n\n        Under current U.S. federal income tax law, the KLX spin-off would fail to qualify for the KLX spin-off tax treatment if the KLX\nspin-off was determined to have been used by B/E Aerospace principally as a device for the distribution of earnings and profits by, for\nexample, facilitating a taxable sale of the stock of B/E Aerospace or KLX through a planned or intended change-in-control transaction\nidentified prior to the KLX spin-off rather than principally to achieve one or more valid corporate business purposes. Furthermore, even if\nthe KLX spin-off were otherwise to qualify for tax-free treatment under Section 355 and related provisions of the Code, it would be\ntaxable to B/E\n\n51\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n61/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nAerospace (but not to B/E Aerospace\'s stockholders) under Section 355(e) of the Code, if the KLX spin-off was determined to be part of a\nplan (or series of related transactions) pursuant to which one or more persons acquire, directly or indirectly, stock representing a 50% or\ngreater interest in B/E Aerospace or KLX.\n\n        If it is determined that the KLX spin-off fails to qualify for the KLX spin-off tax treatment as a result of the merger (for example, if\nthe merger is viewed as part of a plan or series of related transactions that includes the KLX spin-off or the KLX spin-off is found to have\nbeen used principally as a device for the distribution of earnings and profits), or because of the failure of the KLX spin-off to initially\nqualify for the KLX spin-off tax treatment, B/E Aerospace could incur significant tax liabilities. Because B/E Aerospace will be a wholly\nowned subsidiary of Rockwell Collins following the consummation of the merger, any such tax liabilities of B/E Aerospace could also\nadversely affect Rockwell Collins. If the KLX spin-off fails to qualify for the KLX spin-off tax treatment, this may also result in adverse\ntax consequences to stockholders of B/E Aerospace at the time of the KLX spin-off because they would be taxed on the distribution of\nKLX stock as described above.\n\n        In connection with the signing of the merger agreement, Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace each received an opinion from their\nrespective counsel, Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP, which is referred to as Skadden, and Shearman & Sterling to the effect\nthat the merger will not cause the KLX spin-off to fail to qualify for the KLX spin-off tax treatment. The merger is conditioned upon\nreceipt by Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace of tax opinions to the same effect at the time of the consummation of the merger;\nprovided, however, that if either party\'s tax counsel indicates it is unwilling or unable to deliver a tax opinion at the time of the\nconsummation of the merger, the tax opinion condition of either Rockwell Collins or B/E Aerospace may be satisfied by such party\'s\nreceipt of similar tax opinions from both the other party\'s tax counsel and the additional tax counsel.\n\n        The tax opinions received by Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace in connection with the signing of the merger agreement rely on\ncertain representations, assumptions, undertakings and covenants, and the opinions to be delivered at the consummation of the merger will\nbe based on similar representations, assumptions, undertakings and covenants, including representation letters from each of Rockwell\nCollins and B/E Aerospace. These representations relate to, among other items, confirming the accuracy of the representations and\nwarranties originally made with respect to the KLX spin-off, along with compliance with covenants, the actions taken in pursuit of the\ncorporate business purposes of the KLX spin-off, the interaction of the parties, and business developments since the KLX spin-off. If any\nof the factual representations in any of the representation letters, or any of the assumptions in the tax opinions is untrue or incomplete, an\nundertaking or covenant is not complied with or the facts upon which a tax opinion is based are materially different from the facts at the\ntime of the merger, the opinions may not be valid. Moreover, opinions of counsel are not binding on the IRS or the courts. As a result, the\nconclusions expressed in the tax opinions could be challenged by the IRS, and a court may sustain such a challenge. None of Rockwell\nCollins, B/E Aerospace or KLX has requested a ruling from the IRS regarding the impact of the merger on the qualification of the KLX\nspin-off for the KLX spin-off tax treatment.\n\nRisks Relating to the Combined Company after Completion of the Merger \n\nThe combined company may be unable to successfully integrate the businesses of Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace and realize the\nanticipated benefits of the merger.\n\n        The success of the merger will depend, in part, on the combined company\'s ability to successfully combine the businesses of\nRockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace, which currently operate as independent public companies, and realize the anticipated benefits,\nincluding synergies, cost savings, innovation and operational efficiencies, from the combination. If the combined company is unable to\nachieve these objectives within the anticipated time frame, or at all, the anticipated benefits may not be\n\n52\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n62/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nrealized fully or at all, or may take longer to realize than expected and the value of the Rockwell Collins common stock may be harmed.\nAdditionally, credit rating agencies may take negative credit rating actions against the combined company if the credit metrics and other\nrating criteria used by the credit rating agencies to rate debt no longer support Rockwell Collins\' current credit ratings, which would be\nnegatively impacted due to the additional debt Rockwell Collins expects to incur to finance the transaction.\n\n        The merger will involve the integration of B/E Aerospace\'s business with Rockwell Collins\' existing business, which is a complex,\ncostly and time-consuming process. Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace have not previously completed a transaction comparable in size\nor scope to the proposed merger. The integration of the two companies may result in material challenges, including, without limitation:\n\nthe diversion of management\'s attention from ongoing business concerns and performance shortfalls at one or both of the\ncompanies as a result of the devotion of management\'s attention to the merger; \n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nmanaging a larger combined company; \n\nmaintaining employee morale and retaining key management and other employees; \n\nthe possibility of faulty assumptions underlying expectations regarding the integration process; \n\nretaining existing business and operational relationships and attracting new business and operational relationships; \n\nconsolidating corporate and administrative infrastructures and eliminating duplicative operations; \n\ncoordinating geographically separate organizations; \n\nunanticipated issues in integrating information technology, communications and other systems; and \n\nunforeseen expenses or delays associated with the merger.\n\n        Many of these factors will be outside of the combined company\'s control and any one of them could result in delays, increased costs,\ndecreases in the amount of expected revenues and diversion of management\'s time and energy, which could materially affect the combined\ncompany\'s financial position, results of operations and cash flows.\n\n        Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace are currently permitted to conduct only limited planning for the integration of the two\ncompanies following the merger and have not yet determined the exact nature of how the businesses and operations of the two companies\nwill be combined after the merger. The actual integration may result in additional and unforeseen expenses, and the anticipated benefits of\nthe integration plan may not be realized on a timely basis, if at all.\n\nRockwell Collins stockholders and B/E Aerospace stockholders will have a reduced ownership and voting interest after the merger and\nwill exercise less influence over the policies of the combined company than they now have on the policies of Rockwell Collins and B/E\nAerospace, respectively.\n\n        Rockwell Collins stockholders presently have the right to vote in the election of the Rockwell Collins Board and on other matters\naffecting Rockwell Collins. B/E Aerospace stockholders presently have the right to vote in the election of the B/E Aerospace Board and on\nother matters affecting B/E Aerospace. Immediately after the merger is completed, it is expected that current Rockwell Collins\nstockholders will own approximately 80.8% of the combined company\'s common stock outstanding and current B/E Aerospace\nstockholders will own approximately 19.2% of the combined company\'s common stock outstanding.\n\n53\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n63/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\n        As a result, current Rockwell Collins stockholders and current B/E Aerospace stockholders will have less influence on the policies of\nthe combined company than they now have on the policies of Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace, respectively.\n\nThe future results of the combined company may be adversely impacted if the combined company does not effectively manage its\nexpanded operations following the completion of the merger.\n\n        Following the completion of the merger, the size of the combined company\'s business will be significantly larger than the current size\nof either Rockwell Collins\' or B/E Aerospace\'s respective businesses. The combined company\'s ability to successfully manage this\nexpanded business will depend, in part, upon management\'s ability to design and implement strategic initiatives that address not only the\nintegration of two discrete companies, but also the increased scale and scope of the combined business with its associated increased costs\nand complexity. There can be no assurances that the combined company will be successful or that it will realize the expected operating\nefficiencies, cost savings and other benefits currently anticipated from the merger.\n\nThe combined company is expected to incur substantial expenses related to the completion of the merger and the integration of\nRockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace.\n\n        There are a large number of processes, policies, procedures, operations, technologies and systems that must be integrated, including\npurchasing, accounting and finance, sales, payroll, pricing, revenue recognition, marketing, employee benefits, legal and compliance,\nstrategic and financial planning, information technology and treasury. In addition, the businesses of Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace\nwill continue to maintain a presence in Cedar Rapids, Iowa and Wellington, Florida, respectively. The substantial majority of these costs\nwill be non-recurring expenses related to the merger (including financing of the merger and the refinancing of certain indebtedness),\nfacilities and systems consolidation costs. The combined company may incur additional costs to maintain employee morale and to retain\nkey employees. Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace will also incur transaction fees and costs related to formulating integration plans for\nthe combined business, and the execution of these plans may lead to additional unanticipated costs and time delays. Additionally, as a\nresult of the merger, rating agencies may take negative actions with regard to the combined company\'s credit ratings, which may increase\nthe combined company\'s costs in connection with the financing of the merger and its future cost of capital. These incremental transaction\nand merger-related costs may exceed the savings the combined company expects to achieve from the elimination of duplicative costs and\nthe realization of other efficiencies related to the integration of the businesses, particularly in the near term and in the event there are\nmaterial unanticipated costs.\n\nThe combined company will be significantly more leveraged than Rockwell Collins is currently.\n\n        In connection with the merger, the combined company intends to seek approximately $5.9 billion in additional indebtedness. The\ncombined company will have consolidated indebtedness of approximately $8.0 billion, which is greater than the current indebtedness of\nRockwell Collins prior to the merger. The increased indebtedness and higher debt-to-total capitalization ratio of the combined company in\ncomparison to that of Rockwell Collins on a historical basis may have the effect, among other things, of reducing the flexibility of\nRockwell Collins to respond to changing business and economic conditions, requiring the combined company to use substantial amounts\nof cash flow to acquire indebtedness, increasing borrowing costs and placing the combined company in a disadvantage compared to its\ncompetitors with less leverage.\n\n        For a more complete description of the financial impact of the combined company\'s indebtedness, see "Unaudited Pro Forma\nCondensed Combined Financial Statements" beginning on page 173.\n\n54\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n64/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nThe financing arrangements that Rockwell Collins has entered into in connection with the merger contain restrictions and limitations\nthat could, under certain circumstances, significantly impact its ability to operate its business.\n\n        Rockwell Collins intends to incur significant new indebtedness in connection with the merger. The agreements governing the\nindebtedness that it will incur in connection with the merger contain covenants that, among other things, may, under certain circumstances,\nplace limitations on the dollar amounts paid or other actions relating to:\n\nconsolidating with or merging into any other corporation or conveying or transferring its properties and assets substantially\nas an entirety; \n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nincurring secured debt; \n\nentering into sale and leaseback transactions; and \n\ndesignating subsidiaries as restricted or unrestricted.\n\n        Such agreements also require the combined company to maintain a debt-to-capitalization ratio, which may further limit the combined\ncompany\'s discretion in the operation of its business following the merger. Such agreements also contain additional restrictive covenants.\nVarious risks, uncertainties and events beyond the combined company\'s control could affect its ability to comply with the covenants\ncontained in its debt agreements. Failure to comply with any of the covenants in its existing or future financing agreements could result in\na default under those agreements and under other agreements containing cross-default provisions. A default would permit lenders to\naccelerate the maturity of the debt under these agreements. Under these circumstances, Rockwell Collins might not have sufficient funds\nor other resources to satisfy all of its obligations. In addition, the limitations imposed by financing agreements on the combined company\'s\nability to incur additional debt and to take other actions might significantly impair its ability to obtain other financing.\n\nThe market price of the combined company\'s common stock may be affected by factors different from those affecting the price of\nRockwell Collins or B/E Aerospace common stock.\n\n        Upon completion of the merger, holders of Rockwell Collins common stock and B/E Aerospace common stock will be holders of\ncommon stock of Rockwell Collins. As the businesses of Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace are different, the results of operations as\nwell as the price of the combined company\'s common stock may in the future be affected by factors different from those factors affecting\nRockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace as independent stand-alone companies. The combined company will face additional risks and\nuncertainties that Rockwell Collins or B/E Aerospace may currently not be exposed to as independent companies.\n\nThe market price of Rockwell Collins\' common stock may decline as a result of the merger.\n\n        The market price of Rockwell Collins common stock may decline as a result of the merger if, among other things, the combined\ncompany is unable to achieve the expected growth in earnings, or if the operational cost savings estimates in connection with the\nintegration of Rockwell Collins\' and B/E Aerospace\'s businesses are not realized, or if the transaction costs related to the merger are\ngreater than expected, or if the financing related to the transaction is on unfavorable terms. The market price also may decline if the\ncombined company does not achieve the perceived benefits of the merger as rapidly or to the extent anticipated by financial or industry\nanalysts or if the effect of the merger on the combined company\'s financial position, results of operations or cash flows is not consistent\nwith the expectations of financial or industry analysts.\n\n55\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n65/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nOther Risk Factors of Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace\n\n        Rockwell Collins\' and B/E Aerospace\'s businesses are and will be subject to the risks described above. In addition, Rockwell Collins\nand B/E Aerospace are, and will continue to be, subject to the risks described in the Rockwell Collins annual report on Form 10-K for the\nfiscal year ended September 30, 2016 and the B/E Aerospace annual report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2015, as\nupdated by subsequent Quarterly Reports on Form 10-Q and Current Reports on Form 8-K, all of which are filed with the SEC and\nincorporated by reference into this joint proxy statement/prospectus. See "Where You Can Find More Information" beginning on page 198\nfor the location of information incorporated by reference into this joint proxy statement/prospectus.\n\n56\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n66/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nTHE MERGER \n\n        The following is a discussion of the transaction and the material terms of the merger agreement between Rockwell Collins and B/E\nAerospace. You are urged to read carefully the merger agreement in its entirety, a copy of which is attached as Annex A to this joint proxy\nstatement/prospectus and incorporated by reference herein.\n\nBackground of the Merger \n\n        As part of B/E Aerospace\'s ongoing strategic planning process, members of the B/E Aerospace Board and members of B/E Aerospace\nsenior management periodically review and assess B/E Aerospace\'s operations, financial performance and competitive position, as well as\nindustry trends and potential strategic initiatives. In addition, members of B/E Aerospace senior management meet with members of the\nB/E Aerospace Board in the ordinary course of business to discuss strategic alternatives in order to enhance stockholder value, including,\namong other things, business combinations, acquisitions, divestitures, dividends and share repurchases. In connection with these reviews\nand assessments, from time to time, the B/E Aerospace Board and members of B/E Aerospace senior management enlist the assistance of\nfinancial advisors and outside legal advisors.\n\n        As part of Rockwell Collins\' ongoing strategic planning process, members of the Rockwell Collins Board and members of Rockwell\nCollins senior management periodically review and assess Rockwell Collins\' operations, financial performance and competitive position,\nas well as industry trends and potential strategic initiatives to accelerate growth. As part of this process, Rockwell Collins considered a\nnumber of alternatives to expand and strengthen its business. Given Rockwell Collins\' strong position in the products and services that it\ncurrently serves, Rockwell Collins determined to focus its consideration of possible growth opportunities on businesses that were adjacent\nto Rockwell Collins current products and services. Rockwell Collins evaluated the possibility of expanding channels or capabilities, but\ndetermined that adding products and services that would build on Rockwell Collins\' existing strong customer relationships would be a\nmore efficient and lower risk path.\n\n        Accordingly, in early 2015, Rockwell Collins undertook an initiative to assess the desirability of expanding the industry segments\naddressed by Rockwell Collins. This initiative involved a strategic assessment of Rockwell Collins\' capabilities and customer\nrelationships. Starting with approximately 80 companies that fit a general set of criteria, potential targets were analyzed against these\ncriteria. In considering potential acquisition targets, Rockwell Collins considered a number of factors and qualities with respect to potential\nacquisition targets, including the technical differentiation of their respective products and services, the similarity of regulatory regimes in\nwhich they operated, their leadership position in the segments that they served, their customer relationships and reputation and their full\nproduct life cycle capability. At Rockwell Collins\' board meeting in June 2015, a short list of potential targets, which included B/E\nAerospace, was presented. In subsequent board meetings in November 2015, April 2016 and June 2016, the candidates were evaluated\nagainst changing market conditions and assessed fit. The short list of targets evaluated by the Rockwell Collins Board at these meetings\nvaried from 2 to 4 companies. Changes in the composition of the list were made based on Rockwell Collins\' ongoing valuation analysis\nand consideration of market conditions, as well as Rockwell Collins\' assessment of the potential target\'s receptivity to a potential sale\ntransaction. B/E Aerospace remained an acquisition candidate of interest throughout this time.\n\n        The following chronology sets forth a summary of the material events leading up to the execution of the merger agreement.\n\n        In January 2016, a representative of a company, referred to as Party A, contacted Mr. Amin J. Khoury, Executive Chairman of B/E\nAerospace, seeking to arrange a meeting. In the ordinary course of business, B/E Aerospace senior management met with Party A from\ntime to time to discuss, generally, the ongoing business relationship between the parties. In advance of this particular meeting,\n\n57\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n67/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nrepresentatives of Party A requested to include a member of its business development team at such meeting, to which B/E Aerospace\nsenior management agreed. In mid-February 2016, Mr. Khoury met with representatives of Party A. During this meeting, the parties\ndiscussed, among other things, their businesses, their business relationship and general market trends. Party A did not make any specific\ninquiries with respect to a potential transaction involving B/E Aerospace at or following such meeting.\n\n        In February 2016, based on Citigroup\'s prior financial advisory work for Rockwell Collins, representatives of Rockwell Collins\ncontacted representatives of Citigroup to inquire about exploring a potential transaction in the aircraft interiors industry. Following that\ninitial discussion on February 8, Rockwell Collins contacted representatives of Citigroup and expressed preliminary interest in exploring a\npotential transaction with B/E Aerospace.\n\n        In late February 2016, Mr. Jeffrey MacLauchlan, Senior Vice President of Corporate Development of Rockwell Collins, contacted\nMr. Joseph Lower, Chief Financial Officer of B/E Aerospace, to arrange a meeting. On February 29, 2016, Messrs. MacLauchlan and\nLower met to discuss market conditions and industry trends. In addition, Mr. MacLauchlan discussed the complementary nature of\nRockwell Collins\' and B/E Aerospace\'s respective businesses. At the conclusion of the meeting, Messrs. MacLauchlan and Lower agreed\nto stay in touch and to potentially continue their conversation at a future date. Following the meeting, Mr. Lower informed other members\nof B/E Aerospace senior management about the meeting.\n\n        In April 2016, a company, which, together with its parent company is referred to as Party B, called Mr. Khoury to arrange a meeting\nthat would include, among others, a senior executive of Party B. Mr. Khoury notified the B/E Aerospace Board of such request. On\nMay 11, 2016, representatives of B/E Aerospace senior management met with representatives of Party B to explore potential strategic\nalternatives, including an investment in B/E Aerospace by Party B or a combination of B/E Aerospace and Party B. Shortly thereafter,\nParty B informed B/E Aerospace senior management that it was not prepared to make an investment in, or further explore a strategic\ntransaction with, B/E Aerospace.\n\n        Between February and June 2016, Rockwell Collins senior management continued to evaluate potential targets and their relative\nmerits. Rockwell Collins senior management provided a status report of this process to the Rockwell Collins Board at its April 2016\nmeeting. At the June 2016 meeting of the Rockwell Collins Board, Rockwell Collins senior management provided a further update on its\nevaluation and recommended to the Rockwell Collins Board that Rockwell Collins engage more formally with B/E Aerospace to consider\nthe potential for a transaction.\n\n        On or about June 27, 2016, Mr. Kelly Ortberg, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer of Rockwell Collins, contacted\nMr. Khoury telephonically. Mr. Khoury and Mr. Ortberg discussed the complementary nature of Rockwell Collins\' and B/E Aerospace\'s\nrespective businesses, as well as the prospect of a potential transaction involving the two companies. At the conclusion of the\nconversation, Mr. Ortberg advised that Mr. MacLauchlan would contact Mr. Lower to schedule a face-to-face meeting to continue the\ndiscussions.\n\n        On July 7, 2016, B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins executed a mutual non-disclosure agreement. Following execution of the\nagreement, representatives of senior management of Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace scheduled a meeting for July 20, 2016.\n\n        On July 20, 2016, representatives of senior management of B/E Aerospace (Messrs. Khoury and Lower and Mr. Werner Lieberherr,\nPresident and Chief Executive Officer of B/E Aerospace) and Rockwell Collins (Messrs. Ortberg and MacLauchlan, and Mr. Patrick\nAllen, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of Rockwell Collins) met at B/E Aerospace\'s headquarters in Wellington, Florida\nto discuss the prospect of a potential transaction involving the two companies. Each party presented portions of their investor relations\nmaterials, which included publicly available information about each company\'s respective financial and operational results, business and\nproduct lines. In addition, B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins discussed potential areas of cost and revenue synergies\n\n58\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n68/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nthat were identified by each party. Rockwell Collins expressed an interest in continuing discussions to further explore the potential\ncombination benefits. The parties agreed that if further discussions were held, advisors could be helpful in refining these estimates and\napproaches.\n\n        On July 28, 2016, the B/E Aerospace Board met in Boston, Massachusetts in connection with the regularly scheduled annual meeting\nof stockholders of B/E Aerospace. At this meeting, among other matters, B/E Aerospace senior management provided an overview of the\nrecent interest expressed by Party A, Party B and Rockwell Collins in connection with a potential transaction involving B/E Aerospace.\nFollowing conversations amongst the B/E Aerospace Board and B/E Aerospace senior management, the B/E Aerospace Board directed\nB/E Aerospace senior management to explore potential strategic alternatives with assistance from independent financial advisors.\n\n        Subsequent to the B/E Aerospace Board meeting, the parties agreed to meet to continue discussions and to include financial and legal\nadvisors going forward.\n\n        On August 9, 2016, senior management of B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins met in New York to continue preliminary\ndiscussions regarding a potential transaction involving the two companies and discussed the expectations for the meeting with advisors to\noccur the following day.\n\n        On August 10, 2016, representatives of senior management of B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins, together with representatives\nfrom Shearman & Sterling LLP, which is referred to as Shearman & Sterling, outside counsel to B/E Aerospace, Citigroup, as financial\nadvisor to B/E Aerospace, Goldman Sachs, as financial advisor to B/E Aerospace, Skadden, outside counsel to Rockwell Collins, and J.P.\nMorgan, as financial advisor to Rockwell Collins, met at the offices of Shearman & Sterling. At the meeting, representatives of senior\nmanagement of B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins discussed their respective businesses. In addition, B/E Aerospace senior\nmanagement discussed the financial outlook of B/E Aerospace and potential cost and revenue synergies that could be achieved in\nconnection with a potential combination of B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins. At the conclusion of the meeting, senior management of\nB/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins agreed to perform additional due diligence and financial analyses with their respective\nrepresentatives, and to meet again following such additional diligence and analyses to further explore the prospects of a potential\ncombination.\n\n        On August 15, 2015, the executive committee of the Rockwell Collins Board met telephonically. At the meeting, Rockwell Collins\nsenior management provided the committee with an update on the potential acquisition of B/E Aerospace, including the meetings between\nthe two parties on August 9 and August 10, 2016.\n\n        On August 16, 2016, the B/E Aerospace Board met telephonically. Present at the meeting were members of B/E Aerospace senior\nmanagement and representatives from Shearman & Sterling, Citigroup and Goldman Sachs. At the meeting, B/E Aerospace senior\nmanagement discussed the B/E Aerospace five-year plan that had previously been distributed to the B/E Aerospace Board and answered\nquestions from members of the B/E Aerospace Board regarding the assumptions and inputs of the plan. The five-year plan, which had\nbeen prepared in connection with B/E Aerospace senior management\'s evaluation of a potential transaction with Rockwell Collins,\nincluded information related to revenue, earnings before interest and income tax, earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and\namortization and free cash flow for the periods set forth therein. B/E Aerospace senior management then provided an update with respect\nto the ongoing discussions between B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins, including a report on the meetings between the two parties on\nAugust 9 and August 10, 2016.\n\n        Also at this meeting, representatives of Citigroup and Goldman Sachs discussed certain aspects of the transaction and advised the B/E\nAerospace Board that it was expected that any transaction would include consideration consisting of a significant Rockwell Collins stock\ncomponent. Representatives of Shearman & Sterling discussed with the B/E Aerospace Board, among other things, its fiduciary duties\nunder Delaware law in the context of a transaction process.\n\n59\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n69/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\n        Following these discussions, representatives of Citigroup and Goldman Sachs were then excused from the meeting to allow the B/E\nAerospace Board to discuss formally engaging both Citigroup and Goldman Sachs as joint financial advisors. Representatives from each\nof Citigroup and Goldman Sachs were then asked to return to the meeting at separate times to answer specific questions about their\nrespective relationships with Rockwell Collins.\n\n        At the conclusion of the meeting, the B/E Aerospace Board authorized B/E Aerospace senior management to proceed with\nnegotiations with Rockwell Collins and to provide the B/E Aerospace five-year plan to Rockwell Collins in order to facilitate further\ndiscussions. In addition, the B/E Aerospace Board authorized B/E Aerospace senior management to formally retain both Citigroup and\nGoldman Sachs as joint financial advisors in connection with the consideration and review of strategic alternatives by the B/E Aerospace\nBoard. On September 6, 2016, Citigroup and Goldman Sachs each executed engagement letters with B/E Aerospace to provide financial\nadvisory services to B/E Aerospace in connection with the consideration and review of strategic alternatives by the B/E Aerospace Board.\n\n        On August 22, 2016, representatives of senior management of B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins met to further discuss the\nprospect of a potential transaction. The parties also discussed their respective business plans, including each company\'s five-year plan, and\npresented certain legal, financial and operational information to each other.\n\n        On September 2, 2016, the corporate strategy and finance committee and the executive committee of the Rockwell Collins Board met\ntelephonically in a joint meeting. Present at the meeting were members of Rockwell Collins senior management and representatives from\nSkadden and J.P. Morgan. At the meeting, Rockwell Collins senior management provided an update with respect to the potential\nacquisition of B/E Aerospace, including a review of the process followed by Rockwell Collins senior management to identify suitable\nacquisition candidates and a review of B/E Aerospace\'s financial and market profile, the impact of the potential acquisition on the\ncompanies\' combined business portfolio and potential cost synergies. Representatives of J.P. Morgan discussed J.P. Morgan\'s preliminary\nfinancial analysis perspectives with respect to the potential transaction. Rockwell Collins senior management then reviewed with the\ncommittees, and obtained their concurrence on, the terms of a proposed preliminary, non-binding indication of interest for the potential\ntransaction.\n\n        Later on September 2, 2016, Rockwell Collins delivered a preliminary, non-binding indication of interest to B/E Aerospace, pursuant\nto which Rockwell Collins proposed to acquire 100% of the common stock of B/E Aerospace for a per share purchase price of between\n$58 and $60, to be paid 50% in cash and 50% in shares of Rockwell Collins common stock.\n\n        On September 5, 2016, following preliminary discussions with B/E Aerospace senior management, representatives of Citigroup and\nGoldman Sachs were directed to contact representatives of J.P. Morgan to inform J.P. Morgan that B/E Aerospace senior management\nbelieved that the B/E Aerospace Board would likely view Rockwell Collins\' proposal as not sufficiently attractive and would likely be\nunwilling to engage in further discussions based on the valuation included in the proposal.\n\n        On September 7, 2016, the B/E Aerospace Board met at the offices of Shearman & Sterling. Also present at the meeting were\nmembers of B/E Aerospace senior management and representatives from Shearman & Sterling, Citigroup and Goldman Sachs. At the\nmeeting, B/E Aerospace senior management updated the B/E Aerospace Board with respect to the performance and outlook of\nB/E Aerospace, other general market conditions that impact B/E Aerospace\'s businesses, and other factors viewed as relevant in\ndetermining whether B/E Aerospace should further consider the Rockwell Collins proposal or other strategic alternatives. Following that\ndiscussion, B/E Aerospace senior management, together with its financial advisors, provided a general summary of the September 2, 2016\nnon-binding indication of interest, and representatives of Citigroup and Goldman Sachs provided their\n\n60\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n70/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\npreliminary financial analysis with respect to B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins and an overview of preliminary discussions with J.P.\nMorgan with respect to the proposal.\n\n        The B/E Aerospace Board, together with senior management and its advisors, then engaged in a detailed discussion on how to best\nfacilitate a process that would be in the best interests of B/E Aerospace and its stockholders. The B/E Aerospace Board and B/E Aerospace\nsenior management discussed possible strategic alternatives available to maximize stockholder value, including executing B/E Aerospace\'s\norganic business plan, alternative capital structures and capital deployment priorities, potential strategic acquisitions or an alternative\nbusiness combination. B/E Aerospace senior management and the B/E Aerospace Board then discussed the current environment in the\naerospace industry, including the trends in consolidation and competition, and the likely effect of these factors on B/E Aerospace.\nFollowing these discussions, the B/E Aerospace Board did not believe that other strategic alternatives would likely be as attractive as a\npotential transaction with Rockwell Collins (assuming more favorable terms could be negotiated).\n\n        B/E Aerospace senior management then provided an overview of its prior discussions with Party A and Party B regarding a potential\ntransaction involving B/E Aerospace, and noted that neither such discussions resulted in an express or implied indication of interest from\nParty A or Party B that such companies were prepared to pursue a potential transaction involving B/E Aerospace. The B/E Aerospace\nBoard then asked one of its directors that had a previous relationship with (and from time to time speaks to representatives of) a potential\nstrategic partner, referred to as Party C, to contact Party C to gauge its interest in a potential transaction involving B/E Aerospace.\nFollowing the meeting and in response to the inquiry made by a member of the B/E Aerospace Board, Party C advised that it was not\ninterested in pursuing a transaction with B/E Aerospace.\n\n        Representatives of Citigroup and Goldman Sachs then provided an overview of potential transaction partners (other than Rockwell\nCollins) that may have both a strategic rationale and the financial wherewithal to consummate a transaction with B/E Aerospace. These\npotential acquirers included companies currently serving the aerospace and defense markets as well as financial buyers. As part of these\ndiscussions, the B/E Aerospace Board discussed whether other parties should be contacted in light of Rockwell Collins\' proposal and\ndiscussed the likelihood that any other parties would be interested in a strategic transaction involving B/E Aerospace on the same or\nsimilar terms to the Rockwell Collins proposal. Based upon these discussions, the prior contacts with Party A and Party B (and subject to\nthe result of the inquiry to be made to Party C), and advice from the financial advisors, the B/E Aerospace Board determined that such\ntransaction partners would not likely be able to consummate a transaction with B/E Aerospace that would provide equal or greater value to\nB/E Aerospace stockholders as compared to a potential transaction with Rockwell Collins (assuming more favorable terms could be\nnegotiated). As such, the B/E Aerospace Board determined not to expand its search for strategic alternatives with other third parties to\navoid the risk of losing momentum with what was viewed as the most attractive strategic alternative.\n\n        The B/E Aerospace Board, together with B/E Aerospace senior management and its advisors, then engaged in an extensive discussion\nregarding a potential transaction with Rockwell Collins. Following these discussions, the B/E Aerospace Board determined that Rockwell\nCollins\' proposal was, as then proposed, not yet sufficiently attractive from a financial point of view, but that further discussion with\nRockwell Collins was warranted. The B/E Aerospace Board authorized Citigroup and Goldman Sachs to advise J.P. Morgan that\nB/E Aerospace found the Rockwell Collins proposal to be not sufficiently attractive and to provide guidance with respect to elements of\nthe proposal that would need to be improved.\n\n        On September 8, 2016, representatives of Citigroup and Goldman Sachs advised representatives of J.P. Morgan of the outcome of the\nB/E Aerospace Board meeting on September 7, 2016, and the need to improve the economic terms of the proposal by Rockwell Collins in\norder for B/E Aerospace to further consider a potential combination.\n\n61\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n71/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\n        On September 14, 2016, the Rockwell Collins Board met in person for a regularly scheduled board meeting at Rockwell Collins\'\nheadquarters in Cedar Rapids, Iowa. Present at the meeting were members of Rockwell Collins senior management and representatives\nfrom Skadden and J.P. Morgan. At the meeting, representatives of Skadden discussed with the Rockwell Collins Board, among other\nthings, its fiduciary duties under Delaware law in the context of a potential acquisition of B/E Aerospace. Rockwell Collins senior\nmanagement provided an update with respect to the potential acquisition of B/E Aerospace, including a review of the process followed by\nmanagement to identify suitable acquisition candidates and a review of B/E Aerospace\'s financial and market profile, the impact of the\npotential acquisition on the companies\' combined business portfolio and potential cost synergies. Rockwell Collins senior management\nthen presented preliminary valuation perspectives regarding B/E Aerospace and reviewed the terms of the preliminary, non-binding\nindication of interest submitted to B/E Aerospace on September 2, 2016 and B/E Aerospace\'s response to such indication of interest.\nRockwell Collins senior management then reviewed with the Rockwell Collins Board possible revisions to the terms of its indication of\ninterest. The preliminary valuation perspectives regarding B/E Aerospace presented by Rockwell Collins senior management and the\npossible revisions to the terms of the September 12, 2016 indication of interest included the merger consideration (including a cash and\nstock mix) set forth in the merger agreement.\n\n        On September 16, 2016, representatives of J.P. Morgan, at Rockwell Collins\' direction, indicated to representatives of Citigroup and\nGoldman Sachs that Rockwell Collins remained interested in a transaction and was prepared, subject to additional diligence, to negotiate a\ntransaction (i) in a price range of $61 to $62 per share, consisting of 50% cash and 50% shares of Rockwell Collins common stock, subject\nto a price collar, (ii) with termination fees payable by each company under certain circumstances of $200 million and (iii) whereby one\ndirector designated by B/E Aerospace would be appointed to the Rockwell Collins Board.\n\n        Between September 16, 2016 and September 27, 2016, each of B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins continued to perform additional\ndue diligence on the other party, including a telephonic due diligence session that was held on September 25, 2016 among B/E Aerospace,\nRockwell Collins and their respective financial advisors.\n\n        On September 20, 2016, members of the B/E Aerospace Board met telephonically with representatives of B/E Aerospace senior\nmanagement, Shearman & Sterling, Citigroup and Goldman Sachs, during which B/E Aerospace senior management, together with its\nfinancial advisors, provided an update on negotiations between B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins and reviewed the revised terms of the\nproposed transaction conveyed to Citigroup and Goldman by J.P. Morgan on September 16, 2016.\n\n        On September 21, 2016, the compensation committee of the B/E Aerospace Board, consulted with Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher LLP,\nwhich is referred to as Gibson Dunn, regarding the possible engagement of Gibson Dunn as independent legal counsel to assist the\ncompensation committee in its evaluation of certain compensation matters related to a potential transaction. Specifically, as previously\ndisclosed in B/E Aerospace\'s public filings, since 2013, the B/E Aerospace Board and the compensation committee determined that they\nwould favorably consider the grant of transaction bonuses to the top named executive officers of B/E Aerospace in the event of a change in\ncontrol transaction, which bonuses would be in addition to amounts payable under the employment agreements with each executive. The\nfinal determination of the structure and the specific amount of such bonuses was deferred by the compensation committee until such time\nas B/E Aerospace might become involved in active transaction negotiations. The compensation committee determined to retain Gibson\nDunn, negotiated the terms of the Gibson Dunn engagement, and ultimately executed an engagement letter with Gibson Dunn on\nSeptember 30, 2016.\n\n        On September 27, 2016, representatives of B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins senior management, as well as representatives from\nShearman & Sterling, Citigroup, Goldman Sachs, Skadden\n\n62\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n72/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nand J.P. Morgan met at the offices of Shearman & Sterling. Following several rounds of negotiations, the parties reached a tentative\nagreement, subject to further due diligence, the negotiation of other material transaction terms and the negotiation of acceptable definitive\ndocumentation and board approval, on the following terms: (i) Rockwell Collins would acquire 100% of the common stock of\nB/E Aerospace for $62 per share, with the consideration consisting of 50% cash and 50% shares of Rockwell Collins common stock,\nsubject to a two-way 7.5% collar; (ii) the termination fee payable by Rockwell Collins to B/E Aerospace under certain circumstances\nwould be $300 million and the termination fee payable by B/E Aerospace to Rockwell Collins under certain circumstances would be\n$200 million; (iii) Rockwell Collins would add two directors designated by B/E Aerospace to the Rockwell Collins Board; and (iv) certain\nB/E Aerospace compensation and benefits related matters. Based upon Rockwell Collins\' director qualification requirements, John T.\nWhates and Richard G. Hamermesh, both members of the B/E Aerospace Board, were identified as the likely B/E Aerospace designees.\n\n        On September 27, 2016, members of Rockwell Collins senior management contacted Mr. Lieberherr to discuss Mr. Lieberherr\'s\nwillingness to remain with the combined company following the closing of the potential merger. Mr. Lieberherr retained Latham &\nWatkins LLP, which is referred to as Latham & Watkins, to advise him regarding the terms of any future employment with the combined\ncompany. Mr. Lieberherr subsequently informed B/E Aerospace senior management of the possibility that he would continue to work for\nthe combined company following closing of the potential merger.\n\n        On September 29, 2016, B/E Aerospace opened a virtual data room and invited Rockwell Collins and its representatives to review\ndue diligence materials relating to B/E Aerospace included therein.\n\n        On September 30, 2016, Skadden distributed an initial draft of the merger agreement to Shearman & Sterling.\n\n        On September 30, 2016, J.P. Morgan, at Rockwell Collins\' request, provided due diligence materials relating to Rockwell Collins to\nCitigroup and Goldman Sachs, which in turn provided these materials to B/E Aerospace for due diligence review. The due diligence\nmaterials included Rockwell Collin\'s strategic plan and related projections.\n\n        Between September 30, 2016 and October 23, 2016, Rockwell Collins\' and B/E Aerospace\'s legal counsels negotiated the terms and\nconditions of the merger agreement, including, among other things, representations and warranties, covenants relating to conduct of\nbusiness and regulatory approvals, tax matters relating to the KLX spin-off, the treatment of various pre- and post-closing compensation-\nrelated matters, closing conditions and termination rights and fees.\n\n        Between October 1, 2016 and October 21, 2016, Mr. Lieberherr and his counsel, Latham & Watkins, negotiated terms of a future\nemployment agreement with Rockwell Collins and Skadden. In the course of these negotiations, Rockwell Collins and Mr. Lieberherr\ndiscussed a possible leadership role in the combined company and ultimately agreed that Mr. Lieberherr would serve as an Executive Vice\nPresident of Rockwell Collins and the Chief Operating Officer of Rockwell Collins\' aircraft interior systems business unit. On October 21,\n2016, Mr. Lieberherr and Rockwell Collins executed and delivered an employment agreement. Later that same day, Mr. Lieberherr notified\nB/E Aerospace senior management that he had entered into such employment agreement.\n\n        On October 3, 2016, Rockwell Collins hosted a telephonic due diligence call with B/E Aerospace and its financial advisors during\nwhich Rockwell Collins answered various questions regarding Rockwell Collins, its strategic plan and projections and the related due\ndiligence materials previously provided.\n\n        On October 5, 2016, J.P. Morgan, at Rockwell Collins\' request, provided additional due diligence materials relating to Rockwell\nCollins to Citigroup and Goldman Sachs, which in turn provided these\n\n63\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n73/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nmaterials to B/E Aerospace for due diligence review. The diligence materials included Rockwell Collins\' plans for the merger and an initial\ndraft of the Rockwell Collins rating agency presentation.\n\n        On October 7, 2016, Rockwell Collins and representatives from J.P. Morgan met with S&P and Moody\'s to provide an overview of\nthe potential transaction between B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins.\n\n        On October 12, 2016, the Rockwell Collins Board met telephonically. Present at the meeting were members of Rockwell Collins\nsenior management and representatives from Skadden and J.P. Morgan. Rockwell Collins senior management reviewed in detail the\npotential acquisition of B/E Aerospace, including the strategic rationale for the transaction, the estimated cost synergies expected to be\nachieved in the transaction, B/E Aerospace\'s projected financial forecasts and pro forma financial forecasts of the combined companies,\nthe proposed financing of the transaction, the results of the financial and legal due diligence review performed on B/E Aerospace and\nvarious tax considerations relating to the KLX spin-off. Representatives of Skadden reviewed the terms of the proposed draft merger\nagreement for the transaction. Representatives of J.P. Morgan discussed J.P. Morgan\'s preliminary financial analyses with respect to the\ntransaction.\n\n        On October 13, 2016, the B/E Aerospace Board met telephonically. B/E Aerospace senior management provided the B/E Aerospace\nBoard with an update on negotiations between B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins, including the status of negotiations with respect to\ncertain key contractual terms, the status of the mutual due diligence process and certain timing considerations. Mr. Khoury advised that\nRockwell Collins was interested in retaining Mr. Lieberherr, and confirmed Mr. Lieberherr\'s willingness to remain with the combined\ncompany pursuant to the terms of an employment agreement to be negotiated and executed at or immediately prior to signing.\n\n        On October 13, 2016, following four telephonic meetings of the compensation committee with the participation of its independent\nadvisors, Gibson Dunn and Pearl Meyer & Partners, LLC (which also included a presentation from senior management\'s outside counsel,\nFreshfields Bruckhaus Deringer LLP, and senior management\'s outside consulting and tax advisory firm, Golden Parachute Tax\nSolutions LLC), the compensation committee recommended for approval by the B/E Aerospace Board, and the B/E Aerospace Board\n(with Mr. Khoury abstaining) approved, the payment and terms of transaction bonuses for Messrs. Khoury, Lieberherr, Lower and Patch.\n\n        On October 18, 2016, representatives of J.P. Morgan, at Rockwell Collins\' direction, contacted representatives of Citigroup and\nGoldman Sachs to convey Rockwell Collins\' intent to revise the proposed mix of consideration, consisting of 55% cash (i.e., $34.10) and\n45% stock (i.e., shares of Rockwell Collins common stock having a value equal to $27.90), subject to a two-way 7.5% collar.\n\n        On October 21, 2016, the Rockwell Collins Board met at the offices of Skadden in New York. Present at the meeting were members\nof Rockwell Collins senior management and representatives from Skadden and J.P. Morgan. Rockwell Collins senior management updated\nthe Rockwell Collins Board on the results of the additional financial analysis and due diligence performed on B/E Aerospace and the status\nof negotiations with B/E Aerospace. The reports on the additional financial analysis and due diligence presented by Rockwell Collins\nsenior management included a review of B/E Aerospace\'s change of control payments, a review of the anticipated synergies from the\ntransaction and an assessment of certain B/E Aerospace employee and customer relations matters. Rockwell Collins senior management\nalso reviewed in detail the proposed financing of the transaction, including the terms of the proposed bridge commitment for a portion of\nthe cash consideration. Representatives of Skadden reviewed, among other things, the terms of the draft merger agreement, a copy of\nwhich previously had been provided to the Rockwell Collins Board along with a summary of the material terms of the merger agreement.\nRepresentatives of J.P. Morgan reviewed J.P. Morgan\'s financial analyses with respect to the proposed transaction and rendered J.P.\nMorgan\'s oral opinion to the Rockwell Collins Board that, as of such date and based upon and subject to the factors and assumptions set\nforth in its\n\n64\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n74/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nopinion, the merger consideration to be paid by Rockwell Collins was fair, from a financial point of view, to Rockwell Collins. (The oral\nopinion was subsequently confirmed in writing by delivery of J.P. Morgan\'s written opinion dated October 23, 2016.) Following extensive\ndiscussion, the Rockwell Collins Board unanimously approved the merger agreement and the transactions contemplated thereby and\nunanimously approved and adopted resolutions authorizing the transaction and related matters.\n\n        On October 21, 2016, the B/E Aerospace Board met at the offices of Shearman & Sterling. B/E Aerospace senior management\nupdated the B/E Aerospace Board on the status of negotiations with Rockwell Collins and the results of the financial and legal due\ndiligence performed on Rockwell Collins. Representatives of Shearman & Sterling reviewed, among other things, the terms of the draft\nmerger agreement, a copy of which previously had been provided to the B/E Aerospace Board along with a summary of the material terms\nof the merger agreement.\n\n        Representatives of Citigroup and Goldman Sachs presented their updated financial analyses with respect to B/E Aerospace and\nRockwell Collins.\n\n        Representatives of Citigroup then advised the B/E Aerospace Board that, based on Citigroup\'s current understandings and subject to\nreview of the execution version of the merger agreement and future developments, Citigroup expected to be able to render an opinion to\nthe B/E Aerospace Board, as of the date of the merger agreement and to the effect that, as of that date and based upon and subject to the\nfactors and assumptions described therein, the merger consideration to be paid to the holders (other than Rockwell Collins and its\naffiliates) of outstanding shares of common stock of B/E Aerospace pursuant to the merger agreement is fair from a financial point of view\nto such holders.\n\n        Representatives of Goldman Sachs then advised the B/E Aerospace Board that, based on Goldman Sachs\' current understandings and\nsubject to review of the execution version of the merger agreement and future developments, Goldman Sachs expected to be able to render\nan opinion to the B/E Aerospace Board, as of the date of the merger agreement and to the effect that, as of that date and based upon and\nsubject to the factors and assumptions described therein, the merger consideration to be paid to the holders (other than Rockwell Collins\nand its affiliates) of outstanding shares of common stock of B/E Aerospace pursuant to the merger agreement is fair from a financial point\nof view to such holders.\n\n        The B/E Aerospace Board and its advisors engaged in an extended discussion of the potential transaction and the proposed terms and\nconditions of the merger agreement, considering a number of factors, including the comparative likelihood of consummation of the\npotential transaction, the opportunities presented by the potential transaction, the recent and historical market prices for B/E Aerospace\ncommon stock and Rockwell Collins common stock and the fact that the stock portion of the merger consideration would be subject to a\ntwo-way 7.5% collar. The B/E Aerospace Board then reviewed the proposed resolutions authorizing the execution of the merger\nagreement. After carefully considering the merger agreement and the proposed resolutions, it was the consensus of the B/E Aerospace\nBoard that the merger was in the best interests of B/E Aerospace\'s stockholders and, subject to an acceptable outcome in the negotiation of\nthe final issues under the merger agreement, including certain tax matters, the ability of a party to terminate the agreement and the\napplicable fees payable in connection therewith, and certain other matters, the B/E Aerospace Board agreed that it was prepared to approve\nand adopt such proposed resolutions and authorized B/E Aerospace senior management to continue to negotiate and to finalize the merger\nagreement.\n\n        On the evening of October 21, 2016, representatives of Shearman & Sterling, Citigroup, Goldman Sachs, Skadden and J.P. Morgan\nmet at the offices of Shearman & Sterling to negotiate the final terms of the potential transaction.\n\n        On the morning of October 22, 2016, the B/E Aerospace Board reconvened for a telephonic meeting with B/E Aerospace senior\nmanagement and Shearman & Sterling. At the meeting, B/E Aerospace senior management provided an update with respect to the\nnegotiation of the terms and\n\n65\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n75/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nconditions of the potential transaction with Rockwell Collins, the remaining issues related thereto and the proposed resolution of such\nissues. Following a discussion, the B/E Aerospace Board authorized B/E Aerospace senior management to continue to negotiate and\nfinalize the definitive transaction documents in accordance with the proposed terms discussed at the meeting.\n\n        On October 22, 2016, representatives of senior management of B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins and their respective advisors\ncontinued to negotiate the final terms and conditions of the merger agreement and related transactions.\n\n        On the morning of October 23, 2016, Shearman & Sterling circulated an execution version of the merger agreement to the B/E\nAerospace Board, B/E Aerospace senior management, Citigroup and Goldman Sachs. Later that morning, by written consent, the B/E\nAerospace Board confirmed that the merger was in the best interests of B/E Aerospace\'s stockholders, unanimously approved and adopted\nthe merger agreement and the transactions contemplated thereby and unanimously approved and adopted the resolutions authorizing the\ntransaction and related matters. The B/E Aerospace Board received a written opinion, dated October 23, 2016, from each of Citigroup and\nGoldman Sachs to the effect that, as of that date and based upon and subject to the factors and assumptions set forth in such opinion, the\nmerger consideration to be paid to the holders (other than Rockwell Collins and its affiliates) of outstanding shares of common stock of\nB/E Aerospace pursuant to the merger agreement was fair from a financial point of view to such holders.\n\n        On the same day, each of B/E Aerospace, Rockwell Collins and Merger Sub executed and delivered the merger agreement.\nThereafter, B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins issued a joint press release announcing the merger.\n\nRockwell Collins Board of Directors\' Recommendations and Its Reasons for the Transaction \n\n        On October 21, 2016, the Rockwell Collins Board unanimously (i) approved the merger agreement and the transactions contemplated\nby the merger agreement; (ii) determined that the merger agreement and the transactions contemplated by the merger agreement are\nadvisable and in the best interests of Rockwell Collins and Rockwell Collins\' stockholders; (iii) directed that the Share Issuance proposal\nbe submitted to a vote of Rockwell Collins\' stockholders; and (iv) recommended that the stockholders of Rockwell Collins vote "FOR" the\nShare Issuance proposal.\n\n        In evaluating the merger agreement and the transactions contemplated by the merger agreement, the Rockwell Collins Board\nconsulted with Rockwell Collins\' management and legal and financial advisors and, in reaching its determinations, the Rockwell Collins\nBoard considered a variety of factors with respect to the merger and the other transactions contemplated by the merger agreement,\nincluding the specific reasons described above under "Risk Factors" and "\xe2\x80\x94Background of the Merger" beginning on page 46 and\npage 57, respectively, and the factors listed below.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nThe merger would significantly increase Rockwell Collins\' scale and diversify its product portfolio, customer mix and\ngeographic presence; \n\nThe merger would combine market leaders with complementary capabilities in avionics and interior products that also have\na shared reputation for innovation, quality and on-time delivery and a common customer base, including OEMs, airlines\nand lessors; \n\nThe combination of B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins would accelerate technological leadership in integrated digital\nairplanes in that it uniquely positions Rockwell Collins to provide a more integrated solution to meet the digital demands of\nthe commercial airplane; \n\nThe merger would substantially increase Rockwell Collins\' buyer-furnished equipment and aftermarket exposure by\nproviding it with a large revenue stream tied to passenger traffic growth and airline profitability with a substantial\naftermarket component, which would serve to balance Rockwell Collins\' current cyclical exposure to OEM production\nrates;\n\n66\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n76/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nThe combination of B/E Aerospace\'s leading business jet aircraft cabin interior products with Rockwell Collins\' dealer\nnetwork and owner and maintenance databases would facilitate creation of a private aircraft interiors aftermarket, which is\na significant new opportunity; \n\nThe expectation is that the combined company would achieve approximately $160 million of identified cost synergies\nfrom, among other things, the elimination of corporate and public company costs, manufacturing consolidation,\ninformation technology consolidation and supply chain leveraging, and would have improved pre-tax earnings of\napproximately $60 to $90 million per year for the first six years after the acquisition due to certain conforming purchase\naccounting adjustments related to capitalized development costs related to seller furnished equipment contracts; \n\nThe merger would significantly enhance Rockwell Collins\' financial profile by accelerating Rockwell Collins\' free cash\nflow growth and would be accretive to Rockwell Collins\' earnings per share in the first full fiscal year following the\nacquisition; \n\nThe fact that the stock portion of the merger consideration is based upon a floating exchange ratio and subject to a two-way\n7.5% collar, which provides protection against fluctuations in the market price of Rockwell Collins common stock between\nthe date of the merger agreement and the date of the completion of the merger; \n\nThe Rockwell Collins Board\'s knowledge of Rockwell Collins\' business, operations, financial condition, earnings and\nprospects and its knowledge of B/E Aerospace\'s business, operations, financial condition, earnings and prospects, taking\ninto account B/E Aerospace\'s publicly-filed information and the results of Rockwell Collins\' due diligence review of B/E\nAerospace; \n\nThe long-term and recent historical trading prices of Rockwell Collins common stock and B/E Aerospace common stock\nand the amount of the merger consideration; \n\nThe expectation that the combined company will benefit from the experienced management teams of Rockwell Collins and\nB/E Aerospace; \n\nThe commitments by both Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace to complete the merger, as set forth in the merger\nagreement, and the belief of the Rockwell Collins Board that the transaction does not present significant regulatory\nconcerns that would impact the ability to complete the merger; \n\nThe Rockwell Collins Board\'s review of Rockwell Collins\' and B/E Aerospace\'s business, strategies, current and projected\nfinancial condition, current earnings and earnings prospects; \n\nThe oral opinion of J.P. Morgan rendered to the Rockwell Collins Board on October 21, 2016, that, as of such date and\nbased upon and subject to the factors and assumptions set forth in its opinion, the merger consideration to be paid by\nRockwell Collins was fair, from a financial point of view, to Rockwell Collins, as more fully described in the section\nentitled "\xe2\x80\x94Opinion of Rockwell Collins\' Financial Advisor" beginning on page 74. The oral opinion was subsequently\nconfirmed in writing by delivery of J.P. Morgan\'s written opinion dated October 23, 2016. The full text of the written\nopinion of J.P. Morgan, which sets forth the assumptions made, matters considered and limits on the review undertaken, is\nattached as Annex B to this joint proxy statement/prospectus and is incorporated herein by reference, and Rockwell Collins\'\nstockholders are urged to read this written opinion in its entirety; \n\nThe current environment in the aerospace industry, including the trend of consolidation and increased competition; and \n\nThe merger will be subject to the approval of Rockwell Collins\' stockholders.\n\n67\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n77/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\n        The Rockwell Collins Board also specifically considered the terms of the merger agreement, including the following:\n\n        The Rockwell Collins Board weighed the foregoing against a number of potentially negative factors, including:\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nThe termination fee payable by B/E Aerospace to Rockwell Collins if B/E Aerospace terminates the merger agreement to\npursue a competing transaction with a third party or in certain other circumstances; \n\nThat if Rockwell Collins were to receive a takeover proposal from a third party that provided superior value to Rockwell\nCollins and its stockholders, Rockwell Collins and the Rockwell Collins Board would be able, under circumstances\ndescribed in the merger agreement, to consider such superior proposal and the Rockwell Collins Board may change its\nrecommendation that Rockwell Collins stockholders vote in favor of the Share Issuance proposal and/or terminate the\nmerger agreement; \n\nRockwell Collins\' ability, under circumstances described in the merger agreement, to provide information to and engage in\ndiscussions or negotiations with a third party that makes an unsolicited bona fide written takeover proposal; \n\nThe ability of the Rockwell Collins Board, subject to certain conditions, to change its recommendation supporting the\nmerger in response to an intervening event if the Rockwell Collins Board determines that failure to take such action would\nbe inconsistent with its fiduciary duties; \n\nRockwell Collins\' obligation to consummate the transaction is subject to the condition that Rockwell Collins has received\nan opinion regarding the effect of the transaction on the tax-free nature of the KLX spin-off; and \n\nThe customary nature of Rockwell Collins\' other representations, warranties and covenants in the merger agreement.\n\nThe risk of not being able to realize all of the anticipated cost savings and operational synergies between Rockwell Collins\nand B/E Aerospace and the risk that other anticipated benefits might not be realized; \n\nThe challenges inherent in the combination of two businesses of the size and complexity of Rockwell Collins and B/E\nAerospace; \n\nThe costs associated with the completion of the merger and the realization of the benefits expected to be obtained in\nconnection with the merger, including management\'s time and energy and potential opportunity cost; \n\nThe risks that the merger may not be completed and the challenges in absorbing the effect of any failure to complete the\nmerger, including stockholder and market reactions, as well as the diversion of management\'s attention from ongoing\nbusiness concerns; \n\nThe fact that the value of the merger consideration payable to B/E Aerospace stockholders could increase in the event that\nthe price of Rockwell Collins common stock increases more than 7.5% prior to completion of the merger; \n\nThe restrictions on the conduct of Rockwell Collins\' business during the period between the execution of the merger\nagreement and the completion of the merger; \n\nThe risk that regulatory agencies may not approve the merger or may impose terms and conditions on their approvals that\nadversely affect the business and financial results of the combined company as more fully described under "\xe2\x80\x94Regulatory\nApprovals Required for the Merger" beginning on page 116;\n\n68\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n78/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nThe termination fee payable by Rockwell Collins to B/E Aerospace if Rockwell Collins terminates the merger agreement to\npursue a competing transaction with a third party or in certain other circumstances; \n\nThe fact that Rockwell Collins will be required to reimburse B/E Aerospace for its expenses up to $56 million if the merger\nagreement is terminated by either party because the Rockwell Collins stockholders did not approve the share issuance for\nthe transaction; \n\nThe fact that the merger agreement does not preclude a third party from making an unsolicited proposal for a competing\ntransaction with B/E Aerospace and that, under certain circumstances more fully described in the sections "The Merger\nAgreement\xe2\x80\x94Covenants and Agreements\xe2\x80\x94No Solicitation" beginning on page 141 and "The Merger Agreement\xe2\x80\x94\nCovenants and Agreements\xe2\x80\x94Adverse Recommendation Change and Termination" beginning on page 142, B/E Aerospace\nmay furnish non-public information to and enter into discussions with such third party regarding the competing transaction\nand the B/E Aerospace Board may withdraw or modify its recommendations to B/E Aerospace stockholders regarding the\ntransaction and may terminate the merger agreement to enter into a competing transaction under certain circumstances;
