\n\nThe fact that certain senior executives of B/E Aerospace would receive substantial payments in connection with the merger;\n\nThe fact that B/E Aerospace could have substantial liabilities if the merger causes the KLX spin-off to fail to qualify for the\nKLX spin-off tax treatment; \n\nThe risk that the Rockwell Collins stockholders do not approve the Share Issuance proposal; \n\nThe fact that Rockwell Collins\' obligation to complete the transaction is not conditioned upon the ability of Rockwell\nCollins to obtain financing for the cash portion of the consideration; \n\nThe risk of litigation related to the transaction; and \n\nThe risks of the type and nature described under "Risk Factors" beginning on page 46 and the matters described under\n"Cautionary Note Regarding Forward-Looking Statements" beginning on page 44.\n\n        This discussion of the information and factors considered by the Rockwell Collins Board in reaching its conclusions and\nrecommendation includes the principal factors considered by the Rockwell Collins Board, but is not intended to be exhaustive and may not\ninclude all of the factors considered by the Rockwell Collins Board. In view of the wide variety of factors considered in connection with\nits evaluation of the transaction, and the complexity of these matters, the Rockwell Collins Board did not find it useful and did not attempt\nto quantify, rank or assign any relative or specific weights to the various factors that it considered in reaching its determination to approve\nthe transaction, including the share issuance, and to make its recommendation to Rockwell Collins stockholders. Rather, the Rockwell\nCollins Board viewed its decisions as being based on the totality of the information presented to it and the factors it considered, including\nits discussions with, and questioning of, members of Rockwell Collins\' management and Rockwell Collins\' advisors, as well as its\nexperience and history. In addition, individual members of the Rockwell Collins Board may have assigned different weights to different\nfactors.\n\n        The Rockwell Collins Board unanimously determined that the merger agreement and the transactions contemplated by the merger\nagreement were advisable and in the best interests of Rockwell Collins and its stockholders and approved the merger agreement.\nAccordingly, the Rockwell Collins Board unanimously recommends that Rockwell Collins stockholders vote "FOR" the Share Issuance\nproposal at the Rockwell Collins special meeting.\n\n69\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n79/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nB/E Aerospace Board of Directors\' Recommendations and Its Reasons for the Transaction \n\n        On October 23, 2016, the B/E Aerospace Board unanimously (i) approved and declared advisable the merger agreement and the\ntransactions contemplated by the merger agreement; (ii) determined that the merger agreement and the transactions contemplated by the\nmerger agreement are advisable and in the best interests of B/E Aerospace and B/E Aerospace\'s stockholders; (iii) directed that the Merger\nproposal be submitted to a vote of B/E Aerospace\'s stockholders; and (iv) recommended that the stockholders of B/E Aerospace vote\n"FOR" the Merger proposal.\n\n        In evaluating the merger agreement and the transactions contemplated by the merger agreement, the B/E Aerospace Board consulted\nwith B/E Aerospace\'s management and legal and financial advisors and, in reaching its determinations, the B/E Aerospace Board\nconsidered a variety of factors with respect to the merger and the other transactions contemplated by the merger agreement, including the\nspecific reasons described above under "Risk Factors" and "\xe2\x80\x94Background of the Merger" beginning on page 46 and page 57, respectively,\nand the factors listed below.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nThe merger would combine market leaders with complementary capabilities in avionics and interior products that also have\na shared reputation for innovation, quality and on-time delivery and a common customer base, including OEMs, airlines\nand lessors; \n\nThe combination of B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins would accelerate technological leadership in integrated digital\nairplanes in that it uniquely positions Rockwell Collins to provide a more integrated solution to meet the digital demands of\nthe commercial airplane; \n\nThe merger would substantially increase Rockwell Collins\' buyer-furnished equipment and aftermarket exposure by\nproviding it with a large revenue stream tied to passenger traffic growth and airline profitability with a substantial\naftermarket component, which would serve to balance Rockwell Collins\' current cyclical exposure to OEM production\nrates, which additional value would accrue to B/E Aerospace stockholders in connection with the stock portion of the\nconsideration to be received by B/E Aerospace stockholders; \n\nThe combination of B/E Aerospace\'s leading business jet aircraft cabin interior products with Rockwell Collins\' dealer\nnetwork and owner and maintenance databases would facilitate creation of a private aircraft interiors aftermarket, which is\na significant new opportunity; \n\nThe expectation is that the combined company would achieve approximately $160 million of identified cost synergies\nfrom, among other things, the elimination of corporate and public company costs, manufacturing consolidation,\ninformation technology consolidation and supply chain leveraging, and would have improved pre-tax earnings of\napproximately $60 to $90 million per year for the first six years after the acquisition due to certain conforming purchase\naccounting adjustments related to capitalized development costs related to seller furnished equipment contracts; \n\nThe merger would significantly enhance Rockwell Collins\' financial profile by accelerating Rockwell Collins\' free cash\nflow growth and would be accretive to Rockwell Collins\' earnings per share in the first full fiscal year following the\nacquisition, thereby adding value to the stock portion of the consideration received by B/E Aerospace stockholders; \n\nThe fact that the merger consideration consists of cash, providing B/E Aerospace stockholders with certainty of value and\nliquidity upon completion of the merger, along with a significant stock component, which would result in B/E Aerospace\nstockholders immediately prior to the merger holding approximately 20.3% of the common stock of Rockwell Collins\nimmediately following completion of the merger, thus providing B/E Aerospace stockholders with meaningful participation\nin the upside potential of a larger, more diversified company;\n\n70\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n80/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nThe fact that the stock portion of the merger consideration is based upon a floating exchange ratio and subject to a two-way\n7.5% collar, which provides protection against fluctuations in the market price of Rockwell Collins common stock between\nthe date of the merger agreement and the date of the completion of the merger; \n\nThe fact that the value of the merger consideration payable to B/E Aerospace stockholders could increase in the event that\nthe price of Rockwell Collins common stock increases more than 7.5% prior to completion of the merger; \n\nThe B/E Aerospace Board\'s knowledge of B/E Aerospace\'s business, operations, financial condition, earnings and\nprospects and its knowledge of Rockwell Collins\' business, operations, financial condition, earnings and prospects, taking\ninto account Rockwell Collins\' publicly-filed information and the results of B/E Aerospace\'s due diligence review of\nRockwell Collins; \n\nThe long-term and recent historical trading prices of B/E Aerospace common stock and Rockwell Collins common stock\nand the amount of the merger consideration; \n\nThe implied value of the merger consideration at the offer price of $62 per share of B/E Aerospace stock represented: \n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\na 34% premium to B/E Aerospace\'s closing share price of $46.34 as of July 20, 2016, the initial formal meeting\nbetween the parties regarding a potential transaction; \n\na 22% premium to B/E Aerospace\'s closing share price of $50.65 as of October 20, 2016; \n\na 23% premium to B/E Aerospace\'s trailing 30-day volume-weighted average price of $50.61 as of October 20,\n2016; and \n\na 28% premium to B/E Aerospace\'s trailing 90-day volume-weighted average price of 48.30 as of October 20,\n2016; \n\nThe offer price of $62 per share of B/E Aerospace stock represented a multiple of 13.6 times EV/EBITDA of\nB/E Aerospace for the last 12 months ending September 30, 2016; \n\n45% of the merger consideration would be in stock, which will allow B/E Aerospace\'s stockholders to participate in the\nfuture performance of the combined company; \n\nThe expectation that the combined company will benefit from the experienced management teams of B/E Aerospace and\nRockwell Collins; \n\nThe commitments by both B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins to complete the merger, as set forth in the merger\nagreement, and the belief of the B/E Aerospace Board that the transaction does not present significant regulatory concerns\nthat would impact the ability to complete the merger; \n\nThe risks and uncertainties associated with, and inherent in, maintaining B/E Aerospace\'s existence as an independent\ncompany; \n\nThe B/E Aerospace Board\'s review of B/E Aerospace\'s and Rockwell Collins\' business, strategies, current and projected\nfinancial condition, current earnings and earnings prospects; \n\nThe written opinions of Citigroup and Goldman Sachs delivered to the B/E Aerospace Board on October 23, 2016, that, as\nof such date and based upon and subject to the factors and assumptions set forth in the opinion, the merger consideration to\nbe paid to the holders (other than Rockwell Collins and its affiliates) of B/E Aerospace common stock in the merger was\nfair, from a financial point of view, to such stockholders, as more fully described below under the caption "\xe2\x80\x94Opinions of\nB/E Aerospace\'s Financial Advisors" beginning on page 82. The full text of the written opinions of Citigroup and Goldman\nSachs, each dated October 23, 2016, which set\n\n71\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n81/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n82/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nforth, among other things, the assumptions made, matters considered and qualifications and limitations on the reviews\nundertaken in rendering their opinions, are attached as Annex C and Annex D, respectively, to this joint proxy\nstatement/prospectus, and are incorporated herein by reference;\n\nThe current environment in the aerospace industry, including the trends in consolidation and increased competition, and the\npotential financial impact of such trends on B/E Aerospace in the future; \n\nThe merger will be subject to the approval of B/E Aerospace\'s stockholders and that, in this regard, B/E Aerospace\'s\ndirectors and executive officers do not own a sufficient interest in B/E Aerospace common stock, in the aggregate, to\ninfluence substantially the outcome of such stockholder vote; and \n\nB/E Aerospace stockholders who do not vote to adopt the merger agreement and approve the merger and who follow\ncertain prescribed procedures are entitled to appraisal rights under Delaware law.\n\n        The B/E Aerospace Board also specifically considered the terms of the merger agreement, including the following:\n\nThe lack of a financing condition to Rockwell Collins\' obligation to complete the merger; \n\nThe termination fee payable by Rockwell Collins to B/E Aerospace if Rockwell Collins terminates the merger agreement to\npursue a competing transaction with a third party or in certain other circumstances; \n\nThat if B/E Aerospace were to receive a takeover proposal from a third party that provided superior value to B/E Aerospace\nand its stockholders, B/E Aerospace and the B/E Aerospace Board would be able, under certain circumstances described in\nthe merger agreement, to consider such superior proposal and the B/E Aerospace Board may change its recommendation\nthat B/E Aerospace stockholders vote in favor of the Merger proposal and/or terminate the merger agreement; \n\nB/E Aerospace\'s ability, under circumstances described in the merger agreement, to provide information to and engage in\ndiscussions or negotiations with a third party that makes an unsolicited bona fide written takeover proposal; \n\nThe ability of the B/E Aerospace Board, subject to certain conditions, to change its recommendation supporting the merger\nin response to an intervening event if the B/E Aerospace Board determines that failure to take such action would be\ninconsistent with its fiduciary duties; and \n\nThe customary nature of B/E Aerospace\'s other representations, warranties and covenants in the merger agreement.\n\n        The B/E Aerospace Board weighed the foregoing against a number of potentially negative factors, including:\n\nThe fact that the value of the merger consideration payable to B/E Aerospace stockholders could decrease in the event that\nthe price of Rockwell Collins common stock decreases more than 7.5% prior to completion of the merger; \n\nThe restrictions on the conduct of B/E Aerospace\'s business during the period between the execution of the merger\nagreement and the completion of the merger;\n\n72\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n83/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nThe costs associated with the completion of the merger and the realization of the benefits expected to be obtained in\nconnection with the merger, including management\'s time and energy and potential opportunity cost; \n\nThe risk that the merger may not be completed and the challenges in absorbing the effect of any failure to complete the\nmerger, including stockholder and market reactions, as well as the diversion of management\'s attention from ongoing\nbusiness concerns; \n\nThe risk that regulatory agencies may not approve the merger or may impose terms and conditions on their approvals that\nadversely affect the business and financial results of the combined company as more fully described under "\xe2\x80\x94Regulatory\nApprovals Required for the Merger" beginning on page 116; \n\nThe merger agreement does not preclude a third party from making an unsolicited proposal for a competing transaction\nwith Rockwell Collins and that, under certain circumstances more fully described in the sections "The Merger Agreement\n\xe2\x80\x94Covenants and Agreements\xe2\x80\x94No Solicitation" beginning on page 141 and "The Merger Agreement\xe2\x80\x94Covenants and\nAgreements\xe2\x80\x94Adverse Recommendation Change and Termination" beginning on page 142, Rockwell Collins may furnish\nnon-public information to and enter into discussions with such third party regarding the competing transaction and the\nRockwell Collins Board may withdraw or modify its recommendations to Rockwell Collins stockholders regarding the\nmerger and may terminate the merger agreement to enter into a competing transaction under certain circumstances; \n\nThe termination fee payable by B/E Aerospace to Rockwell Collins if B/E Aerospace terminates the merger agreement to\npursue a competing transaction with a third party or in certain other circumstances; \n\nThe risk that the B/E Aerospace stockholders do not approve the Merger proposal; \n\nThe risk that B/E Aerospace will be required to reimburse Rockwell Collins for its expenses up to $85 million if the merger\nagreement is terminated by either party because the B/E Aerospace stockholders do not approve the Merger proposal; \n\nThe challenges inherent in the combination of two businesses of the size and complexity of B/E Aerospace and Rockwell\nCollins; \n\nThe risk of litigation related to the transaction; \n\nThe risk of not being able to realize all of the anticipated cost savings and operational synergies between B/E Aerospace\nand Rockwell Collins and the risk that other anticipated benefits might not be realized; and \n\nThe risks of the type and nature described under "Risk Factors," beginning on page 46 and the matters described under\n"Cautionary Note Regarding Forward-Looking Statements" beginning on page 44.\n\n        This discussion of the information and factors considered by the B/E Aerospace Board in reaching its conclusions and\nrecommendation includes the principal factors considered by the B/E Aerospace Board, but is not intended to be exhaustive and may not\ninclude all of the factors considered by the B/E Aerospace Board. In view of the wide variety of factors considered in connection with its\nevaluation of the merger and the other transactions contemplated by the merger agreement, and the complexity of these matters, the\nB/E Aerospace Board did not find it useful and did not attempt to quantify, rank or assign any relative or specific weights to the various\nfactors that it considered in reaching its determination to approve the merger and the other transactions contemplated by the merger\nagreement, and to make its recommendation to B/E Aerospace stockholders. Rather, the\n\n73\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n84/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nB/E Aerospace Board viewed its decisions as being based on the totality of the information presented to it and the factors it considered,\nincluding its discussions with, and questioning of, members of B/E Aerospace\'s management and B/E Aerospace\'s advisors, as well as its\nexperience and history. In addition, individual members of the B/E Aerospace Board may have assigned different weights to different\nfactors.\n\n        Certain of B/E Aerospace\'s directors and executive officers have financial interests in the merger that are different from, or in addition\nto, those of B/E Aerospace\'s stockholders generally. The B/E Aerospace Board was aware of and considered these potential interests,\namong other matters, in evaluating the merger and in making its recommendation to B/E Aerospace stockholders. For a discussion of these\ninterests, see "\xe2\x80\x94Interests of Directors and Executive Officers in the Merger" beginning on page 102.\n\n        The B/E Aerospace Board unanimously determined that the merger agreement and the transactions contemplated by the merger\nagreement were advisable and in the best interests of B/E Aerospace and its stockholders and approved the merger agreement.\nAccordingly, the B/E Aerospace Board unanimously recommends that B/E Aerospace stockholders vote "FOR" the Merger proposal at the\nB/E Aerospace special meeting.\n\nOpinion of Rockwell Collins\' Financial Advisor \n\n        Pursuant to an engagement letter dated October 6, 2016, Rockwell Collins retained J.P. Morgan as its financial advisor in connection\nwith the merger.\n\n        At the meeting of the Rockwell Collins Board on October 21, 2016, J.P. Morgan rendered its oral opinion to the Rockwell Collins\nBoard that, as of such date and based upon and subject to the factors and assumptions set forth in its opinion, the merger consideration to\nbe paid by Rockwell Collins was fair, from a financial point of view, to Rockwell Collins. J.P. Morgan has confirmed its October 21, 2016\noral opinion by delivering its written opinion to the Rockwell Collins Board, dated October 23, 2016, that, as of such date, the merger\nconsideration to be paid by Rockwell Collins was fair, from a financial point of view, to Rockwell Collins.\n\n        The full text of the written opinion of J.P. Morgan, which sets forth the assumptions made, matters considered and limits on\nthe review undertaken, is attached as Annex B to this joint proxy statement/prospectus and is incorporated herein by reference.\nThe summary of the opinion of J.P. Morgan set forth in this joint proxy statement/prospectus is qualified in its entirety by\nreference to the full text of such opinion. Rockwell Collins stockholders are urged to read the opinion in its entirety. J.P. Morgan\'s\nopinion was addressed to the Rockwell Collins Board (in its capacity as such) in connection with and for the purposes of its\nevaluation of the merger, was directed only to the fairness, from a financial point of view, to Rockwell Collins of the merger\nconsideration to be paid by Rockwell Collins and did not address any other aspect of the merger. J.P. Morgan expressed no\nopinion as to the fairness of the merger consideration to the holders of any class of securities, creditors or other constituencies of\nRockwell Collins or as to the underlying decision by Rockwell Collins to engage in the merger. The issuance of J.P. Morgan\'s\nopinion was approved by a fairness committee of J.P. Morgan. The opinion does not constitute a recommendation to any\nstockholder of Rockwell Collins as to how such stockholder should vote with respect to the merger or any other matter.\n\n        In arriving at its opinion, J.P. Morgan, among other things:\n\nreviewed a draft dated October 23, 2016 of the merger agreement; \n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nreviewed certain publicly available business and financial information concerning B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins\nand the industries in which they operate;\n\n74\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n85/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\ncompared the proposed financial terms of the merger with the publicly available financial terms of certain transactions\ninvolving companies J.P. Morgan deemed relevant and the consideration received for such companies; \n\ncompared the financial and operating performance of B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins with publicly available\ninformation concerning certain other companies J.P. Morgan deemed relevant and reviewed the current and historical\nmarket prices of B/E Aerospace common stock and Rockwell Collins common stock and certain publicly traded securities\nof such other companies; \n\nreviewed certain internal financial analyses and forecasts prepared by the managements of B/E Aerospace and Rockwell\nCollins relating to their respective businesses and by Rockwell Collins relating to B/E Aerospace\'s business, as well as the\nestimated amount and timing of the cost savings and related expenses and synergies expected to result from the merger,\nwhich are referred to as the Synergies; and \n\nperformed such other financial studies and analyses and considered such other information as J.P. Morgan deemed\nappropriate for the purposes of its opinion.\n\n        In addition, J.P. Morgan held discussions with certain members of the management of B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins with\nrespect to certain aspects of the merger, the past and current business operations of B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins, the financial\ncondition and future prospects and operations of B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins, the effects of the merger on the financial condition\nand future prospects of Rockwell Collins, and certain other matters J.P. Morgan believed necessary or appropriate to its inquiry.\n\n        In giving its opinion, J.P. Morgan relied upon and assumed the accuracy and completeness of all information that was publicly\navailable or was furnished to or discussed with J.P. Morgan by B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins or otherwise reviewed by or for J.P.\nMorgan, and J.P. Morgan did not independently verify (and did not assume responsibility or liability for independently verifying) any such\ninformation or its accuracy or completeness. J.P. Morgan did not conduct and was not provided with any valuation or appraisal of any\nassets or liabilities, nor did J.P. Morgan evaluate the solvency of B/E Aerospace or Rockwell Collins under any applicable laws relating to\nbankruptcy, insolvency or similar matters. In relying on financial analyses and forecasts provided to J.P. Morgan or derived therefrom,\nincluding the Synergies, J.P. Morgan assumed that they were reasonably prepared based on assumptions reflecting the best currently\navailable estimates and judgments by management as to the expected future results of operations and financial condition of B/E Aerospace\nand Rockwell Collins to which such analyses or forecasts relate. J.P. Morgan expressed no view as to such analyses or forecasts (including\nthe Synergies) or the assumptions on which they were based. J.P. Morgan also assumed that the merger and the other transactions\ncontemplated by the merger agreement will have the tax consequences described in discussions with, and materials furnished to J.P.\nMorgan by, representatives of Rockwell Collins, and will be consummated as described in the merger agreement, and that the definitive\nmerger agreement would not differ in any material respects from the draft thereof furnished to J.P. Morgan. J.P. Morgan also assumed that\nthe representations and warranties made by Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace in the merger agreement and the related agreements were\nand will be true and correct in all respects material to J.P. Morgan\'s analysis. J.P. Morgan is not a legal, regulatory or tax expert and relied\non the assessments made by advisors to Rockwell Collins with respect to such issues. J.P. Morgan further assumed that all material\ngovernmental, regulatory or other consents and approvals necessary for the consummation of the merger will be obtained without any\nadverse effect on B/E Aerospace or Rockwell Collins or on the contemplated benefits of the merger.\n\n        J.P. Morgan\'s opinion was necessarily based on economic, market and other conditions as in effect on, and the information made\navailable to J.P. Morgan as of, the date of such opinion. J.P. Morgan\'s opinion noted that subsequent developments may affect J.P.\nMorgan\'s opinion, and that J.P. Morgan does not have any obligation to update, revise, or reaffirm such opinion. J.P. Morgan\'s opinion is\n\n75\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n86/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nlimited to the fairness, from a financial point of view, of the merger consideration to be paid by Rockwell Collins, and J.P. Morgan has\nexpressed no opinion as to the fairness of any merger consideration to the holders of any class of securities, creditors or other\nconstituencies of Rockwell Collins or as to the underlying decision by Rockwell Collins to engage in the merger. Furthermore, J.P. Morgan\nexpressed no opinion with respect to the amount or nature of any compensation to any officers, directors, or employees of any party to the\nmerger, or any class of such persons relative to the merger consideration to be paid by Rockwell Collins or with respect to the fairness of\nany such compensation. J.P. Morgan expressed no opinion as to the price at which Rockwell Collins common stock or B/E Aerospace\ncommon stock will trade at any future time.\n\n        The terms of the merger agreement, including the exchange ratio, were determined through arm\'s length negotiations between\nRockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace, and the decision to enter into the merger agreement was solely that of the Rockwell Collins Board\nand the B/E Aerospace board of directors. J.P. Morgan\'s opinion and financial analyses constituted only one of the many factors considered\nby the Rockwell Collins Board in its evaluation of the merger and should not be viewed as determinative of the views of the Rockwell\nCollins Board or management with respect to the merger or the merger consideration.\n\n        In accordance with customary investment banking practice, J.P. Morgan employed generally accepted valuation methodology in\nrendering its opinion to the Rockwell Collins Board and contained in the presentation delivered to the Rockwell Collins Board in\nconnection with the rendering of such opinion and does not purport to be a complete description of the analyses or data presented by\nJ.P. Morgan. Some of the summaries of the financial analyses include information presented in tabular format. The tables are not intended\nto stand alone, and in order to more fully understand the financial analyses used by J.P. Morgan, the tables must be read together with the\nfull text of each summary. Considering the data set forth below without considering the full narrative description of the financial analyses,\nincluding the methodologies and assumptions underlying the analyses, could create a misleading or incomplete view of J.P. Morgan\'s\nanalyses.\n\n        Using publicly available information, J.P. Morgan compared selected financial and market data of B/E Aerospace with similar data\nfor selected publicly traded companies that J.P. Morgan deemed relevant for purposes of analysis. Morgan selected a multiple reference\nrange of 10.0x - 14.0x for TV/ LTM EBITDA and a multiple reference range of 20.0x - 30.0x for LTM P/E.\n\n        After applying such ranges to figures provided by B/E Aerospace for LTM EBITDA and LTM EPS, respectively, for B/E Aerospace\nfor the 12-month period ended September 30, 2016, the analysis indicated the following implied per share equity value ranges for B/E\nAerospace common stock, rounded to the nearest $0.25:\n\n \n \nTV/ LTM EBITDA\nLTM P/E\n\nImplied Per Share\nEquity Value\nRange of\nB/E Aerospace\nCommon Stock\n \n \n \n  $ 40.50  $ 64.25 \n  $ 65.75  $ 98.75 \n\nHigh\n\nLow\n\n \n \n\n        The ranges of implied per share equity values for B/E Aerospace common stock were compared to the closing price of $50.65 per\nshare of B/E Aerospace common stock on October 20, 2016, and the offer price of $62.00 per share of B/E Aerospace common stock.\n\nDiscounted Cash Flow Analysis\n\n        J.P. Morgan conducted a discounted cash flow analysis for the purpose of determining the fully diluted equity value per share for B/E\nAerospace common stock.\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n89/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n78\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n90/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\n        J.P. Morgan calculated the unlevered free cash flows that B/E Aerospace is expected to generate (i) during the fourth quarter of\ncalendar year 2016 through calendar year 2021 based upon the adjusted B/E Aerospace forecast and (ii) during calendar years 2022\nthrough 2026 based upon extrapolations from the adjusted B/E Aerospace forecast reviewed and approved by Rockwell Collins\nmanagement. J.P. Morgan calculated a range of terminal values for B/E Aerospace at the end of the projection period by applying terminal\ngrowth rates, based on J.P. Morgan\'s professional judgment given the nature of B/E Aerospace, its business and its industry, ranging from\n2.5% to 3.5%. The unlevered free cash flows and the range of terminal values were then discounted to present values using discount rates\nranging from 7.5% to 8.5%, which were chosen by J.P. Morgan based upon an analysis of the weighted average cost of capital of B/E\nAerospace. The present values of the unlevered free cash flows and the range of terminal values were then adjusted for B/E Aerospace\'s\nnet debt and divided by the fully diluted shares outstanding of B/E Aerospace. The discounted cash flow analysis indicated an implied per\nshare equity value range for B/E Aerospace common stock, rounded to the nearest $0.25, of $53.50 to $78.25.\n\n        The range of implied per share equity values for B/E Aerospace common stock was compared to the closing price of $50.65 per share\nof B/E Aerospace common stock on October 20, 2016, and the offer price of $62.00 per share of B/E Aerospace common stock.\n\nRockwell Collins Financial Analysis\n\nDiscounted Cash Flow Analysis\n\n        J.P. Morgan conducted a discounted cash flow analysis for the purpose of determining the fully diluted equity value per share for\nRockwell Collins common stock.\n\n        J.P. Morgan calculated the unlevered free cash flows that Rockwell Collins is expected to generate (i) during fiscal years 2017\nthrough 2021 based upon the Rockwell Collins stand-alone management forecast and (ii) during fiscal years 2022 through 2026 based\nupon extrapolations from the Rockwell Collins stand-alone management forecast reviewed and approved by Rockwell Collins\nmanagement. J.P. Morgan calculated a range of terminal values for Rockwell Collins at the end of the projection period by applying\nterminal growth rates, based on J.P. Morgan\'s professional judgment given the nature of Rockwell Collins, its business and its industry,\nranging from 2.0% to 3.0% to the unlevered free cash flows excluding pension contributions, to which a 0% terminal growth rate was\napplied per Rockwell Collins management instruction. The unlevered free cash flows and the range of terminal values were then\ndiscounted to present values using discount rates ranging from 7.5% to 8.5%, which were chosen by J.P. Morgan based upon an analysis of\nthe weighted average cost of capital of Rockwell Collins. The present values of the unlevered free cash flows and the range of terminal\nvalues were then adjusted for Rockwell Collins\' net debt and divided by the fully diluted shares outstanding of Rockwell Collins. The\ndiscounted cash flow analysis indicated an implied per share equity value range for Rockwell Collins common stock, rounded to the\nnearest $0.25, of $98.25 to $136.75.\n\nPotential Value Creation Analysis\xe2\x80\x94Intrinsic Value Approach\n\n        J.P. Morgan prepared a value creation analysis that compared the implied equity value derived from J.P. Morgan\'s discounted cash\nflow analysis of Rockwell Collins on a standalone basis to Rockwell Collins stockholders\' pro forma ownership of the implied equity\nvalue of the combined company.\n\n        The pro forma combined company equity value was equal to: (i) Rockwell Collins\' standalone discounted cash flow value of\n$15.1 billion (calculated using a 2.5% terminal growth rate and 8.0% discount rate, representing the midpoint of the terminal growth rate\nand discount rate ranges, respectively, applied in the discounted cash flow analysis for Rockwell Collins described above), plus (ii) B/E\nAerospace\'s standalone discounted cash flow value of $6.5 billion (calculated using a 3.0% terminal growth rate and an 8.0% discount\nrate, representing the midpoint of the terminal growth rate\n\n79\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n91/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nand discount rate ranges, respectively, applied in the discounted cash flow analysis for B/E Aerospace described above), plus (iii) the\ndiscounted cash flow value of Rockwell Collins management expectations of after-tax synergies totaling $1.8 billion (calculated using a\n3.0% terminal growth rate and an 8.0% discount rate representing the midpoint of the terminal growth rate and discount rate ranges,\nrespectively), less (iv) cash consideration of $3.8 billion (which includes the retirement of certain B/E Aerospace restricted stock units,\ntransaction costs and change of control expenses). J.P. Morgan then calculated the implied pro forma equity value of the combined\ncompany attributable to Rockwell Collins stockholders based on the implied equity ownership percentage of 80% by Rockwell Collins\nstockholders implied by the exchange ratio in the consideration (assuming Rockwell Collins\' closing share price as of October 20, 2016)\nand the number of Rockwell Collins diluted shares outstanding on a standalone basis (based on information as of September 30, 2016 per\nRockwell Collins management). J.P. Morgan then compared the result to the implied equity value of Rockwell Collins on a standalone\nbasis indicated by the discounted cash flow analysis of Rockwell Collins (described above) whereby the discount rates used were chosen\nby J.P. Morgan based upon an analysis of the weighted average cost of capital of Rockwell Collins. The value creation analysis indicated\nan implied pro forma equity value of $15.6 billion attributable to Rockwell Collins stockholders and implied pro forma accretion in\nimplied equity value to Rockwell Collins stockholders of 3.4% higher than the implied equity value on a standalone basis indicated by the\ndiscounted cash flow analysis of Rockwell Collins.\n\nOther Information\n\nHistorical Stock Trading\n\nEquity Research Analyst Price Targets\n\n        J.P. Morgan reviewed the historical share prices of B/E Aerospace common stock for the 52-week period ended October 20, 2016. J.P.\nMorgan noted that the low and high closing share prices during this period were $37.91 and $53.11 per share of B/E Aerospace common\nstock, respectively.\n\n        J.P. Morgan reviewed the most recent publicly available research analyst price targets for B/E Aerospace common stock prepared and\npublished by selected equity research analysts. J.P. Morgan noted that the range of such price targets as of October 20, 2016 was $48.00 to\n$66.00 per share of B/E Aerospace common stock.\n\n        J.P. Morgan noted that the historical stock trading and equity research analyst price targets analyses are not valuation methodologies\nbut were presented merely for reference only.\n\nMiscellaneous\n\n        The foregoing summary of financial analyses does not purport to be a complete description of the analyses or data presented by J.P.\nMorgan. The preparation of a fairness opinion is a complex process and is not necessarily susceptible to partial analysis or summary\ndescription. J.P. Morgan believes that the foregoing summary and its analyses must be considered as a whole and that selecting portions of\nthe foregoing summary and these analyses, without considering all of its analyses as a whole, could create an incomplete view of the\nprocesses underlying the analyses and its opinion. As a result, the ranges of valuations resulting from any particular analysis or\ncombination of analyses described above were merely utilized to create points of reference for analytical purposes and should not be taken\nto be the view of J.P. Morgan with respect to the actual value of Rockwell Collins or B/E Aerospace. The order of analyses described does\nnot represent the relative importance or weight given to those analyses by J.P. Morgan. In arriving at its opinion, J.P. Morgan did not\nattribute any particular weight to any analyses or factors considered by it and did not form an opinion as to whether any individual analysis\nor factor (positive or negative), considered in isolation, supported or failed to support its opinion. Rather, J.P. Morgan considered the\ntotality of the factors and analyses performed in determining its opinion.\n\n80\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n92/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\n        Analyses based upon forecasts of future results are inherently uncertain, as they are subject to numerous factors or events beyond the\ncontrol of the parties and their advisors. Accordingly, forecasts and analyses used or made by J.P. Morgan are not necessarily indicative of\nactual future results, which may be significantly more or less favorable than suggested by those analyses. Moreover, J.P. Morgan\'s analyses\nare not and do not purport to be appraisals or otherwise reflective of the prices at which businesses actually could be acquired or sold.\nNone of the selected companies reviewed as described in the above summary is identical to B/E Aerospace, and none of the selected\ntransactions reviewed was identical to the merger. However, the companies selected were chosen because they are publicly traded\ncompanies with operations and businesses that, for purposes of J.P. Morgan\'s analysis, may be considered similar to those of B/E\nAerospace. The transactions selected were similarly chosen because their participants, size and other factors, for purposes of J.P. Morgan\'s\nanalysis, may be considered similar to the merger. The analyses necessarily involve complex considerations and judgments concerning\ndifferences in financial and operational characteristics of the companies involved and other factors that could affect the companies\ncompared to B/E Aerospace and the transactions compared to the merger.\n\n        As a part of its investment banking business, J.P. Morgan and its affiliates are continually engaged in the valuation of businesses and\ntheir securities in connection with mergers and acquisitions, investments for passive and control purposes, negotiated underwritings,\nsecondary distributions of listed and unlisted securities, private placements, and valuations for corporate and other purposes. J.P. Morgan\nwas selected to advise Rockwell Collins with respect to the merger on the basis of, among other things, such experience and its\nqualifications and reputation in connection with such matters and its familiarity with Rockwell Collins, B/E Aerospace and the industries\nin which they operate.\n\n        For services rendered in connection with the merger, Rockwell Collins agreed to pay J.P. Morgan a transaction fee of $27.5 million,\nof which $5.0 million became payable by Rockwell Collins at the time J.P. Morgan delivered its opinion, and the balance of which is\npayable upon the closing of the merger. Rockwell Collins has also agreed to pay J.P. Morgan 10% of any break-up fee received by\nRockwell Collins following or in connection with the termination, abandonment or failure of the merger, provided that such fee will not\nexceed the amount that would have been payable to J.P. Morgan if the merger had been consummated. In addition, Rockwell Collins has\nagreed to reimburse J.P. Morgan for certain of its expenses incurred in connection with its services, including the fees and expenses of\ncounsel, and will indemnify J.P. Morgan against certain liabilities arising out of J.P. Morgan\'s engagement. During the two years preceding\nthe date of J.P. Morgan\'s opinion, J.P. Morgan and its affiliates have had commercial or investment banking relationships with Rockwell\nCollins and B/E Aerospace for which J.P. Morgan and such affiliates have received customary compensation. Such services during such\nperiod have included acting as joint bookrunner and joint lead arranger on Rockwell Collins\' revolving credit facility in February 2016; as\njoint lead arranger and joint bookrunner on the B/E Aerospace credit facilities in December 2014 and in May 2016; as lead arranger and\nlead-left bookrunner on credit facilities of KLX; as lead bookrunner on an offering of debt securities of KLX in November 2014; and as\nfinancial advisor to B/E Aerospace in connection with the KLX spin-off in December 2014. J.P. Morgan and its affiliates also provided\nasset management services to Rockwell Collins during such period. In addition, J.P. Morgan\'s commercial banking affiliate is an agent\nbank and a lender under outstanding credit facilities of Rockwell Collins, B/E Aerospace and KLX, for which it receives customary\ncompensation or other financial benefits. J.P. Morgan and its affiliates have committed to provide financing to Rockwell Collins in\nconnection with the merger for customary compensation, which is expected to be approximately $20 million in fees payable to J.P. Morgan\nin connection with such financing. During the two-year period preceding delivery of its opinion, the aggregate fees received by J.P.\nMorgan from Rockwell Collins were approximately $3 million and from B/E Aerospace were approximately $10 million. In the ordinary\ncourse of their businesses, J.P. Morgan and its affiliates may actively trade the debt and equity securities or financial instruments\n(including derivatives, bank loans or other obligations) of Rockwell Collins or B/E Aerospace for their own\n\n81\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n93/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\naccounts or for the accounts of customers and, accordingly, they may at any time hold long or short positions in such securities.\n\nOpinions of B/E Aerospace\'s Financial Advisors \n\nOpinion of Citigroup Global Markets Inc.\n\n        On October 23, 2016, Citigroup delivered to the B/E Aerospace Board a written opinion dated October 23, 2016, to the effect that, as\nof such date and based on and subject to the assumptions made, procedures followed, matters considered and limitations and qualifications\nset forth in the written opinion, the merger consideration to be received by the holders of outstanding shares of common stock of\nB/E Aerospace (other than excluded holders) in the merger was fair, from a financial point of view, to such holders.\n\n        The full text of Citigroup\'s written opinion, dated October 23, 2016, which sets forth, among other things, the assumptions\nmade, procedures followed, matters considered and limitations and qualifications on the review undertaken by Citigroup in\nrendering its opinion, is attached to this joint proxy statement/prospectus as Annex C and is incorporated into this joint proxy\nstatement/prospectus by reference in its entirety. The summary of Citigroup\'s opinion set forth below is qualified in its entirety by\nreference to the full text of the opinion. We urge you to read the opinion carefully and in its entirety. Citigroup\'s opinion, the\nissuance of which was authorized by Citigroup\'s fairness opinion committee, was provided to the B/E Aerospace Board (in its\ncapacity as such) in connection with its evaluation of the merger and was limited to the fairness, from a financial point of view, as\nof the date of the opinion, to the holders of outstanding shares of common stock of B/E Aerospace (other than excluded holders) of\nthe merger consideration to be received by such holders in the merger. Citigroup\'s opinion does not address any other aspects or\nimplications of the merger and does not constitute a recommendation to any stockholder as to how such stockholder should vote or\nact on any matters relating to the merger or otherwise. Citigroup\'s opinion does not address the underlying business decision of\nB/E Aerospace to effect the merger, the relative merits of the merger as compared to any alternative business strategies that might\nexist for B/E Aerospace or the effect of any other transaction in which B/E Aerospace might engage. The following is a summary of\nCitigroup\'s opinion.\n\n        In arriving at its opinion, Citigroup, among other things:\n\nreviewed the merger agreement; \n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nheld discussions with certain senior officers, directors and other representatives and advisors of B/E Aerospace and certain\nsenior officers and other representatives and advisors of Rockwell Collins concerning the businesses, operations and\nprospects of B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins; \n\nexamined certain publicly available business and financial information relating to B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins; \n\nexamined certain financial forecasts and other information and data relating to B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins which\nwere provided to or discussed with Citigroup by the respective managements of B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins,\nincluding information relating to the potential strategic implications and operational benefits (including the amount, timing\nand achievability thereof) anticipated by the managements of B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins to result from the\nmerger; \n\nreviewed the financial terms of the merger as set forth in the merger agreement in relation to, among other things: current\nand historical market prices and trading volumes of B/E Aerospace common stock and Rockwell Collins common stock,\nthe historical and projected earnings and other operating data of B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins and the capitalization\nand financial condition of B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins;\n\n82\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n94/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nconsidered, to the extent publicly available, the financial terms of certain other transactions which Citigroup considered\nrelevant in evaluating the merger; \n\nanalyzed certain financial, stock market and other publicly available information relating to the businesses of other\ncompanies whose operations Citigroup considered relevant in evaluating those of B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins; \n\nevaluated certain potential pro forma financial effects of the merger on Rockwell Collins; and \n\nconducted such other analyses and examinations and considered such other information and financial, economic and\nmarket criteria as Citigroup deemed appropriate in arriving at its opinion.\n\n        In rendering its opinion, Citigroup assumed and relied, without independent verification, upon the accuracy and completeness of all\nfinancial and other information and data publicly available or provided to or otherwise reviewed by or discussed with Citigroup and upon\nthe assurances of the managements of B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins that they were not aware of any relevant information that was\nomitted or that remained undisclosed to Citigroup. With respect to financial forecasts and other information and data provided to or\notherwise reviewed by or discussed with Citigroup, Citigroup was advised by the respective managements of B/E Aerospace and Rockwell\nCollins that such forecasts and other information and data were reasonably prepared on bases reflecting the best currently available\nestimates and judgments of the managements of B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins as to the future financial performance of\nB/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins, the potential strategic implications and operational benefits anticipated to result from the merger and\nthe other matters covered thereby, and assumed, with B/E Aerospace\'s consent, that the financial results (including the potential strategic\nimplications and operational benefits anticipated to result from the merger) reflected in such forecasts and other information and data will\nbe realized in the amounts and at the times projected.\n\n        Citigroup also assumed, with B/E Aerospace\'s consent, that the merger will be consummated in accordance with its terms, without\nwaiver, modification or amendment of any material term, condition or agreement and that, in the course of obtaining the necessary\nregulatory or third party approvals, consents and releases for the merger, no delay, limitation, restriction or condition will be imposed that\nwould have an adverse effect on B/E Aerospace, Rockwell Collins or the contemplated benefits of the merger. Citigroup\'s opinion related\nto the relative values of B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins. Citigroup did not express any opinion as to what the value of Rockwell\nCollins common stock actually will be when issued pursuant to the merger or the price at which shares of Rockwell Collins common stock\nwill trade at any time. Citigroup did not make and it was not provided with an independent evaluation or appraisal of the assets or\nliabilities (contingent or otherwise) of B/E Aerospace or Rockwell Collins and Citigroup did not make any physical inspection of the\nproperties or assets of B/E Aerospace or Rockwell Collins. Citigroup\'s opinion did not address the underlying business decision of\nB/E Aerospace to effect the merger, the relative merits of the merger as compared to any alternative business strategies that might exist for\nB/E Aerospace or the effect of any other transaction in which B/E Aerospace might engage. Citigroup also expressed no view as to, and\nCitigroup\'s opinion did not address, the fairness (financial or otherwise) of the amount or nature or any other aspect of any compensation\nto any officers, directors or employees of any parties to the merger, or any class of such persons, relative to the merger consideration or\notherwise. Citigroup\'s opinion was necessarily based upon information available to it, and financial, stock market and other conditions and\ncircumstances existing, as of October 20, 2016, except as otherwise noted.\n\n        For a summary of the material financial analyses presented by Citigroup, together with Goldman Sachs, to the B/E Aerospace Board\nin connection with the delivery of Citigroup\'s opinion, see the section entitled "\xe2\x80\x94Financial Analyses by Financial Co-Advisors" beginning\non page 87.\n\n83\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n95/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\n        Under the terms of Citigroup\'s engagement, B/E Aerospace has agreed to pay Citigroup, for its financial advisory services in\nconnection with the merger, an aggregate fee of approximately $27.3 million, $5 million of which was payable upon delivery by Citigroup\nof its opinion and the remainder of which is payable upon completion of the merger. Subject to certain limitations, B/E Aerospace also has\nagreed to reimburse Citigroup, subject to certain conditions, for reasonable and documented travel and other reasonable and documented\nout-of-pocket expenses incurred by Citigroup in performing its services, including reasonable and documented fees and expenses of its\nlegal counsel, and to indemnify Citigroup and related persons against certain liabilities, including liabilities under the federal securities\nlaws, arising out of its engagement.\n\n        Citigroup and its affiliates in the past have provided, and currently provide, services to B/E Aerospace unrelated to the merger, for\nwhich services Citigroup and such affiliates have received and expect to receive compensation, including, without limitation, during the\ntwo-year period prior to October 23, 2016, having acted or acting (i) as financial advisor to B/E Aerospace in connection with\nB/E Aerospace\'s spin-off of KLX Inc. in December 2014, and (ii) as lender, syndication agent, joint lead arranger and joint book-runner in\nconnection with a term loan and revolving credit facility of B/E Aerospace. During the two year period ended October 23, 2016, Citigroup\nhas received compensation for financial advisory and/or underwriting services provided by its Investment Banking Division directly to\nB/E Aerospace and/or its affiliates of approximately $18,700,000. Citigroup and its affiliates in the past have also provided, and currently\nprovide, services to Rockwell Collins unrelated to the merger, for which services Citigroup and such affiliates have received and expect to\nreceive compensation, including, without limitation, during the two-year period prior to October 23, 2016, acting as lender, syndication\nagent, joint lead arranger and joint book-runner in connection with two revolving credit facilities of Rockwell Collins, as well as acting as\nlender in connection with certain committed corporate credit card facilities of Rockwell Collins. During the two-year period ended\nOctober 23, 2016, Citigroup has received compensation for financial advisory and/or underwriting services provided by its Investment\nBanking Division directly to Rockwell Collins and/or to its affiliates of approximately $50,000. In the ordinary course of business,\nCitigroup and its affiliates may actively trade or hold the securities of B/E Aerospace and Rockwell Collins for its own account or for the\naccount of its customers and, accordingly, may at any time hold a long or short position in such securities. In addition, Citigroup and its\naffiliates (including Citigroup Inc. and its affiliates) may maintain relationships with B/E Aerospace, Rockwell Collins and their respective\naffiliates.\n\n        In response to a request by Rockwell Collins, made after the execution of the merger agreement, that Citigroup participate in the\nfinancing of the merger by Rockwell Collins, the B/E Aerospace Board granted Citigroup permission to participate in such financing.\nPursuant to such request and consent, Citigroup is now participating in such financing, including as a joint lead arranger and lender with\nrespect to certain credit facilities, and Citigroup is now actively exploring participating, and may participate as an active bookrunner with\nrespect to capital markets offerings.\n\n        The B/E Aerospace Board selected Citigroup to act as one of its financial advisors in connection with the merger based on Citigroup\'s\nreputation and experience. Citigroup is an internationally recognized investment banking firm which regularly engages in the valuation of\nbusinesses and their securities in connection with mergers and acquisitions, negotiated underwritings, competitive bids, secondary\ndistributions of listed and unlisted securities, private placements and valuations for corporate and other purposes.\n\nOpinion of Goldman, Sachs & Co.\n\n        On October 23, 2016, Goldman Sachs delivered to the B/E Aerospace Board a written opinion dated October 23, 2016, to the effect\nthat, as of such date and based upon and subject to the factors and assumptions set forth therein, the merger consideration to be paid to the\nholders (other than\n\n84\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n96/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nRockwell Collins and its affiliates) of outstanding shares of common stock of B/E Aerospace pursuant to the merger agreement was fair\nfrom a financial point of view to such holders.\n\n        The full text of the written opinion of Goldman Sachs, dated October 23, 2016, which sets forth assumptions made,\nprocedures followed, matters considered and limitations on the review undertaken in connection with the opinion, is attached as\nAnnex D. Goldman Sachs provided its opinion for the information and assistance of the B/E Aerospace Board in connection with\nits consideration of the merger. The Goldman Sachs opinion is not a recommendation as to how any holder of B/E Aerospace\'s\ncommon stock should vote with respect to the merger or any other matter.\n\n        In connection with rendering the opinion described above and performing its related financial analyses, Goldman Sachs reviewed,\namong other things:\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nthe merger agreement;
