Lieberherr and Patch, termination will occur automatically upon consummation\nof the merger.\n\nDirector and Officer Indemnification \n\nAccounting Treatment \n\n        Under the merger agreement, certain indemnification and insurance rights exist in favor of B/E Aerospace and its subsidiaries\' current\nand former directors and officers. See "\xe2\x80\x94Interests of Directors and Executive Officers in the Merger\xe2\x80\x94Indemnification and Insurance"\nbeginning on page 113 for information about these rights.\n\n        Rockwell Collins prepares its financial statements in accordance with GAAP. The transaction will be accounted for by applying the\nacquisition method in accordance with Accounting Standards Codification 805, Business Combinations, or ASC 805, which requires the\ndetermination of the acquirer, the acquisition date, the fair value of assets and liabilities of the acquiree and the measurement of\n\n115\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n127/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\ngoodwill. The accounting guidance provides that in identifying the acquiring entity in a combination effected through an exchange of\nequity interests, all pertinent facts and circumstances must be considered, including the relative voting rights of the stockholders of the\nconstituent companies in the combined entity, the composition of the board of directors and senior management of the surviving\ncorporation, the relative size of each company and the terms of the exchange of equity securities in the business combination, including\npayment of any premium.\n\n        Based on the fact that current Rockwell Collins Board members will represent a majority of the directors of the Rockwell Collins\nBoard immediately following completion of the transaction, Rockwell Collins stockholders will own approximately 80.8% of the stock of\nthe surviving corporation with B/E Aerospace stockholders receiving a premium (as of the date preceding the transaction announcement)\nover the fair market value of their shares on such date, as well as other terms of the transaction, Rockwell Collins is considered to be the\nacquirer of B/E Aerospace for accounting purposes.\n\n        Accordingly, Rockwell Collins will allocate the purchase price to the fair value of B/E Aerospace\'s assets and liabilities at the\nacquisition date. To the extent the net fair value of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed is less than the purchase price, goodwill will\nbe recognized for the difference. Currently, the preliminary purchase price allocation indicates that goodwill will be recognized because\nthe preliminary net fair value of the assets to be acquired and liabilities to be assumed is less than the preliminary purchase price.\n\n        All unaudited pro forma condensed combined consolidated financial statements contained in this joint proxy statement/prospectus\nwere prepared using the acquisition method of accounting. The final allocation of the purchase price will be determined after the\ntransaction is completed and after completion of an analysis to determine the estimated net fair value of B/E Aerospace\'s assets and\nliabilities. Accordingly, the final acquisition accounting adjustments may be materially different from the unaudited pro forma\nadjustments. Any decrease in the estimated net fair value of the assets and liabilities of B/E Aerospace as compared to the unaudited pro\nforma information included in this joint proxy statement/prospectus will have the effect of increasing the goodwill recognized related to\nthe transaction.\n\nRegulatory Approvals Required for the Merger \n\n        To complete the merger, Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace must obtain approvals or consents from, or make filings with, a\nnumber of United States federal, state and foreign antitrust regulators. We describe below the material United States federal, state and\nforeign approvals. Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace are not currently aware of any other material governmental consents, approvals or\nfilings that are required prior to the parties\' completion of the transaction other than those we describe below. If additional approvals,\nconsents and filings are required to complete the transaction, Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace intend to seek such consents and\napprovals and make such filings.\n\n        Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace expect to complete the transaction in the spring of 2017. Although Rockwell Collins and B/E\nAerospace believe that they will receive the required consents and approvals described below to complete the transaction, we cannot give\nany assurance as to the timing of these consents and approvals or as to Rockwell Collins\' and B/E Aerospace\'s ultimate ability to obtain\nsuch consents or approvals (or any additional consents or approvals which may otherwise become necessary) or that we will obtain such\nconsents or approvals on terms and subject to conditions satisfactory to Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace. The receipt of the regulatory\napprovals (as described hereinafter) is a condition to the obligation of each of Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace to complete the\nmerger. For more information about the receipt of regulatory approvals as a condition to closing under the merger agreement, see the\nsection entitled "The Merger Agreement\xe2\x80\x94Covenants and Agreements\xe2\x80\x94Appropriate Actions; Consents; Filings" beginning on page 139.\n\n116\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n128/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nHart-Scott-Rodino Antitrust Improvements Act\n\n        The merger is subject to the requirements of the HSR Act and the related rules and regulations, which provide that certain\ntransactions may not be completed until required information has been furnished to the DOJ and the FTC and until certain waiting periods\nhave been terminated, have expired or approval has been obtained. The HSR Act requires Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace to observe\na 30-day waiting period after the submission of their HSR filings before consummating their transaction, unless the waiting period is\nterminated early.\n\n        On November 7, 2016, each of Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace filed a Notification and Report Form under the HSR Act with\nthe DOJ and the FTC, which filings started the initial 30-day waiting period required by the HSR Act. The required 30-day waiting period\nexpired at 11:59 Eastern time on December 7, 2016.\n\nOther Regulatory Approvals\n\n        The merger is also subject to antitrust review by governmental authorities in several foreign jurisdictions in which the companies\nhave a sufficient market presence to require filings. The parties are making filings in Europe, China, the Philippines, South Korea and\nTurkey.\n\nEurope\n\nChina\n\nSouth Korea\n\n        Based on the businesses in which Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace are engaged, a merger filing with the European Commission,\nwhich is referred to as the EC, and observation of the applicable review period under the EU Merger Regulation (Council Regulation (EC)\nNo. 139/2004) is required before the merger agreement and the transactions contemplated thereby may close. The initial review period is\n25 EC working days from filing of the EU notification, and can be extended to 35 EC working days if commitments are offered by the\nparties (Phase I) or by an additional 20 EC working days at the request of Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace. The review period may be\nfurther extended for an additional 90 EC working days or for an even longer period of time for an in-depth investigation (Phase II).\n\n        Based on the businesses in which Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace are engaged, a merger notification will be made to the Anti-\nMonopoly Bureau of the Ministry of Commerce of China. Under the anti-monopoly law, the transactions may not be consummated until\nthe expiration of a 30 calendar day review period following the complete filing of a notification concerning the merger agreement and the\ntransactions contemplated thereby (Phase I). The review period may be extended for an additional 90 calendar days (Phase II) and further\nfor an additional 60 calendar days in the event of an in-depth investigation (Phase III).\n\n        Based on the businesses in which Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace are engaged, an antitrust notification is required to the Korea\nFair Trade Commission, which is referred to as the KFTC, Under the Monopoly Regulation and Fair Trade Act, the transactions may not\nbe consummated until the expiration of a 30 calendar day review period following the complete filing of a notification concerning the\nmerger agreement and the transactions contemplated thereby (Phase I). The review period may be extended for an additional 90 calendar\ndays at the KFTC\'s discretion (Phase II).\n\n117\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n129/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nPhilippines\n\nTurkey\n\n        Based on the businesses in which Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace are engaged, a merger notification must be made to the\nPhilippine Competition Commission. Under the Philippine Competition Act, the transactions may not be consummated until the expiration\nof a 30 calendar day review period following the complete filing of a notification concerning the merger agreement and the transactions\ncontemplated thereby (Phase I). The review period may be extended for an additional 60 calendar days for an in-depth investigation\n(Phase II).\n\n        Based on the businesses in which Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace are engaged, Turkish competition law requires notification of\nand approval by the Turkish Competition Authority because the merger exceeds certain thresholds. The transactions may not be\nconsummated until the expiration of a 30 calendar day review period following receipt of the complete notification (Phase I). The review\nperiod may be extended for an additional 6 months at the Authority\'s discretion (Phase II).\n\nTreatment of B/E Aerospace\'s Existing Debt; Financing\n\n        In connection with the merger, the parties intend to terminate B/E Aerospace\'s existing revolving credit facility and term loan facility.\nRockwell Collins\' obligation to complete the merger is not conditioned upon its obtaining financing. Rockwell Collins anticipates that\napproximately $3.6 billion will be required to pay the aggregate cash portion of the merger consideration to the B/E Aerospace\nstockholders. Rockwell Collins intends to fund the cash component of the merger through sources of debt financing.\n\n        For a more complete description of sources of funding for the merger, see "\xe2\x80\x94Source of Funding for the Merger" beginning on page\n123.\n\nTreatment of B/E Aerospace Stock-Based Awards \n\nTreatment of B/E Aerospace Restricted Stock Awards and RSU Awards\n\n        Upon completion of the merger, each outstanding award of B/E Aerospace restricted stock and each B/E Aerospace restricted stock\nunit award that in each case was granted prior to the date of the merger agreement will (i) become fully vested and, to the extent such\naward is subject to performance conditions, such performance conditions will be deemed satisfied at the maximum level and (ii) be\ncancelled and converted into the right to receive a lump sum cash payment per share of B/E Aerospace common stock underlying such\naward equal to the value of the per share merger consideration less any applicable withholding taxes. Upon completion of the merger,\nexcept for outstanding restricted stock unit awards granted to the executive officers of B/E Aerospace in November 2016, consistent with\npast practice, which will be cancelled and converted into a cash payment pursuant to their terms, each outstanding award of B/E Aerospace\nrestricted stock and each B/E Aerospace restricted stock unit award that in each case was granted on or following the date of the merger\nagreement will be assumed by Rockwell Collins and converted into a Rockwell Collins award of restricted stock or restricted stock unit\naward, as applicable, which will vest subject to the grantee\'s continued service with Rockwell Collins or its affiliates through each\napplicable vesting date (with any performance conditions that were applicable to the B/E Aerospace award deemed satisfied at target level\nperformance and following the closing, the converted Rockwell Collins award subject only to time-based vesting) covering a number of\nshares of Rockwell Collins common stock (rounded down to the nearest whole share) determined by multiplying the number of shares of\nB/E Aerospace that were subject to the B/E Aerospace award by a ratio of the value of the merger consideration divided by the Rockwell\nCollins stock price (with the value of the stock consideration portion of the merger consideration determined by multiplying the number of\nsuch shares of Rockwell Collins common stock by the Rockwell Collins stock price).\n\n118\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n130/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nTreatment of B/E Aerospace Stock Units\n\n        Each stock unit credited to the account of any current or former director under the B/E Aerospace Amended and Restated Non-\nEmployee Directors Stock and Deferred Compensation Plan that is outstanding immediately prior to the effective time of the merger,\nwhich is referred to as the effective time, will be converted into the right to receive the merger consideration.\n\n        For a more complete description of the treatment of outstanding restricted stock unit awards granted to the executive officers of B/E\nAerospace in November 2016, see "\xe2\x80\x94Interests of Directors and Executive Officers in the Merger" beginning on page 102.\n\n        Any applicable withholding taxes resulting from this treatment will be satisfied by reducing the amount of cash, if any, that would\notherwise be provided to holders of such awards. If no cash is to be provided to a holder of such an award or if the amount of cash that\nwould otherwise be provided to a holder of such awards is not sufficient to cover the applicable withholding taxes, then the number of\nshares of Rockwell Collins common stock that would otherwise be provided to the holder in accordance with the terms described above\nwill be reduced to the extent necessary to cover the shortfall.\n\nAppraisal Rights \n\nRockwell Collins Stockholders Appraisal Rights\n\nB/E Aerospace Stockholders Appraisal Rights\n\n        Under Delaware law, Rockwell Collins stockholders will not be entitled to any appraisal rights in connection with the merger or any\nother transactions described in this joint proxy statement/prospectus.\n\n        Record holders of B/E Aerospace common stock who comply with the procedures summarized below will be entitled to appraisal\nrights if the merger is completed. Under Section 262 of the General Corporation Law, which is referred to as Section 262, holders of shares\nof B/E Aerospace common stock with respect to which appraisal rights are properly demanded and perfected and not withdrawn or lost are\nentitled, in lieu of receiving the merger consideration, to have the "fair value" of their shares (exclusive of any element of value arising\nfrom the accomplishment or expectation of the merger) at the effective time, judicially determined and paid to them in cash by complying\nwith the provisions of Section 262. B/E Aerospace is required to send a notice to that effect to each stockholder not less than 20 days prior\nto the B/E Aerospace special meeting. This joint proxy statement/prospectus constitutes that notice to the record holders of B/E Aerospace\ncommon stock.\n\n        The following is a brief summary of Section 262, which sets forth the procedures for demanding statutory appraisal rights. This\nsummary, however, is not a complete statement of the applicable requirements, and is qualified in its entirety by reference to Section 262,\na copy of the text of which is attached to this joint proxy statement/prospectus as Annex E. If you wish to consider exercising your\nappraisal rights, you should carefully review the text of Section 262 contained in Annex E. Failure to comply timely and properly with the\nrequirements of Section 262 may result in the loss of your appraisal rights under the DGCL. The following summary does not constitute\nany legal or other advice nor does it constitute a recommendation that stockholders exercise their appraisal rights under Section 262.\n\n        Stockholders of record who desire to exercise their appraisal rights must do all of the following: (i) not vote in favor of the adoption\nof the merger agreement, (ii) deliver in the manner set forth below a written demand for appraisal of the stockholder\'s shares to the\nSecretary of B/E Aerospace before the vote on the adoption of the merger agreement at the B/E Aerospace special meeting,\n(iii) continuously hold the shares of record from the date of making the demand through completion of the merger and (iv) otherwise\ncomply with the requirements of Section 262.\n\n119\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n131/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\n        Only a holder of record of B/E Aerospace common stock is entitled to demand an appraisal of the shares registered in that holder\'s\nname. A demand for appraisal must be executed by or for the stockholder of record. The demand should set forth, fully and correctly, the\nstockholder\'s name as it appears on the certificates representing shares. If shares are owned of record in a fiduciary capacity, such as by a\ntrustee, guardian or custodian, such demand must be executed by the fiduciary. If shares are owned of record by more than one person, as\nin a joint tenancy or tenancy in common, the demand must be executed by or on behalf of all joint owners. An authorized agent, including\nan agent of two or more joint owners, may execute the demand for appraisal for a stockholder of record; however, the agent must identify\nthe record owner and expressly disclose that, in exercising the demand, the agent is acting as agent for the record owner.\n\n        A record owner, such as a broker, who holds shares as a nominee for others may exercise appraisal rights with respect to the shares\nheld for all or less than all beneficial owners of shares as to which the holder is the record owner. In that case, the written demand must set\nforth the number of shares covered by the demand. Where the number of shares is not expressly stated, the demand will be presumed to\ncover all shares outstanding in the name of the record owner.\n\n        Beneficial owners who are not record owners and who intend to exercise appraisal rights should consult with the record owner to\ndetermine the appropriate procedures for having the record holder make a demand for appraisal with respect to the beneficial owner\'s\nshares. Any holder of shares held in "street name" who desires appraisal rights with respect to those shares must take such actions as may\nbe necessary to ensure that a timely and proper demand for appraisal is made by the record owner of the shares. Shares held through\nbrokerage firms, banks and other financial institutions are frequently deposited with and held of record in the name of a nominee of a\ncentral security depository, such as Cede & Co., The Depository Trust Company\'s nominee. A demand for appraisal with respect to such\nshares must be made by or on behalf of the depository nominee and it must identify the depository nominee as the record owner. Any\nbeneficial holder of shares desiring appraisal rights with respect to such shares which are held through a brokerage firm, bank or other\nfinancial institution is responsible for ensuring that the demand for appraisal is made by the record holder.\n\n        As required by Section 262, a demand for appraisal must be in writing and must reasonably inform B/E Aerospace of the identity of\nthe record holder (which might be a nominee as described above) and of such holder\'s intention to seek appraisal of the holder\'s shares.\n\n        Stockholders of record who elect to demand appraisal of their shares must mail or deliver their written demand to: B/E\nAerospace, Inc., 1400 Corporate Center Way, Wellington, Florida 33414, Attention: Ryan M. Patch, Vice President\xe2\x80\x94Law, General\nCounsel and Secretary. The written demand for appraisal should specify the stockholder\'s name and mailing address. The written demand\nmust reasonably inform B/E Aerospace that the stockholder intends thereby to demand an appraisal of his, her or its shares. The written\ndemand must be received by B/E Aerospace prior to the vote on the Merger proposal at the B/E Aerospace special meeting. Neither voting\n(in person or by proxy) against, abstaining from voting on or failing to vote on the adoption of the merger agreement will alone suffice to\nconstitute a written demand for appraisal within the meaning of Section 262. In addition, the stockholder must not vote its shares of B/E\nAerospace common stock in favor of adoption of the merger agreement. An executed proxy that does not contain voting instructions will,\nunless revoked, be voted in favor of adoption of the merger agreement and will cause the stockholder\'s right of appraisal to be lost.\nTherefore, a stockholder who desires to exercise appraisal rights should either (i) refrain from executing and submitting the enclosed proxy\ncard or (ii) vote by proxy against the adoption of the merger agreement or affirmatively register an abstention with respect thereto.\n\n        Notwithstanding a stockholder\'s compliance with the foregoing requirements, Section 262 provides that, because immediately prior to\nthe merger B/E Aerospace common stock was listed on a national securities exchange, the Delaware Chancery Court will dismiss the\nproceedings as to all holders of\n\n120\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n132/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nshares of B/E Aerospace common stock who are otherwise entitled to appraisal rights unless (i) the total number of shares of B/E\nAerospace common stock entitled to appraisal exceeds 1% of the outstanding shares of B/E Aerospace common stock or (ii) the value of\nthe consideration provided in the merger for such total number of shares of B/E Aerospace common stock entitled to appraisal exceeds\n$1 million.\n\n        Within 120 days after completion of the merger, but not thereafter, either the surviving corporation in the merger or any stockholder\nwho has timely and properly demanded appraisal of such stockholder\'s shares and who has complied with the requirements of Section 262\nand is otherwise entitled to appraisal rights, or any beneficial owner for which a demand for appraisal has been properly made by the\nrecord holder, may commence an appraisal proceeding by filing a petition in the Delaware Court of Chancery, with a copy served on the\nsurviving corporation in the case of a petition filed by a stockholder, demanding a determination of the fair value of the shares of all\nstockholders who have properly demanded appraisal. There is no present intent on the part of B/E Aerospace as the surviving corporation\nto file an appraisal petition and stockholders seeking to exercise appraisal rights should not assume that the surviving corporation will file\nsuch a petition or that the surviving corporation will initiate any negotiations with respect to the fair value of such shares. Accordingly,\nstockholders who desire to have their shares appraised should initiate any petitions necessary for the perfection of their appraisal rights\nwithin the time periods and in the manner prescribed in Section 262.\n\n        Within 120 days after completion of the merger, any stockholder who has complied with the applicable provisions of Section 262 will\nbe entitled, upon written request, to receive from the surviving corporation a statement setting forth the aggregate number of shares of B/E\nAerospace common stock not voting in favor of the merger and with respect to which demands for appraisal were received by the\nsurviving corporation and the number of holders of such shares. A person who is the beneficial owner of shares held in a voting trust or by\na nominee on behalf of such person may, in such person\'s own name, file a petition or request from the surviving corporation for the\nstatement described in the previous sentence. Such statement must be mailed within 10 days after the written request therefor has been\nreceived by the surviving corporation.\n\n        If a petition for appraisal is duly filed by a B/E Aerospace stockholder and a copy of the petition is delivered to the surviving\ncorporation, then the surviving corporation will be obligated, within 20 days after receiving service of a copy of the petition, to file with\nthe Delaware Register in Chancery a duly verified list containing the names and addresses of all stockholders who have demanded an\nappraisal of their shares of B/E Aerospace common stock and with whom agreements as to the value of their shares of B/E Aerospace\ncommon stock have not been reached. After notice to stockholders who have demanded appraisal, if such notice is ordered by the\nDelaware Court of Chancery, the Delaware Court of Chancery will conduct a hearing upon the petition and determine those stockholders\nwho have complied with Section 262 and who have become entitled to appraisal rights. The Delaware Court of Chancery may require the\nstockholders who have demanded an appraisal for their shares and who hold stock represented by certificates to submit their certificates of\nstock to the Delaware Register in Chancery for notation thereon of the pendency of the appraisal proceedings; and if any stockholder fails\nto comply with such direction, the Delaware Court of Chancery may dismiss the proceedings as to such stockholder. Where proceedings\nare not dismissed, the appraisal proceeding will be conducted, as to the shares of B/E Aerospace common stock owned by such\nstockholders, in accordance with the rules of the Delaware Court of Chancery, including any rules specifically governing appraisal\nproceedings.\n\n        After a hearing on such petition, the Delaware Court of Chancery will determine which stockholders are entitled to appraisal rights\nand thereafter will appraise the shares owned by those stockholders, determining the fair value of the shares exclusive of any element of\nvalue arising from the accomplishment or expectation of the merger, together with interest to be paid, if any, upon the amount determined\nto be the fair value. Unless the Delaware Court of Chancery in its discretion\n\n121\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n133/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\ndetermines otherwise for good cause shown, interest from the date the merger is completed through the date of payment of the judgment\nwill be compounded quarterly and will accrue at 5% over the Federal Reserve discount rate (including any surcharges) as established from\ntime to time during the period between the date the merger is completed and the date of payment of the judgment. Notwithstanding the\nforegoing, at any time before the entry of judgment in the proceedings, the surviving corporation may pay to each stockholder entitled to\nappraisal an amount in cash (which will be treated as an advance against the payment due to such stockholder), in which case interest shall\naccrue after such payment only upon the sum of (i) the difference, if any, between the amount so paid and the fair value of the shares as\ndetermined by the Delaware Court of Chancery and (ii) interest theretofore accrued, unless paid at that time. When the fair value is\ndetermined, the Delaware Court of Chancery will direct the payment of such value, together with interest, if any, on the amount\ndetermined to be fair value, to the stockholders entitled to receive the same upon the surrender by such holders of the certificates\nrepresenting their shares, if any, or, immediately in the case of any uncertificated shares. The parties have made no determination as to\nwhether such a payment will be made if the merger is consummated, and B/E Aerospace reserves the right to make such a payment upon\nthe consummation of the merger.\n\n        In determining fair value, the Delaware Court of Chancery is to take into account all relevant factors. In Weinberger v. UOP, Inc., et\nal., the Delaware Supreme Court stated that "proof of value by any techniques or methods which are generally considered acceptable in\nthe financial community and otherwise admissible in court" should be considered in an appraisal proceeding and that "[f]air price\nobviously requires consideration of all relevant factors involving the value of a company." The Delaware Supreme Court has stated that in\nmaking this determination of fair value the court must consider market value, asset value, dividends, earnings prospects, the nature of the\nenterprise and any other facts which could be ascertained as of the date of the merger which throw any light on future prospects of the\nmerged corporation. Section 262 provides that fair value is to be determined "exclusive of any element of value arising from the\naccomplishment or expectation of the merger." In Cede & Co. v. Technicolor,  Inc., the Delaware Supreme Court stated that such exclusion\nis a "narrow exclusion [that] does not encompass known elements of value," but which rather applies only to the speculative elements of\nvalue arising from such accomplishment or expectation. In Weinberger, the Delaware Supreme Court construed Section 262 to mean that\n"elements of future value, including the nature of the enterprise, which are known or susceptible of proof as of the date of the merger and\nnot the product of speculation, may be considered."\n\n        Stockholders considering seeking appraisal should bear in mind that the fair value of their shares determined under Section 262 could\nbe more than, the same as, or less than the merger consideration they are entitled to receive pursuant to the merger agreement if they do not\nseek appraisal of their shares, and that opinions of investment banking firms as to the fairness from a financial point of view of the\nconsideration payable in a transaction are not opinions as to fair value under Section 262. Each of Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace\nreserves the right to assert, in any appraisal proceeding, that for purposes of Section 262, the "fair value" of a share of B/E Aerospace\ncommon stock is less than the applicable merger consideration.\n\n        The cost of the appraisal proceeding may be determined by the Delaware Court of Chancery and charged upon the parties as the\nDelaware Court of Chancery deems equitable in the circumstances. However, costs do not include attorneys\' and expert witness fees. The\nDelaware Court of Chancery may order that all or a portion of the expenses incurred by such stockholder in connection with the appraisal\nproceeding, including, without limitation, reasonable attorneys\' fees and the fees and expenses of experts, be charged pro rata against the\nvalue of all shares entitled to appraisal. In the absence of such a determination of assessment, each party bears its own expenses.\n\n        From and after the date of completion of the merger, any stockholder who has duly demanded appraisal in compliance with\nSection 262 will not, after completion of the merger, be entitled to vote\n\n122\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n134/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nfor any purpose any shares subject to such demand or to receive payment of dividends or other distributions on such shares, except for\ndividends or distributions payable to stockholders of record at a date prior to completion of the merger.\n\n        Within 10 days after the effective time, the surviving corporation must give notice of the date that the merger became effective to\neach of B/E Aerospace\'s stockholders who has properly filed a written demand for appraisal, who did not vote in favor of the proposal to\nadopt the merger agreement and who has otherwise complied with Section 262. At any time within 60 days after completion of the merger,\nany stockholder who has demanded appraisal and who has not commenced an appraisal proceeding or joined that proceeding as a named\nparty will have the right to withdraw such stockholder\'s demand for appraisal and to accept the cash and Rockwell Collins common stock\nto which the stockholder is entitled pursuant to the merger. After this period, the stockholder may withdraw such stockholder\'s demand for\nappraisal only with the written approval of the surviving corporation. If no petition for appraisal is filed with the Delaware Court of\nChancery within 120 days after completion of the merger, stockholders\' rights to appraisal will cease and all stockholders will be entitled\nonly to receive the merger consideration as provided for in the merger agreement. No petition timely filed in the Delaware Court of\nChancery demanding appraisal will be dismissed as to any stockholders without the approval of the Delaware Court of Chancery, and that\napproval may be conditioned upon such terms as the Delaware Court of Chancery deems just. However, the preceding sentence will not\naffect the right of any stockholder who has not commenced an appraisal proceeding or joined the proceeding as a named party to withdraw\nsuch stockholder\'s demand for appraisal and to accept the terms offered upon the merger within 60 days after completion of the merger.\n\n        The foregoing is a brief summary of Section 262 that sets forth the procedures for demanding statutory appraisal rights. This\nsummary, however, is not a complete statement of all applicable requirements and is qualified in its entirety by reference to Section 262, a\ncopy of the text of which is attached as Annex E to this joint proxy statement/prospectus.\n\n        Failure to comply strictly with all the procedures set forth in Section 262 may result in the loss of a stockholder\'s statutory\nappraisal rights. Consequently, if you wish to exercise your appraisal rights, you are strongly urged to consult a legal advisor\nbefore attempting to exercise your appraisal rights.\n\nSource of Funding for the Merger \n\n        Rockwell Collins\' obligation to complete the merger is not conditioned upon its obtaining financing.\n\n        Rockwell Collins anticipates that approximately $3.6 billion will be required to pay the aggregate cash portion of the merger\nconsideration to the B/E Aerospace stockholders. Rockwell Collins expects to issue up to $4.35 billion in aggregate principal amount of its\nsenior unsecured notes in one or more public offerings or private placements and borrow up to $1.5 billion under a new senior unsecured\nsyndicated term loan facility. Rockwell Collins has entered into a committed bridge loan credit facility of $4.35 billion that would be\nfunded only to the extent some or all of the senior unsecured notes described above are not issued prior to the consummation of the\nacquisition. Rockwell Collins expects to fund approximately $3.6 billion (based on the outstanding shares of B/E Aerospace common\nstock on January 26, 2017) for the aggregate cash portion of the merger consideration payable to the B/E Aerospace stockholders through\nthe debt financing described above.\n\nNYSE Listing of Rockwell Collins Common Stock; Delisting and Deregistration of B/E Aerospace Common Stock \n\n        Prior to the completion of the merger, Rockwell Collins has agreed to use its reasonable best efforts to cause the shares of Rockwell\nCollins common stock to be issued in connection with the merger to be approved for listing on the NYSE. The listing of the shares of\nRockwell Collins common\n\n123\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n135/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nstock on the NYSE, subject to official notice of issuance, is also a condition to completion of the merger.\n\n        If the merger is completed, B/E Aerospace common stock will cease to be listed on the NASDAQ and B/E Aerospace common stock\nwill be deregistered under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended, which is referred to as the Exchange Act.\n\nLitigation Relating to the Merger \n\n        In connection with the merger, two purported B/E Aerospace stockholders filed two putative class action complaints in the Court of\nChancery in the State of Delaware seeking to enjoin the merger and other relief and, at the same time, moved to expedite proceedings. The\nlawsuits were captioned The Vladimir Gusinsky Living Trust v. B/E Aerospace, et. al., C.A. No. 12957-VCS (Del. Ch.) (filed December 1,\n2016) and Sharon Klein v. B/E Aerospace, et. al., C.A. No. 12969-VCS (Del. Ch.) (filed December 8, 2016). On December 21, 2016, the\ntwo lawsuits were consolidated under the caption In re B/E Aerospace, Inc. Stockholder Litigation, Consol. C.A. No. 12957-VCS, with the\ncomplaint filed on December 1, 2016 in the Gusinsky action as the operative complaint. The defendants in the consolidated action are\nB/E Aerospace, the members of the B/E Aerospace Board, Rockwell Collins and Merger Sub. The defendants filed motions to dismiss on\nDecember 23, 2016. On January 9, 2017, following Rockwell Collins\' and B/E Aerospace\'s agreement to make certain supplemental\ndisclosures, plaintiffs informed the Court of Chancery that they were withdrawing their motion to expedite proceedings.\n\n        The complaint in the consolidated action alleges, among other things, that the directors of B/E Aerospace breached their fiduciary\nduties by misstating and/or omitting material information from the Form S-4 filed by Rockwell Collins on November 23, 2016, and that\nthe corporate defendants aided and abetted such alleged breaches of fiduciary duties.\n\n        In connection with the merger, one purported B/E Aerospace stockholder filed one putative class action lawsuit in the United States\nDistrict Court for the Southern District of Florida seeking to enjoin the merger and other relief. The lawsuit is captioned Kipp Dodds v. B/E\nAerospace, et. al., Case 1:16-cv-25038-KMM (S.D. Fla.) (filed December 5, 2016). The defendants are B/E Aerospace and the members\nof the B/E Aerospace Board. The defendants have not yet responded to the complaint in this lawsuit.\n\n        The complaint in the Dodds action alleges, among other things, that the Form S-4 filed by Rockwell Collins on November 23, 2016\nmisstates and/or omits material information under Sections 14(a) and 20(a) of the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934, SEC Rule 14a-9\nand 17 C.F.R. \xc2\xa7 244.100. On January 5, 2017, plaintiff filed a motion for preliminary injunction to enjoin the B/E Aerospace shareholder\nvote on the merger. On January 20, 2017, following Rockwell Collins\' and B/E Aerospace\'s agreement to make certain supplemental\ndisclosures, plaintiff withdrew his motion for preliminary injunction on the basis that the supplemental disclosures mooted the disclosure\nclaims asserted in the Dodds action, and the court entered an electronic order denying the motion for preliminary injunction as moot.\n\n        The outcome of these lawsuits and any additional lawsuits filed in the future is uncertain. One of the conditions to the closing of the\nmerger is that no governmental authority has issued or entered any order after the date of the merger agreement having the effect of\nenjoining or otherwise prohibiting the consummation of the merger or the other transactions contemplated by the merger agreement, and\nthese lawsuits seek an order enjoining consummation of the merger. If the cases are not resolved, these lawsuits could prevent or delay\ncompletion of the merger and result in substantial costs to Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace, including, but not limited to, costs\nassociated with the indemnification of directors and officers. The defense or settlement of any lawsuit or claim that remains unresolved at\nthe\n\n124\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n136/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\ntime the merger is completed may adversely affect Rockwell Collins\' and B/E Aerospace\'s business, financial condition, results of\noperations and cash flows.\n\nU.S. Federal Income Tax Consequences \n\nTax Consequences of the Merger\n\n        The following is a general discussion of the United States federal income tax consequences of the merger to U.S. holders and non-\nU.S. holders (each as defined below) of B/E Aerospace common stock who hold their stock as a capital asset within the meaning of\nSection 1221 of the Code. The summary is based on the Code, the U.S. Treasury Regulations issued under the Code, and administrative\nrulings and court decisions in effect as of the date of this joint proxy statement/prospectus, all of which are subject to change at any time,\npossibly with retroactive effect. Because holders of Rockwell Collins common stock will retain their shares of Rockwell Collins common\nstock in the merger, the transaction should have no tax consequences for such stockholders.\n\n        For purposes of this discussion, the term "U.S. holder" means a beneficial owner of B/E Aerospace common stock that is for U.S.\nfederal income tax purposes (1) a citizen or individual resident of the United States, (2) a corporation (or other entity taxable as a\ncorporation for U.S. federal income tax purposes) created or organized in the United States, (3) an estate the income of which is includible\nin gross income for U.S. federal income tax purposes regardless of its source or (4) a trust if (A) a court within the United States is able to\nexercise primary supervision over the administration of the trust and one or more U.S. persons have the authority to control all substantial\ndecisions of the trust, or (B) the trust has a valid election in effect under applicable Treasury regulations to be treated as a U.S. person for\nU.S. federal income tax purposes. A "non-U.S. holder" means a beneficial owner of B/E Aerospace common stock that is neither a U.S.\nholder nor a partnership for U.S. federal income tax purposes.\n\n        This summary is not a complete description of all the tax consequences of the merger and, in particular, may not address United\nStates federal income tax considerations applicable to holders of B/E Aerospace common stock who are subject to special treatment under\nU.S. federal income tax law (including, for example, partnerships (or an entity or arrangement treated as a partnership for U.S. federal\nincome tax purposes) and partners therein, financial institutions, dealers in securities, insurance companies or tax-exempt entities, U.S.\nexpatriates, former long-term residents of the United States, holders who acquired B/E Aerospace common stock pursuant to the exercise\nof an employee stock option or right or otherwise as compensation, and holders who hold B/E Aerospace common stock as part of a\nhedge, straddle or conversion transaction). Also, this summary does not address U.S. federal income tax considerations applicable to\nholders of options or warrants to purchase B/E Aerospace common stock, or holders of debt instruments convertible into B/E Aerospace\ncommon stock. In addition, no information is provided with respect to the tax consequences of the merger under the U.S. federal estate,\ngift, Medicare, and alternative minimum tax laws, or any applicable state, local, or foreign tax laws. This summary does not address the\ntax consequences of any transaction other than the merger.\n\n        The tax consequences of the merger will depend on your specific situation. You should consult your own tax advisor as to the\ntax consequences of the merger in your particular circumstances, including the applicability and effect of the alternative minimum\ntax and any state, local, non-U.S. or other tax laws and of changes in those laws.\n\nTax Consequences to U.S. Holders\n\n        The receipt of the merger consideration by U.S. holders in exchange for shares of B/E Aerospace common stock pursuant to the\nmerger will be a taxable transaction for U.S. federal income tax purposes. In general, for U.S. federal income tax purposes, a U.S. holder\nwho receives the merger\n\n125\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n137/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nconsideration in exchange for shares of B/E Aerospace common stock pursuant to the merger will recognize gain or loss in an amount\nequal to the difference, if any, between (1) the sum of the amount of cash, including cash received in lieu of fractional shares, and the fair\nmarket value of Rockwell Collins common stock received in the merger and (2) the U.S. holder\'s adjusted tax basis in its B/E Aerospace\ncommon stock exchanged therefor.\n\n        If a U.S. holder\'s holding period in the shares of B/E Aerospace common stock surrendered in the merger is greater than one year as\nof the date of the merger, the gain or loss will be long-term capital gain or loss. Long-term capital gains of certain non-corporate holders,\nincluding individuals, are generally subject to U.S. federal income tax at preferential rates. The deductibility of a capital loss recognized\non the exchange is subject to limitations. If a U.S. holder acquired different blocks of B/E Aerospace common stock at different times or\ndifferent prices, such U.S. holder must determine its adjusted tax basis and holding period separately with respect to each block of B/E\nAerospace common stock.\n\n        A U.S. holder\'s aggregate tax basis in Rockwell Collins common stock received in the merger will equal the fair market value of the\nRockwell Collins common stock as of the effective time. The holding period of the Rockwell Collins common stock received in the\nmerger will begin on the day after the merger.\n\nTax Consequences to Non-U.S. Holders\n\n        Payments made to a non-U.S. holder in exchange for shares of B/E Aerospace common stock pursuant to the merger generally will\nnot be subject to U.S. federal income tax unless:\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nthe gain, if any, on such shares of B/E Aerospace common stock is effectively connected with a trade or business of the\nnon-U.S. holder in the United States (and, if required by an applicable income tax treaty, is attributable to the non-U.S.\nholder\'s permanent establishment in the United States); \n\nthe non-U.S. holder is an individual who is present in the U.S. for 183 days or more in the taxable year of the exchange of\nshares of B/E Aerospace common stock for the merger consideration pursuant to the merger and certain other conditions\nare met; or \n\nthe non-U.S. holder owned, directly or under certain constructive ownership rules of the Code, more than 5% of B/E\nAerospace common stock at any time during the five-year period preceding the merger, and B/E Aerospace is or has been a\n"U.S. real property holding corporation" within the meaning of Section 897(c)(2) of the Code for U.S. federal income tax\npurposes at any time during the shorter of the five-year period preceding the merger or the period that the non-U.S. holder\nheld B/E Aerospace common stock.\n\n        Gain described in the first bullet point above will be subject to tax at generally applicable U.S. federal income tax rates. Any gain\ndescribed in the first bullet point above of a non-U.S. holder that is a corporation may also be subject to an additional "branch profits tax"\nat a 30% rate (or lower applicable treaty rate). A non-U.S. holder described in the second bullet point immediately above will be subject to\ntax at a rate of 30% (or a lower applicable treaty rate) on any gain realized, which may be offset by U.S.-source capital losses recognized\nin the same taxable year. If the third bullet point above applies to a non-U.S. holder, gain recognized by such holder will be subject to tax\nat generally applicable U.S. federal income tax rates. B/E Aerospace believes that it has not been a "U.S. real property holding\ncorporation" for U.S. federal income tax purposes at any time during the five-year period preceding the merger.\n\n126\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n138/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nInformation Reporting and Backup Withholding\n\n        Payments made in exchange for shares of B/E Aerospace common stock pursuant to the merger may be subject, under certain\ncircumstances, to information reporting and backup withholding. To avoid backup withholding, a U.S. holder that does not otherwise\nestablish an exemption should complete and return an Internal Revenue Service Form W-9, certifying under penalties of perjury that such\nU.S. holder is a "United States person" (within the meaning of the Code), that the taxpayer identification number provided is correct and\nthat such U.S. holder is not subject to backup withholding.\n\n        A non-U.S. holder may be subject to information reporting and backup withholding on the merger consideration received in exchange\nfor B/E Aerospace common stock unless the Non-U.S. Holder establishes an exemption, for example, by properly certifying its non-U.S.\nstatus on an appropriate version of Internal Revenue Service Form W-8.\n\n        Backup withholding is not an additional tax. Any amounts withheld under the backup withholding rules may be refunded or credited\nagainst a holder\'s U.S. federal income tax liability, if any, provided that such holder furnishes the required information to the Internal\nRevenue Service in a timely manner.\n\n        Holders of B/E Aerospace common stock are urged to consult their own tax advisors with respect to the tax consequences of\nthe merger in their particular circumstances, including the applicability and effect of the alternative minimum tax and any state,\nlocal, non-U.S. or other tax laws and of changes in those laws.\n\nRestrictions on Sales of Shares of Rockwell Collins Common Stock Received in the Merger \n\n        All shares of Rockwell Collins common stock received by B/E Aerospace stockholders in the merger will be freely tradable for\npurposes of the Securities Act and the Exchange Act, except for shares of Rockwell Collins common stock received by any B/E Aerospace\nstockholder who becomes an "affiliate" of Rockwell Collins after completion of the merger (such as B/E Aerospace directors or executive\nofficers who become directors or executive officers of Rockwell Collins after the merger). This joint proxy statement/prospectus does not\ncover resales of shares of Rockwell Collins common stock received by any person upon completion of the merger, and no person is\nauthorized to make any use of this joint proxy statement/prospectus in connection with any resale.\n\n127\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n139/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nTHE MERGER AGREEMENT \n\n        This section of this joint proxy statement/prospectus describes the material provisions of the merger agreement, but does not describe\nall of the terms of the merger agreement and may not contain all of the information about the merger agreement that is important to you.\nThe following summary is qualified by reference to the complete text of the merger agreement, which is attached as Annex A to this joint\nproxy statement/prospectus and incorporated by reference herein. The rights and obligations of Rockwell Collins, B/E Aerospace and the\nMerger Sub are governed by the express terms and conditions of the merger agreement and not by this summary or any of the other\ninformation contained in this joint proxy statement/prospectus. You are urged to read the full text of the merger agreement because it is the\nlegal document that governs the merger.\n\n        The merger agreement contains representations, warranties and covenants by each of the parties thereto, which were made only for\npurposes of the merger agreement, as of specified dates. The representations, warranties and covenants in the merger agreement were\nmade solely for the benefit of the parties thereto; may be subject to limitations agreed upon by the contracting parties, including being\nqualified by confidential disclosures made for the purposes of allocating contractual risk between the parties to such agreement instead of\nestablishing these matters as facts; and may be subject to standards of materiality applicable to the contracting parties that differ from\nthose applicable to investors. Investors should not rely on representations, warranties and covenants or any descriptions thereof as\ncharacterizations of the actual state of facts or condition of Rockwell Collins, Merger Sub, B/E Aerospace or any of their respective\nsubsidiaries or affiliates. Investors are not entitled to rely on the representations and warranties, which are only for the benefit of the\nparties to the merger agreement. Moreover, information concerning the subject matter of the representations, warranties and covenants\nmay change after the date of the merger agreement, which subsequent information may or may not be fully reflected in Rockwell Collins\'\nor B/E Aerospace\'s public disclosures. Each such agreement should not be read alone, but should instead be read in conjunction with the\nother information regarding the merger agreement, the merger, Rockwell Collins, B/E Aerospace and their respective affiliates and\nbusinesses, which is contained in or incorporated by reference into this joint proxy statement/prospectus, as well as in the Forms 10-K,\nForms 10-Q and other filings that each of Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace have made or will make with the SEC.\n\nStructure of the Merger \n\n        The merger agreement provides that, upon the terms and subject to the conditions set forth in the merger agreement, and in\naccordance with the DGCL, at the effective time, Merger Sub will be merged with and into B/E Aerospace. As a result of the merger, the\nseparate corporate existence of Merger Sub will cease, and B/E Aerospace will continue as the surviving corporation and a direct or\nindirect, wholly owned subsidiary of Rockwell Collins. The certificate of incorporation of B/E Aerospace, as in effect immediately prior to\nthe effective time, will be amended in its entirety as set forth in Exhibit A to the merger agreement and, as so amended will be the\ncertificate of incorporation of the surviving corporation. The bylaws of Merger Sub, as in effect immediately prior to the effective time,\nwill be the bylaws of the surviving corporation, except as to the name of the surviving corporation, which shall be "B/E Aerospace, Inc."\n\nMerger Consideration to be Received by B/E Aerospace Stockholders \n\n        At the effective time, upon the terms and subject to the conditions set forth in the merger agreement, each share of B/E Aerospace\ncommon stock issued and outstanding immediately prior to the effective time (other than (i) shares of B/E Aerospace common stock that\nare owned, directly or indirectly, by Rockwell Collins, B/E Aerospace (including as treasury stock) or Merger Sub, which will be cancelled\nimmediately prior to the effective time, and (ii) shares of B/E Aerospace common stock with respect to which appraisal rights are properly\ndemanded and not withdrawn under Section 262 of\n\n128\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n140/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nthe DGCL, both of which are collectively referred to as the B/E Aerospace excluded shares) will be converted into the right to receive the\nmerger consideration, which is:\n\n$34.10 in cash, without interest, from Rockwell Collins; and \n\na fraction of a validly issued, fully paid and non-assessable share of Rockwell Collins common stock, having a value equal\nto $27.90, subject to adjustment based upon a two-way collar mechanism described below.\n\n        The exchange ratio will be calculated based upon the volume-weighted average price per share of Rockwell Collins common stock on\nthe NYSE (as reported by Bloomberg L.P. or, if not reported on Bloomberg L.P., in another authoritative source mutually selected by\nRockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace) on each of the 20 consecutive trading days ending with the trading day immediately prior to the\nclosing date, which is referred to as the Rockwell Collins stock price. If the Rockwell Collins stock price is greater than or equal to $77.41\nand less than or equal to $89.97, the exchange ratio will be equal to the quotient of (i) $27.90 divided by (ii) the Rockwell Collins stock\nprice, which, in each case, will result in the stock consideration having a value equal to $27.90. If the Rockwell Collins stock price is less\nthan $77.41 or greater than $89.97, then a two-way collar mechanism will apply pursuant to which, (a) if the Rockwell Collins stock price\nis greater than $89.97, the exchange ratio will be fixed at 0.3101 and the value of the stock consideration will be more than $27.90, and\n(b) if the Rockwell Collins stock price is less than $77.41, the exchange ratio will be fixed at 0.3604 and the value of the stock\nconsideration will be less than $27.90.\n\n        The following table sets forth an illustrative range of the potential merger consideration based on various Rockwell Collins stock\nprices, ranging from $65.00 to $110.00, which reflect the 52-week stock price range for Rockwell Collins common stock as of January 26,\n2017, plus or minus approximately 10 percent, as applicable. The highlighted rows represent the Rockwell Collins stock price values that\nare within the two-way collar mechanism described above.\n\nRockwell Collins\nStock Price\n\n \n\nValue of Stock\nConsideration\nper share of\nB/E Aerospace\nCommon Stock\n\n \n\nCash Consideration\nper share of\nB/E Aerospace\nCommon Stock(1)\n\n \n\nTotal\nConsideration\n\n \n\n \n\nExchange\nRatio\n0.3604 \n0.3604 \n0.3604 \n0.3604 \n0.3604 \n0.3487 \n0.3361 \n0.3244 \n0.3134 \n0.3101 \n0.3101 \n0.3101 \n0.3101 \n0.3101 \n0.3101 \n0.3101 \n\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n\n65.00 \n68.00 \n71.00 \n74.00 \n77.00 \n80.00 \n83.00 \n86.00 \n89.00 \n92.00 \n95.00 \n98.00 \n101.00 \n104.00 \n107.00 \n110.00 \n\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n\n23.42 \n24.50 \n25.58 \n26.66 \n27.75 \n27.90 \n27.90 \n27.90 \n27.90 \n28.52 \n29.45 \n30.38 \n31.32 \n32.25 \n33.18 \n34.11 \n\n129\n\n34.10 \n34.10 \n34.10 \n34.10 \n34.10 \n34.10 \n34.10 \n34.10 \n34.10 \n34.10 \n34.10 \n34.10 \n34.10 \n34.10 \n34.10 \n34.10 \n\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n$\n\n57.52 \n58.60 \n59.68 \n60.76 \n61.85 \n62.00 \n62.00 \n62.00 \n62.00 \n62.62 \n63.55 \n64.48 \n65.42 \n66.35 \n67.28 \n68.21 \n\n(1)\n\nB/E Aerospace stockholders will receive $34.10 in cash per share of B/E Aerospace common stock.\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n141/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\n        The examples above are illustrative only. It is impossible to accurately predict the market price of Rockwell Collins common stock at\nthe effective time or during the period over which the Rockwell Collins stock price is calculated, and therefore impossible to accurately\npredict the number or value of the shares of Rockwell Collins common stock that B/E Aerospace stockholders will receive in the merger.\nYou should obtain current market quotations for shares of Rockwell Collins common stock.\n\n        All fractional shares of Rockwell Collins common stock that would otherwise be issued to a B/E Aerospace stockholder as part of the\nmerger consideration will be aggregated to create whole shares of Rockwell Collins common stock that will be issued to B/E Aerospace\nstockholders as part of the merger consideration. If a fractional share of Rockwell Collins common stock remains payable to a\nB/E Aerospace stockholder after aggregating all fractional shares of Rockwell Collins common stock payable to such B/E Aerospace\nstockholder, then such B/E Aerospace stockholder will be paid, in lieu of such remaining fractional share of Rockwell Collins common\nstock, an amount in cash, without interest, rounded down to the nearest cent, equal to the product of (x) the amount of the fractional share\ninterest in a share of Rockwell Collins common stock to which such holder would otherwise be entitled (rounded to three decimal places)\nand (y) the Rockwell Collins stock price.\n\n        Rockwell Collins stockholders will continue to own their existing shares of common stock of Rockwell Collins, the form of which\nwill not be changed by the transaction.\n\nTreatment of B/E Aerospace Stock-Based Awards \n\nB/E Aerospace\n\nTreatment of B/E Aerospace Restricted Stock Awards and RSU Awards\n\n        Upon completion of the merger, each outstanding award of B/E Aerospace restricted stock and each B/E Aerospace restricted stock\nunit award that in each case was granted prior to the date of the merger agreement will (i) become fully vested and, to the extent such\naward is subject to performance conditions, such performance conditions will be deemed satisfied at the maximum level and (ii) be\ncancelled and converted into the right to receive a lump sum cash payment per share of B/E Aerospace common stock underlying such\naward equal to the value of the per share merger consideration less any applicable withholding taxes. Upon completion of the merger,\nexcept for outstanding restricted stock unit awards granted to the executive officers of B/E Aerospace in November 2016, consistent with\npast practice, which will be cancelled and converted into a cash payment pursuant to their terms, each outstanding award of B/E Aerospace\nrestricted stock and each B/E Aerospace restricted stock unit award that in each case was granted on or following the date of the merger\nagreement will be assumed by Rockwell Collins and converted into a Rockwell Collins award of restricted stock or restricted stock unit\naward, as applicable, which will vest subject to the grantee\'s continued service with Rockwell Collins or its affiliates through each\napplicable vesting date (with any performance conditions that were applicable to the B/E Aerospace award deemed satisfied at target level\nperformance and following the closing, the converted Rockwell Collins award subject only to time-based vesting) covering a number of\nshares of Rockwell Collins common stock (rounded down to the nearest whole share) determined by multiplying the number of shares of\nB/E Aerospace that were subject to the B/E Aerospace award by a ratio of the value of the merger consideration divided by the Rockwell\nCollins stock price (with the value of the stock consideration portion of the merger consideration determined by multiplying the number of\nsuch shares of Rockwell Collins common stock by the Rockwell Collins stock price).\n\nTreatment of B/E Aerospace Stock Units\n\n        Each stock unit credited to the account of any current or former director under the B/E Aerospace Amended and Restated Non-\nEmployee Directors Stock and Deferred Compensation Plan that is outstanding immediately prior to the effective time of the merger,\nwhich is referred to as the effective time, will be converted into the right to receive the merger consideration.\n\n130\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n142/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\n        For a more complete description of the treatment of outstanding restricted stock unit awards granted to the executive officers of B/E\nAerospace in November 2016, see "The reducing the amount of cash, if any, that would\notherwise be provided to holders of such awards. If no cash is to be provided to a holder of such an award or if the amount of cash that\nwould otherwise be provided to a holder of such awards is not sufficient to cover the applicable withholding taxes, then the number of\nshares of Rockwell Collins common stock that would otherwise be provided to the holder in accordance with the terms described above\nwill be reduced to the extent necessary to cover the shortfall.\n\nClosing \n\nEffective Time \n\n        Unless another time, date or place is agreed to in writing by Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace, the closing of the merger will\noccur on a date to be specified by Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace, but no later than the second business day after the satisfaction or\nwaiver of the closing conditions set forth in the merger agreement (other than those conditions that by their terms are to be satisfied at the\nclosing, but subject to the satisfaction or waiver of such conditions).\n\n        The merger will become effective at the time the certificate of merger has been duly filed with the Delaware Secretary of State or at\nsuch other date and time as is agreed between Rockwell Collins and B/E Aerospace and specified in the certificate of merger.\n\nConversion of Shares; Exchange of Certificates; No Fractional Shares \n\nConversion and Exchange of B/E Aerospace Common Stock\n\n        The conversion of shares of B/E Aerospace common stock, other than the B/E Aerospace excluded shares, into the right to receive the\nmerger consideration will occur automatically at the effective time. As promptly as practicable after the effective time, but in no event later\nthan 5 business days after such time, Rockwell Collins\' exchange agent will mail a letter of transmittal to each holder of record of a\ncertificate or book-entry share, in each case, representing shares of B/E Aerospace common stock, whose shares of B/E Aerospace\ncommon stock were converted into the right to receive the merger consideration. The letter of transmittal will specify that delivery will be\neffected and risk of loss and title to such certificates or book-entry shares, as applicable, will pass only upon proper delivery of such\ncertificates (or affidavits of loss in lieu of such certificates) or book-entry shares to the exchange agent. The letter of transmittal will be\naccompanied by instructions for surrendering such certificates or book-entry shares in exchange for the merger consideration, any\ndividends or distributions payable pursuant to the merger agreement and cash in lieu of any fractional shares of Rockwell Collins common\nstock payable as part of the merger consideration. No interest will be paid or will accrue on any cash payable upon surrender of a\ncertificate or book-entry share. B/E Aerospace stockholders should not return stock certificates with the enclosed proxy card.\n\n        At the effective time, shares of B/E Aerospace common stock will no longer be outstanding, will be automatically cancelled and will\ncease to exist, and each certificate or book-entry share that represented shares of B/E Aerospace common stock immediately prior to the\neffective time will cease to have any rights with respect to such B/E Aerospace common stock other than the right to receive, upon\nsurrender of such certificate or book-entry share, the merger consideration as described above and subject to the terms and conditions set\nforth in the merger agreement.\n\n        Following surrender by holders of certificates or book-entry shares previously representing B/E Aerospace common stock to the\nexchange agent for exchange, such holders will receive any\n\n131\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n143/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\ndividends or other distributions with a record date after the effective time and a payment date on or prior to the date of such surrender with\nrespect to shares of Rockwell Collins common stock they receive as merger consideration, without interest.\n\n        Rockwell Collins and the exchange agent will be entitled to deduct and withhold from the consideration otherwise payable to any\nperson under the merger agreement such amounts as Rockwell Collins and the exchange agent are required to deduct and withhold from\nsuch consideration under the Code or under any provision of state, local or foreign tax law.\n\n        All shares of Rockwell Collins common stock issued pursuant to the merger agreement will be issued in book-entry form unless a\nphysical certificate is requested.\n\nRepresentations and Warranties; Material Adverse Effect \n\n        The merger agreement contains a number of representations and warranties made by the parties thereto that are subject in some cases\nto exceptions and qualifications (including exceptions that have not had, and would not reasonably be expected to have, a "material\nadverse effect"). See the definition of "material adverse effect" beginning on page 133 of this joint proxy statement/prospectus. The\nparties\' representations and warranties under the merger agreement relate to, among other things:\n\ndue organization, valid existence, good standing and qualification to do business; \n\ncapitalization and ownership of subsidiaries; \n\ncorporate authorization of the merger agreement and the transactions contemplated by the merger agreement and the valid\nand binding nature of the merger agreement; \n\nthe unanimous approval and recommendation by such party\'s board of directors of the merger agreement and the\ntransactions contemplated by the merger agreement; \n\nthe B/E Aerospace Stockholder Approval and the Rockwell Collins Stockholder Approval; \n\nrequired consents and approvals from governmental entities; \n\nthe absence of any conflicts or violations of organizational documents and other agreements or laws; \n\ndocuments filed with the SEC and financial statements; \n\ninternal controls and disclosure controls and procedures relating to financial reporting; \n\nthe absence of certain changes or events; \n\nconduct of their businesses in the ordinary course and the absence of a material adverse effect; \n\nthe absence of certain undisclosed liabilities; \n\nthe absence of certain legal proceedings, investigations and governmental orders; \n\npossession of, and compliance with, permits necessary for the conduct of such party\'s business; \n\naccuracy of information supplied or to be supplied in connection with this joint proxy statement/prospectus; \n\nemployee benefit plans; \n\nemployment and labor matters; \n\ntax matters; \n\nmaterial contracts and related party transactions;\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n144/330\n\n\x0c8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n132\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\n145/330\n\n\x0c\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n8/28/2019\n\nhttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/861361/000104746917000512/a2230778zdefm14a.htm\n\nTable of Contents\n\nintellectual property;
